Ottawa,
January 4, 1945.

Reverend Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 17th instant, enclosing the September quarter return of the Aklavik C.E. Residential School, it is found that the name of Bertha Stewart, No. 032, is shown on the return, although her name did not appear on the June quarter return. Please let me know if she has been re-admitted to the school.

Dear Sirs,

Enclosed are the Quarterly Returns for the Quarter ending December 31, 1945.

Please note on the Admission form-

057 Zena Kendi entered school Sept. I 1945 and I believe I omitted to put her name on the form last quarter.

60 John Wilfred Snowshoe was sent down from McPherson by his father along with his two brothers. The doctor has examined him and passed him but the father has not yet been in town to sign the application forms. We will forward them as soon as signed.

The hope of a school at McPherson has influenced our numbers from there this year. There was a great deal of sickness in the school last year which was of a T.B. nature. We refused a number of old pupils on this score and other children were not returned to us for the same reason. We are pleased to be able to say that this year we are free from this type of trouble in spite of epidemics of communicable diseases.

There are more children of school age at McPherson than can be accommodated in this school and the day school there. When next Sept., arrives there will be some difficulty in deciding who should come here and who stay up there. Who should decide this? The Family Allowance puts Education on a sort of compulsory basis. Who is to do the compelling? No one wants to send their children away from home to attend school. Someone should be delegated to say who is to attend the day school and who attends the Residential. There was a police constable at McPherson last summer. He if he were there again might be a favourable person or the Indian Agent could perhaps do so when he is down at Treaty time.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Sir,

I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of October 27th, file No 364097, also your of same date, file No 500193-3, in reference to the Indian day schools in this Agency.

In reply I beg to say that the Bishop of Yukon's Secretary has been notified that the Department is allowing payment, at the rate of $3.00 per day, for each day that the schools at Champagne Landing, Little Salmon, Rampart House and Teslin Lake were open during the quarters for which returns were forwarded and that no grant would be made for the Shingle Point Eskimo day school in view of the fact that only two pupils were taught during the period the school was open.

Regarding these schools being in operation at such infrequent intervals I may say that the chief reason is, the Indians are usually away during the winter months scattered in small parties in their hunting and trapping grounds. During the short summer they usually gather together in their various villages. It has been the custom of the Bishop to engage the services of students to come north to teach these Indians during the time they are all together in their villages. This entails considerable expense but the Bishop feels that he ought to do something towards giving the Indians some little education. Whether such intermittent teaching is of any real value is open to question, very little progress is possible under such conditions, it leads one to doubt whether the expenditure is justifiable.

On the other hand, if the Bishop did not bring in these students the Indians would get absolutely nothing in the way of education. It is only with the aid of the Department's grants that His Lordship is able to do this.

Referring to the question as to whether the Department gets value for the expenditures incurred my reply is, I do not think it does, at the same time one feels that the Indians should be given some opportunity of acquiring the art of reading and writing.

The Bishop of Yukon is in Toronto for the winter, he will, no doubt, visit the Department before he returns north.

Your obedient servant,

J.D. McLean, Esq.
Asst Deputy and Secretary.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 1st ultimo, relative to the arrangement made with His Lordship the Bishop of Yukon in connection with the Indian day schools in the Yukon.

In reply I beg to say that as the teachers at Moosehide and Selkirk are qualified, and the schools conducted regularly, the Department will allow salary for the ten teaching months at the rate of $110 per month. Payment of rental formerly allowed will be discontinued.

Relative to the other schools where the work is seasonal, the Department agreed to pay a per diem rate of $3 for the days these schools are in operation.

The work at Rampart House and Old Crow Village is linked together, and these schools should be fairly regular all the year round. It is the intention to have the regular missionary teach in one or other throughout the year, and he will be assisted by native workers at both schools. It is the intention of His Lordship to use the graduates of Carcross for this purpose.

Relative to Ross River and Little Salmon, His Lordship stated that the work at these points is linked together and is bound to be more regular, and will be conducted only during the summer.

The work at Teslin Lake and Champagne Landing will be fairly regularly conducted. We understand that the Indians move from one point to the other.

John Hawksley, Esq.,
Indian Superintendent,
Dawson, Y.T.

The supervision of the work in Yukon has undergone several changes, and therefore I feel that I should take it upon myself as Archbishop or Metropolitan to write you. The Rt. Rev. A.H. Sovereign who succeeded me as Bishop of Yukon has been transferred to the Diocese of Athabasca and Bishop Geddes of Mackenzie River is supervising the work for the time being. However he has not had the opportunity of getting acquainted with the condition of affairs.

I therefore write to you as representing Yukon in a general way, and I wish to ask you to reconsider the question of discontinuing the grants to the above named places. You will understand that in some cases preparation has to be made a long time ahead. For example two students have been already sent in to Teslin Lake and Champagne Landing, and their expenses have been paid, and by this time they will be pretty well on through their Summer's work. It is impossible to curtail this expense to any great extent, and I hope you will be able to give the grant especially to these two places.

The Anglican Church has been endeavoring to co-operate with the Indian Department for the benefit of the Indian children in Yukon. Some one has to make preparations for these schools; as I have mentioned above the preparations have to be made some time in advance. Bishop Sovereign made all arrangements for the carrying on of the work this Summer the same as other Summers with the expectation that the Indian Department would stand by us in helping out in connection with this important work.

I wish to ask therefore if you will kindly reconsider the question and make allowance for these schools for the Summer months of 1933. I am sending a copy of this letter to Bishop Sovereign and also to Bishop Geddes.

Dear Sir,

Your letter of June 19th, File #166-12-1, has been forwarded to me from Yukon, in reference to Grants to Indian Day Schools in Yukon.

I have been transferred from Yukon to Athabasca this Spring, but all the arrangements for the Indian Day Schools in Yukon had been completed by me before I left the Far North. I am very sorry that your Department has made this ruling and I trust that it is not too late to rescind it, for it works a very great hardship on the Church of England in Yukon and to the Indian wards, for which we along with you are jointly responsible.

1. This summer term of three or four months is the only time for the education of the Indian boys and girls. During the summer months, they come into these central Posts with their parents, and they are thus together in one place. For many years, the Church of England has sent into these districts qualified Missionaries and Teachers, some of them University Graduates and some of them Medical Students of the higher years. In an intensive training, these Teachers have given to the Indians a knowledge of the written and spoken English, a training in simple Arithmetic, a knowledge of the rules of health and sanitation, a love for their Country and their Empire and a true Loyalty to their Empire's King. Moreover, they are taught the Ten Commandments and a knowledge of God, so that they might grow up into law-abiding Citizens. Surely such a training is beyond estimation.

2. Again, may I state that the Church of England is the only Church in all of Yukon doing this work. The other Churches in a fine manifestation of sportsmanship have recognized that the Church of England was first on the ground and was also doing the work with care and efficiency, and have therefore left the work ENTIRELY to us. There is no overlapping. Your Department has always recognized this and has always loyally supported the work by Grants per capita, a fair and reasonable basis of apportionment. The work is being done on behalf of the wards of your Department; it is being done efficiently; surely you would not take away this small and necessary assistance which you have given us in the Past.

3. I would emphasize the Medical side of the work. At Teslin, Rampart House and Champagne, our Teachers sent in each year, really
act as Doctors and First aid men, and have rendered valuable aid in the caring for the sick, and first aid to those who have been injured in accidents. For many years, our Teacher at Champagne has been a Medical Student, in the persons of Dr. Herschel Stringer and Dr. Wilfred Stringer, each returning for a three year period. In 1932, Dr. Wilfred Stringer saved a man's life, ill from blood poisoning, who certainly would have died without the skilful treatment which he received from this Teacher. In fact, the Natives had already prepared a coffin for the sick man. Do you not think that a work such as this should not go unrecognized by the Department of Indian Affairs, especially when it is being done at so small a cost to the Department.

4. The cost of this service to the Indians as given by the Church is very great. I trust that you will recognize this in your consideration of the whole problem. These Student-teachers are brought out in the month of May from Toronto, Winnipeg and Vancouver, and in September their fares are paid to their respective Colleges and homes. This matter of transportation alone is one of great expense, for the distances are great and the rates are high. It is along way from Toronto to Champagne and Teslin. We also give to each man a salary of $225.00 for the summer, pay their board and provide a lodging place. We greatly need the assistance of the Department in these heavy expenses, for they are incurred by the Church in serving the Wards of the Department. Your Department pays for the erection of the Buildings for the Indian Boarding Schools, and also gives a per capita Grant for the food and clothing of the Indians at those Schools. Why then take away the Grant for the education of the children in these isolated Posts who are not able to go to the Boarding Schools, for their accommodation is very limited? Please do not make it hard and almost impossible to care for these less fortunate Children, who are not able to enter these splendid Boarding Schools.

5. Come with me to the first named place, Teslin Lake, a journey of over 200 miles from Whitehorse. Here for three years, we have sent Mr. S.W.Semple, B.A. He comes from the University of British Columbia in Vancouver. We pay his fare from Vancouver to Skagway, from Skagway to Carcross by rail, from Carcross to Atlin by Plane, and there hire an Indian Guide to take him over the long trail to Teslin. Here for four months, he labours in this isolated Post among these Indians. They have only six mails a year. He holds School every weekday for the full day, with the exception of Saturday, and he has a Class of forty (40) pupils. Three nights a week are given up to the Adult Education Class attended by twelve (12) older Young People who study simple Book-keeping, letter writing etc. Services are held on Sunday attended by the whole tribe. The only Education received by the members of this Tribe has been given by the Church of England assisted by your Department, and this work has gone on for many years. In Ottawa, the children of the City are given a first class education by the State. Why should not the State at least assist in the education of these Canadian children in the Far North? It covers only four months in the year.

6. As to the efficiency of the work done, I would humbly ask you for opinions from Mr. Hawksley, the Indian Agent, Col. Allard of the R.C.M.P. and Mr. Drury of the Trading Firm of Taylor.
and Drury at Whitehorse, who visits these Posts each year. May I say that I have personally visited these isolated Posts and have lived for as long as two weeks in their midst and am able to know from personal contact of the work done.

7. Finally, may I say that I as usual depended on the Department of Indian Affairs and in April prepared to place in these Posts Teachers as in years past. They are now on the field, for I did not receive any word whatever from the Department as to any reduction in Grants, least of all a cancellation. I trust that you will see the fairness of an appeal for the usual Grants for this year, and with returning prosperity already in sight, that it will not be necessary for you to cancel or even reduce the usual Grants made on behalf of this very important work—the education and training of these Indian Wards, body, mind and soul,—for whom we are all equally responsible.

I therefore humbly ask for a reconsideration of the whole problem and I do sincerely trust that it may be possible for you to continue these Grants, not only for this year, but for the coming years.

I wish also to thank you and your Department for the sympathetic and reasonable assistance which you have given to the Church of England in the discharge of these necessary duties during these many years past,—services of a most valuable and necessary character, for which all citizens of Canada are equally responsible.

Believe me,

Yours faithfully,

A.W. Souriquy.

Dear Sir,

I have before me your letter of Sept. 7th 1933, File No. 166-3-1, addressed to Right Rev. A.H. Sovereign, Bishop of Athabasca, with reference to grants allowed for Indian day schools in the Yukon. I have also before me a copy of Bishop Sovereign's letter to you of August 21st, 1933.

I am writing to ask you to consider the possibility of continuing the grants to the Indian Day Schools at Carmacks, Champagne, and Teslin during the year 1934.

First of all may I express my appreciation of your continuance of the grants to these schools for the year 1933.

Bishop Sovereign went into the matter so thoroughly in his letter that I feel sure nothing will be gained if I were to go over the same ground. From a knowledge gained in the past thirteen years from close and intimate contact with our Indian and Eskimo peoples of the North, I want to add my testimony to the value of the work that the Day schools are doing among our Native peoples. Work that I am convinced does not take second place even to the work that is being done in the Residential Schools. Some of the finest of our Indians in the North are those whose only education is what they were allowed to receive for a few short weeks in the summer of each year. Their education has not progressed so far as the graduates of the Residential Schools, yet they speak English, they can read and write, and in their standing in the Community, in their honesty and integrity, they are second to none.

It is not my intention or desire to belittle the work of our Indian Residential Schools. Nor do I wish to build up a case for our Day Schools by detracting in any way from the work being done in the Residential Schools. To my mind the two systems are complementary, for the Residential School makes possible the education of children who probably never come within a hundred miles or more of any of the Day Schools. At the same time I am convinced that where it is possible to operate a Day School it is by far the better way to educate the Indian Child. In a vast area, sparsely populated, such as the Yukon it is of course out of the question to give each child the opportunity of attending a Day School. But I think it would be most unwise to deprive the people of Teslin, for example, of the little opportunity we are giving them to become better citizens. As citizens of a Christian country we have a duty and a responsibility to the Native peoples of Canada, a responsibility that can, I am confident, be most efficiently discharged through the cooperation of the forces of Church and State.

Before I conclude, I should like to point out that during the Calendar year 1931, the Diocese of Yukon received from your Department, in the way of grants to Day Schools, St. Paul's Hostel, etc., the sum of $9116.99. In 1932 we received $7639.56. Up to the tenth of November 1933 we had received $3072.67. This latter sum of course will be increased by the payments for the December quarter and other adjustments, but I doubt very much that the total for 1933 will reach $6000.00. During this three year period the number of our workers has not decreased. We have effected some economies in the operation of St. Paul's Hostel due to a decrease in the number of children attending that Institution, but we have been hard pressed to maintain the work on our greatly reduced income.

No one sympathises with you more than I do, in your efforts to maintain, on a greatly reduced income, the vast amount of work that you are doing for the Indians of our great Dominion. At the same time I hope you will see the justice of my contention that in the past two years the Diocese of Yukon has borne at least its fair share of the economies effected; further that, if reductions are still necessary, they should be spread over the whole work and not confined to any one locality.

I am planning to leave here for the Yukon about March 10th, travelling by way of Edmonton and Vancouver. I should like to hear from you prior to that date, if possible, as to whether we may expect any grants this year for the Day Schools at Carmacks, Champagne, and Teslin. I am hoping to make arrangements when I am in Vancouver, for the men to conduct the work at these three missions this year. But unless your Department can provide the usual grant for the Day Schools, I do not think it will be possible for us to open these schools this year.
I sincerely hope that you may find it possible to continue the grants to the Day Schools at Carmacks, Champagne, and Teslin.

Yours faithfully,

MEMORANDUM: Mr. Sutherland,

With reference to your memorandum of the 24th instant, also to Mr. MacKenzie's memorandum, attached thereto, in regard to the request of His Lordship, Bishop Geddes, that cheques for the salaries of the teachers of the summer schools Champagne, Teslin and Carmacks, in the Yukon, be made payable and forwarded to the Diocese of the Yukon, instead of to the individual teachers, I have to draw your attention to the Treasury Board's Minute, T156134B, dated January 4th, 1935, to the effect that an employee may authorize the proceeds of his salary cheque to be deposited to his credit in a chartered bank. He may assign a portion of his salary to the Civil Service Co-operative Credit Society and to certain Civil Service Mutual Benefit Societies, or to his wife or relative, when for the purpose of providing for the maintenance of dependents, provided the Deputy Head gives his consent, but "no other assignment or charge upon the salary or wages of any employee of Canada shall be received, recognized or acted upon."

In view of the foregoing, it is regretted that it will not be possible to meet the wishes of His Lordship, Bishop Geddes and make the teacher's salary cheques payable to the Diocese of the Yukon.

Mr. MacKenzie's memorandum is returned herewith as requested.

Representative of the Treasury.

EMCL/J
Ottawa, March 27th, 1936.

Right Reverend Sir,

With reference to your verbal request that the cheques for the salaries of the teachers of the summer schools in the Yukon be made payable and sent to the Diocese of the Yukon instead of to the individual teachers, I took up your request with the Representative of the Treasury. He advises me as follows:

"I have to draw your attention to the Treasury Board's Minute, T156134B, dated January 4th, 1935, to the effect that an employee may authorize the proceeds of his salary cheque to be deposited to his credit in a chartered bank. He may assign a portion of his salary to the Civil Service Co-operative Credit Society and to certain Civil Service Mutual Benefit Societies, or to his wife or relative, when for the purpose of providing for the maintenance of dependents, provided the Deputy Head gives his consent, but "no other assignment or charge upon the salary or wages of any employee of Canada shall be received, recognized or acted upon".

You will note that the above regulation precludes our complying with your request.

I have the honour to be,

Right Reverend Sir,

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Bishop of Yukon,
Fort Smith, N.W.T.

Extract from Dr. McGill's letter of November 21, 1942, addressed to Rt. Rev. W.A. Geddes, D.D., Bishop of Yukon, Dawson, Y.T.

I am disposed to think that some misunderstanding has arisen in respect to the operation of seasonal schools in the Yukon Territory. There is nothing on file here to indicate that the grants usually made to these schools have been withdrawn at any time. In the estimates of this year I note that provision has been made for the operation of the following schools: Champagne Landing, Old Crow Village, Rampart House, Teslin Lake and Whitehorse, in addition to the two more or less regular schools at Moosehide and Selkirk. The total amount set apart for the operation of these schools is $3,790.

Extract from reply dated December 17, 1942, received from Bishop Geddes.

I am a little concerned about the first paragraph in your letter regarding grants for the Seasonal Day Schools operated by our Church at Teslin, Champagne and Whitehorse. These three schools have been operated by our Church during the past three summers but we have been unable to receive the grants from your Department that formerly were paid. In fact in 1940 when the return for the Teslin Day School was forwarded to Ottawa it was returned with the notification that no grant would be paid. I gather from your letter that the funds for these schools are in the estimates that have been approved by Parliament and I shall be grateful if you can advise me as to how we can secure the grants for these schools that we have been operating.
Ottawa,

INDIAN DAY SCHOOL REGULATIONS

All Indian schools shall be kept open for not less than 200 days in each year.

Schedule shall be opened after the summer holidays on September 1st, unless this date should be Labour Day, and shall close for Christmas holidays on December 22nd.

The winter term will commence on January 3rd and end on June 30th in each year.

The following holidays will be allowed: Christmas Day, New Year's Day, all Statutory Labor Days, Thanksgiving Day, Easter Monday, Good Friday, Easter Tuesday, Good Friday, Easter Monday, the remainder of the week following Easter Monday.

In addition to the above the Roman Catholic Schools will be allowed as holidays a limited number of holy days of obligation not exceeding five a year, which will be counted as teaching days and for which payment of salary will be demanded.

When in the interest of the school work such action may be desirable, the holidays allowed during the summer (two months) must, upon the recommendation of the local agent, be approved of by the Department.

The morning session shall be held each season of not less than 15 and not more than 90 minutes, plus, with a recess.

Schools of children will be held on a basis of ten (10) teaching months in each school year.

Schools shall be held at the end of each quarter, upon receipt of quarterly returns. As school is often shorter each month in the quarter, each quarter will be considered separately.

Each school must be opened and closed punctually at the hours approved of by the Department.

Summer holidays are not taken into account in the purpose of yearly salaries. Each school year shall begin and end for the classes mentioned above, and the yearly salary charged will be paid for the period stated, regardless of the length of the holiday period.

All teachers will be required to give at least one month's notice of their intention to resign.

All questions relating to the day school district is referred to the local Indian Agent.

Sir:

I have the honor to enclose herewith requisition for school material for the Mooseneide Indian Day School.

Also requisition for the Champagne Landing Indian Day School. It will be noted that a register has been supplied there was one on hand here. I am inclined to think that the box of white chalk the teacher has on hand is sufficient for some time I do not see the necessity of a second box.

I consider the request for 36 Alexander Primers is excessive, 24 would meet the needs.

The teacher shows 49 pupils on the roll, this is an unusual number, and generally speaking, not more than half that number are in attendance at the same time.

This school is in operation for a few weeks during the early summer only.

A pointer can easily be obtained from the small spruce trees which grow in abundance near the school.

Enclos. 2.

The Secretary of Indian Department,

Sir,-

LITTLE SALMON RIVER RAID:

A village of fifteen houses, about sixty-seven miles distant from Hoota-link-qua. Native population one hundred and two, forty four being between six and eighteen years of age.

They are away from the village hunting about six months of the year. They strongly expressed their desire for a Day School, adding that if a school were established, their women and children would reside permanently in the village. They seemed very desirous of having their children educated.

Sir,

I beg to inform you that a return has been received by the Department covering the period which the school at Little Salmon was in operation during the quarter ended June 30th, last.

J.D. McLean Esq,
Asst Deputy and Secretary,
Dept of Indian Affairs,

Sir:

I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt of your letter dated Sep't 18th, file # 468106/2 in reference to the school at Little Salmon.

In my report of Aug 8th on the Little Salmon band of Indians I mentioned that a day school had been opened and that the schoolroom, at the time of my visit, had not been properly fitted up as they were waiting the arrival of lumber to construct desks and seats.

Since my visit it has been reported by the Bishop of the Yukon, who was recently at Little Salmon, that desks and seats sufficient to accommodate the pupils have been put into the school.

The schoolroom is a well built log building with good shingle roof and the ground fenced in by wire fencing, it is warm, well ventilated, and lighted by two good windows on each side of the building. Enclosed herewith is a photo, the first building is the residence of the teacher, the second at the right of the picture with ladder on the roof is the school. Being a new building it is in excellent repair.

There are 30 pupils on the roll, 21 boys and 9 girls, the attendance is rather irregular on the part of some of the pupils by reason of the necessity of going away to hunt. While at the settlement the pupils attend fairly regularly.

The school is open for at least six months of the year that is from April 1st to Sep't 30th the teacher is in residence during that period. The Indians do not stay around the settlement much during the winter months consequently the teacher goes to Carmacks from Oct to March and from there visits Little Salmon when the Indians are in. During these visits he
J.D.M.

conducts the day school.

Little Salmon is a permanent settlement of Indians; they spend most of the winter hunting and trapping in the surrounding district bringing in the results of their hunt occasionally during this period and exchanging them for necessary supplies.

I had an opportunity of seeing the progress some of the pupils had made, several write fairly well and read words or three letters correctly. Considering the short time the school has been opened the teacher has done very well with the material he has to work upon.

The Department has already sent a supply of school material so that now the school is well equipped for work.

The Rev C. Swanson, B.A. is in charge of the school.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Sup't of Indians.
MEMORANDUM.

Mr. Scott,

I beg to call your attention to the letter hereunder from Mr. Hawksley, Superintendent of Indians for the Yukon, reporting on the day school which has been opened at Little Salmon in that territory in charge of Rev. Cecil Swanson, B.A. of Toronto University. They wish to have this school recognized by the Department and provision made for a salary for the teacher.

The grant allowed for day schools in the Yukon is at the rate of $720.00 per annum. None of these schools are open the whole of the year and Mr. Hawksley says that the Little Salmon School would only be open about six months in the year. There are thirty pupils on the roll, which is a higher enrolment than at any of the other day schools in the territory. You will see from the accompanying snapshot that they have a school building and teacher's residence already and the school has had seats and desks provided. I think the Department would be quite justified in recognizing this school and making the usual grant.

Ottawa,
January 23, 1940.

Right Reverend Sir:

The Department is in receipt of a return signed by Rev. R.C.W. Ward showing that he operated the Carmacks Seasonal School for a period of 35 days between October 30 and December 22, 1939.

This is the first intimation that the Department has received that this school would be in operation during the calendar year 1939. As a matter of fact our records show that Rev. Mr. Ward is the teacher of the Selkirk Indian Day School and he has been paid salary at that school for the months of October, November and December, 1939. Under these circumstances it is difficult to understand how he also taught at the Carmacks School. In view of the fact that he has already been paid for the period October 1 to December 31 as teacher of the Selkirk School it is not possible to consider any payment for his services at the Carmacks School for the period during which he states he had the school in operation. Incidentally I may say that due to the economic conditions now confronting us it will not be possible for the Department to make any allowance for seasonal schools until such time as you are further advised. We will, however, continue to pay the regular salary to the teachers at the Moosehide, Old Crow Village and Selkirk schools as we understand that these schools are operated for 10 months in each academic year.

Yours truly,

Rt. Rev. W. A. Geddes,
Bishop of Yukon,
Dawson, Y. T.

Right Rev. Sir:

Reference your letter of April 25

I have discussed the contents of your letter at some length with Major Clark. His views indicate that Mr. Bridge has other interests than those of the school and that therefore he is not conducting it probably in accordance with the regulations laid down in the School Register.

We doubt also whether the Department is receiving full value for its salary outlay, particularly when we compare this school with the one at Mayo.

We have two alternatives that are obvious at the present time:

(1) to write to the Bishop concerning Mr. Bridge,

(2) to suggest to the Bishop a transfer or exchange between Mr. Bridge and Mr. Brownlee at Carmacks.

I would be quite prepared, in an official letter to Mr. Bridge, if this transfer is approved, to advise him that departmental regulations must be strictly observed in operating our day schools, particularly insofar as opening and closing
hours are concerned. It seems evident that Mr. Bridge is sincere enough in his efforts but that he takes every opportunity to give visits to Dawson City, etc., a priority over his teaching duties. This cannot be tolerated during school hours, especially when we are allowing him an adequate salary.

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.
Mr. M.F. Neary:

Re: Monthly day school returns.

I have made the necessary corrections and am returning the reports to you.

I was away for one month's holiday, from the seventh of Aug. until the fourth of Sep. At the present time the school is being well attended as there are quite a number of Indians here.

The new school is not under construction at the time of writing; needless to say I am still handicapped by not having a proper school room. I am serving cocoa both morning and afternoon. My reason for doing this is that some children are unable to attend both morning and afternoon. Especially some of the older ones who have work to do.

The Yukon Health nurse is in the village at the present time. Miss Larkin takes quite a keen interest in the children.

Yours sincerely,

W.J. Brownlee

Right Rev. Sir:

The Department received a day school return from the Little Salmon (Carmacks) School for the quarter ended December 31st and we allowed $3 a day for a period of 59 days.

On July 20th, we visited the Moosehide village, situated about three miles below Dawson. We were accompanied by the Rev. Mr. O'Meara. Dear Sir:

In answer to yours of April 10th in which you state that slow progress has apparently been made by the pupils of the Moosehide Day School, I wish to say that I have visited the school several times, and have considered the question very carefully.

In the first place, the apparent progress in all the Indian day schools is very slow, and is due to some extent to the fact that the children do not attend the school regularly, as they accompany their parents on expeditions away from the school. I have endeavoured to point out to the teacher at Moosehide certain possible improvements, and I trust good progress may be made. REPORT ON THE WORK OF THE PUPILS OF MOOSEHIDE DAY SCHOOL.

READING:- Seven of the pupils were using the reading cards supplied by the Department, they repeated the words in a parrot like manner indicating that it was memory rather than sight reading, some of them were rather puzzled when unexpectedly taken back a few lines and asked to read over that particular line. The teacher's attention was called to this fault which is, I think, the result of the teacher repeating the words along with his pupils.

Three pupils were using primer pt 1, their work may be classed as very fair, they are rather slow in picking up the meanings of the English words.

SPELLING:- The work was only fair in this subject, lack of application on the part of the pupils is the reason that may be assigned as the cause.

WRITING:- Always a favorite study of the Indians was on the whole good, there is more progress in this subject than in any other dealt with in the school.

ARITHMETIC:- Simple addition was as far as any of the pupils had gone with the exception of one who had been for a time at the Carcross School, he was doing multiplication, the work of all the pupils was good and accurate, the figures were poorly formed however all the pupils passed the tests given.

DICTION:- Four pupils sat for this test and passed it creditably, words of four letters was the limit given.

Singing :- Very poor, the teacher is not at all musical and not well able to lead in this.

CALISTHENICS:- All drills taken from the Manual were very well done the pupils are apparently interested in this subject.

Discipline and Conduct:- Very Good on the part of all.

March 25th, 1918.

Dawson. Y.T.

CHRISTIE INDUSTRIAL SCHOOL.

At the time of my visit to Christie this summer, I found Father Calmus, the principal, doing splendid work. He is busy from morning until night—administrating, teaching and supervising the boys' activities, even in the barns. Sister Caroline, the Superior, is a splendid type. She says Father Calmus is doing better than any of the late Principals.

The boys are not worked half enough, and the Principal is erecting a gymnasium to work off their surplus energy.

I advised the re-shingling of the roof and promised two sewing machines. We should pay part of the account for shingling.

The girls' dormitory was especially fine. There is a chair beside each bed—a splendid arrangement.

The water supply is adequate.

The property belongs to the O.S.B. Order, but if they withdrew it would revert to the Diocese. The land is all stumps and rocks, and there is no possible chance to farm, or to have a good garden. The Department should go slow taking over this property, as the land is so bad.

There is a very bright boy at this school by the name of Moses Smith, and the Department might do well to offer him tuition in a few years, upon graduation.

Mr. Agent Cox has not been at Christie for two years, and the Principal claims that Constable Bartlett has not been any help to them of late.

I understand Father Moser is going back to this vicinity as missionary.

Dear Sir,

I have been looking over the list of the grants made by your Department to the Indian Day Schools in Yukon, and I wish to ask about the grant given towards Moosehide Day School for the quarter ending September 1923. The number of days in the quarter in which school was open was 52 and the average attendance 6.2. The grant for the quarter was $92.00. The grant for the quarter ending December 1923 for Moosehide Day School is $276.00 and the school was open 63 days with an average attendance of 6.8. The difference in the amount is much greater than the difference in the teaching days would indicate, and I think some mistake may have been made. There may however be some explanation that does not occur to me, but I shall be glad of a line from you on this matter.

I wish to thank you for your continued interest in and support of the Indian Day Schools. In the case of some of the Indian Schools we are able to have regular school the year round. In other places the Indians travel around a great deal and it seems impossible to hold school except at certain seasons of the year when the Indians assemble in one place. However, we are doing what we can to hold Day Schools wherever possible and we are greatly encouraged by your grants given towards the upkeep of the school.
In visiting the different centres where Lay Schools have been held, I always feel considerably encouraged. The Indian children in some cases may appear to be making slow progress but it is the only opportunity they have to get any advancement in school subjects. The teachers take advantage of the opportunity to give the children instruction in deportment and knowledge of things generally, and I feel the energy put forth is well worth while.

I remain,

Yours faithfully,

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 10th instant, with reference to the closing of the Moosehide Indian Day School.

In preparing our appropriation for the current fiscal year, provision was made for only nine months' salary for each teacher of an Indian day school. In the case of the Moosehide School, it has been open for the months of April, May and June. Consequently, between September 1, 1940, and March 31, 1941, salary is only available for six months.

In view of the request of the teacher, the Department has no objection to the Moosehide school remaining open for September, but it should be closed for the month of January. Salary will not be paid the teacher for the latter month.

The first problem was to discreetly persuade the Indians living in very bad houses in Dawson, to move downstream three miles to their traditional village of Moosehide, where a day school was being organized. Most of my time at Dawson was spent in reviewing correspondence, studying circulars, etc. A very large amount of mail had been held pending my arrival at Dawson, which was cleared up before leaving. Upon my departure all Indian families but one had moved to Moosehide, the day school had commenced, the dilapidated community Hall patched up, and community life - dormant for a number of years - again assumed the Indian pattern.

R.J. MEKK
Indian Agent

R. J. Meek, Esq.,
Indian Agent,

Further to your letter of March 26, re the preparation of Annual Estimates, and our reply of March 25, please be advised that many of the sheets included in a complete set of Welfare Estimates do not refer to your agency. The Indians of Canada are divided into two classes: Treaty Indians and non-Treaty Indians. Your Indians belong to the latter class and are not entitled by treaty terms to issues of Ammunition, Nets, Snare-wire, Triennial Clothing, etc.

In the three Prairie Provinces, the Northwest Territories and remote areas where Indians are located long distances from source of supplies, Agents estimate their relief requirements - food, soap, etc., a year in advance. These supplies are purchased on contract from wholesalers and shipped in to departmental warehouses, from which they are distributed weekly, or monthly, to aged and indigent Indians who have no other source of maintenance.

In the other parts of the Dominion and your agency, assistance is supplied by direct purchase from the merchant. However, if your Indians can be taken off direct relief by the issue of nets, ammunition, snare-wire or seeds, the branch is prepared to give sympathetic consideration to any representations you may care to make. In fact, it will be in order to include items in your 1947-48 Estimates covering requirements in tent duck (Allotment 12-421) canoe canvas (09-632) ammunition, twine for nets and snare-wire (02-229).

Insofar as Indian Education is concerned, it is not necessary to estimate for desks, supplies, rents and teachers' salaries.
salaries. These are all included by the Branch in a bulk amount, based on part year's requirements and new commitments.

However, it will be necessary to include estimates for:

(1) Repairs required to government-owned buildings; and

(2) New buildings required.

If you will please let us know your requirements for biscuits, we will put these amounts in our order which goes to the manufacturers on May 15. To assist you in estimating requirements, it is suggested that you allow for 6 lbs. per student in average attendance, e.g., if average attendance is 20 - then ask for 120 lbs. of biscuits for that particular school.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Until such time as you move into Moose Hide, taking up permanent residence there, I must refuse admission of your children to the Day School at Moose Hide.

The Archbishop is perhaps not aware that the school is not operated during the summer months (July and August). In some years June might be a "summer" month.

Please note the three missives underleaf.

A great deal of friction has been caused by conducting school in the house. Mr. Bridge has required the children to do certain chores which are more associated with the home than the school. This activity is resented by certain parents.

The space in the house available for school automatically operates to reduce the attendance. The attached photo shows the woefully inadequate blackboard available in the room used. And further, since no storage space for surplus books, etc., is available, the resulting clutter has to be seen to be believed!

The vacant school was rented to Indians as a house. The outcome was a row of the first magnitude. When the school becomes vacant again, it will set up a chain reaction which will be heard as far at least as Whitehorse.

Finally, I had to remonstrate with one Indian woman who added up the factors of single man, house and Indian girls to trump up the old, old story.

C.A.F. Clark
Ottawa, July 14, 1947.

Dear Archbishop Adams:

I have for answer your letter of June 25 with regard to our Indian School at Moosehide, Y.T.

We have recently had our Educational Survey Officer, Major C.A. Clark, visit this school. He has been consulted concerning Captain Bridge's request. Major Clark informs us that a great deal of friction has already been caused by conducting school in the teacher's residence. Some of the Indians complained to Major Clark that Captain Bridge had required the children to do certain chores which were more associated with the home than with the school. Such activities were resented by some of the parents.

The space in the teacher's residence available for school automatically operates to reduce the attendance. Photographs in our possession show the woefully inadequate blackboard space available in the room now being used and also the poor lighting. Furthermore, since no storage space for surplus books was available, the room presented an untidy appearance.

During a certain period, the vacant school was rented to Indians as a house. Apparently this also caused a great deal of resentment on the part of the Indians.

Sincerely yours,

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Most Reverend Walter R. Adams, M.A., D.D.,
Archbishop of Kootenay,
Bishop's House,
Vernon, B.C.

The Secretary, Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada.

Dear Sir,

On Dec. 8th, 1917, I received from your Department Cheque No. 2205 for the sum of $105.80 marked as being the grant for the Sept. Quarter 1917 for Middle River School. I deposited the cheque in the Canadian Bank of Commerce, Dawson, thinking it was a grant for one of our schools, and that perhaps a mistake had been made in the name Middle River. On looking it up more carefully there does not seem to be any school in Yukon to which this would correspond, and I write you now asking if the Department has not made a mistake. If you advise me to that effect, I shall return the amount to your Department.

I remain,

Yours sincerely,

Dawson, June 29, 1918.

Secretary, Dept. Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada.

Dear Sir,

I wish to refer to your letter of April 4th in which you state that the cheque of $105.80 was intended for the Moosehide Day School for the quarter ending September 1917.

I had received nothing from your Department for that particular quarter, but there still seems to be some mistake with reference to the amount. During the September quarter of 1917, school was held for forty-two days, as you will see by referring to the report. In previous quarters you allowed a per diem of $4.60, which would make the September quarter 1917 grant $193.20.

The cheque in question which you state was intended for Moosehide Day School September quarter 1917 amounted to $105.80. This would indicate that there still would be some mistake. I write you in case you may be able to clear the matter up.

I remain,

Yours sincerely,

J. O. Stringer

Bishop of Yukon.

Dawson, Yukon, Canada,
March 26, 1924.

Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada.

Dear Sir,

I have been looking over the list of the grants made by your Department to the Indian day schools in Yukon, and I wish to ask about the grant given towards to Moosehide Indian Day School for the quarter ending September, 1923. The number of days in the quarter in which school was open was 52 and the average attendance 6.2. The grant for the quarter was $92.00. The grant for the quarter ending December, 1923, for Moosehide day school is $276.00 and the school was open 63 days with an average attendance of 6.8. The difference in the amount is much greater than the difference in the teaching days would indicate and I think some mistake may have been made. There may, however, be some explanation that does not occur to me but I shall be glad of a line from you on this matter.

Yours faithfully,

Isaac O. Yukon.
Ottawa, April 22, 1924.

Right Reverend Sir,

In reply to your letter of the 26th ultimo, I beg to say that previous to September 1st last, the Department paid the salary and rent at the Moosehide Indian Day School on a quarterly basis, but beginning on the date mentioned it was decided to pay salary, etc., at all Indian day schools on a basis of ten teaching months in the academic year.

The amount allowed at Moosehide is $720.00 a year and, in addition, an allowance of $200.00 a year is made for the rent of the building. This makes a total amount for the academic year of $920.00 and payment of this is made as follows:

| Month       | Salary          | Rent   |
|-------------|-----------------|--------|
| September qr. (1 month) | $72.00         | $20.00 |
| December " (3 " ) | $216.00        | $60.00 |
| March " (3 " ) | $216.00        | $60.00 |
| June " (3 " ) | $216.00        | $60.00 |

Total salary and rent ...........................................$920.00

I have the honour to be,

Right Reverend Sir,

Right Rev. I. O. Stringer, D.D.,
Bishop of Yukon,
Dawson, Yukon.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.
Sir,

I have the honor to enclose herewith the quarterly returns of the Moosehide Indian Day School for the quarter ending June 30th, 1924.

This school was inspected recently and an examination held. The progress of the pupils is slow but there is a decided advance since the last examination.

Your obedient servant,

John Hawksley,
Indian Superintendent.

Right Reverend Sir:

When you visited the Department on September 27 you advised me that there had been a change in the teaching services at the Moosehide Indian Day School and that Rev. L. G. Chappel had replaced Rev. Alex Anderson on September 1, 1938.

As you are aware the cheques in payment of salaries of teachers of Indian schools are issued monthly and they are mailed from here in time to reach the school before the last day of the month. Previous to your visit the salary cheque for the month of September, amounting to $110.00, was mailed to Rev. Alex Anderson, Dawson, Y.T. Immediately on receipt of your information that Rev. Mr. Anderson had been succeeded by Rev. L. G. Chappel the former was written and requested to return the September salary cheque No. 95591 for $110.00. As yet this cheque has not been returned. Present regulations do not permit our issuing a cheque to Mr. Chappel until Rev. Mr. Anderson returns the cheque sent to him. I should appreciate it if you would get in touch with Rev. Mr. Anderson and arrange to have him send back the cheque that was forwarded to him. As soon as this is received the salary due Rev. L. G. Chappel will be paid.

Yours truly,

Rt. Rev. W.A. Geddes, D.D.,

Sir:

Capt. H.E. Bridge, in charge of the Church of England day school at Moosehide Indian Village, near Dawson, Y.T., is proceeding to that point in a few days. He is interested in introducing physical training and sports to the pupils of his school and requests that a football be forwarded to him. It is also thought that the Indians would take quickly to their traditional game of lacrosse. My own experience with Indians of the Stikine Agency shows that they were enthusiastic when I brought in a dozen lacrosse sticks in 1936. I would suggest that if it is in order two dozen lacrosse sticks and three lacrosse balls be sent to Capt. Bridge for use at the Moosehide Indian school.

The school has not been in operation for two years owing to shortage of personnel. Not much school equipment is left, and when Capt. Bridge has been there for a week or so he intends to send me a list of school requirements. In the meantime could the following necessities be forwarded to Capt. Bridge, at Dawson:

- 5 doz rough scribblers, unlined
- 5 doz drawing books
- 1 box white chalk
- 2 doz boxes crayons
- 5 doz ruled exercise books
- ½ gross pencils
- 1 box colored chalk
- 1 box erasers

R.J. Meek

Today I am in receipt of letter from Capt. H.B. Bridge, in charge of the Indian Day School at Moosehide, near Dawson. He states in part:

"I have purchased a second hand phonograph from A. Barnes for $13.00 for the school. I am borrowing a number of records of good music, vocal, instrumental and orchestral for purposes of musical appreciation. Do you think the Department would pay for this, no obligation of course but my income is very small and expense just the opposite, there might also be some records supplied by the Indian Department of an educational value."

I do not know the policy of the Department with regard to musical appreciation in day schools. Capt. Bridge has taken a great deal of interest in the cultural side of the children's education. I understand he trained a choir of Indian youngsters who sang at Dawson for the Christmas festivities. Capt. Bridge himself was formerly a professional singer in the U.S.A.

He further informs me he put on a special treat for the children at Christmas, with presents for each child. The presents came from Los Angeles by a generous donor.

Capt. Bridge's great interest in the cultural life of the children would appear to be deserving of some encouragement. Could I be advised if he may submit a voucher for the expense of the gramophone and records?

Acting Indian Agent.

Date: April 17th, 1948
While accompanying T-B clinic to Moosehide Indian Reserve, Dawson, Y.T., on June 17th, Mr. H.E. Bridge, teacher at the Indian Day School, Moosehide, informed me that he had obtained enough new spruce logs to build a proper school adjoining and abutting the present Church of England mission.

In company with Archbishop W.R. Adams, Bishop of the Yukon, we were shown that the present school building is in an extremely dilapidated condition, and would be torn down shortly. Mr. Bridge had been forced to conduct the school in the large living room of the Mission, but it had not proved satisfactory. The idea was to make a large opening in the south wall of the living room, opening to the newly proposed classroom, measuring approximately 20' x 30'.

Apparently Mr. Bridge had succeeded in interesting some benefactors in the Indians of Moosehide who were prepared to contribute several hundred dollars to a new school. His Grace proposed to contribute $300.00 of church funds, and has requested $300.00 towards the schoolroom from Indian Affairs Branch. Could the $200.00 contained in the 1948-49 Estimates for repairs to Moosehide School be granted to this enterprise. The sum of $100.00 asked for to repair school at Fort Selkirk will not be used, as the school has now been closed at the request of the Department, though Archbishop Adams continues the salary of the former teacher Mrs. Cowaret who conducts the school for the benefit of some half dozen Indian children.

The $300.00 requested for school building will be for labor in erecting same, and materials for roofing, etc. Logs have already been taken to site. A new schoolroom will certainly be a great improvement on the present mission house-schoolroom setup. If funds are available I would recommend authorization be given as soon as possible.

(R.J. Meek) Indian Agent.

Your letter of April 14th, 1948, file 166-13-1 (E), Moosehide Indian Day School. I beg to advise that H.E. Bridge taught school during the month of July, school to be closed for August and September. It will reopen on October 1st.

During August and continuing to the present, a new schoolroom has been built - a very good one I am informed. Estimated cost of new school is $1200.00 of which sum this Branch contributed $300.00. Several hundred dollars were subscribed by the business men of Dawson, the balance being paid by the Diocese of the Yukon.

Archbishop W.R. Adams has now requested the sum of $200.00 for installing an electrical unit. This generator (2400 KW) was given to the school by the Yukon Territorial Government. It is a heavy engine requiring a cement foundation. The electric plant will be used for lighting the school and for a moving picture projection machine.

May I pleased be advised if $200.00 can be allocated for electric installation.

When Dr. Procter, Indian Health Services, Ottawa, inspected the Indian Day School at Moosehide recently, it was brought to his attention by H.E. Bridge, teacher, that cocoa, sugar and milk is not supplied to the children of his school for noon-day lunches.

Moosehide Indian Day School

With further reference to my letter of December 9th, 1948, and your reply of December 16th, file 927-5 (E.), concerning radio sets for the above school,

I have interviewed Mr. Chapman, a member of the radio committee at Dawson who informed me that the Dawson radio transmitter CFYT, has recently been broadcasting educational programmes through the Department of Education for B.C., in co-operation with the C.B.C. The subjects included musical appreciation, historical and geographical subjects, etc. These recordings were released twice a week.

Mr. R. Huland, Superintendent of Schools for the Yukon writes as follows:

"We have been receiving broadcasting records from Mr. Phillip J. Kitley, CBC, Vancouver Hotel, Vancouver. He is in charge of educational broadcasts, and would be glad to supply you with some, I am sure. Most of our teachers do not wish to have educational broadcasts during school hours, as their time-table is too crowded as it is; however, our local station has been good enough to send out programmes in the evening, and I believe they have been of great benefit to the children."

It appears that Moosehide School would qualify for a radio receiver under the terms of your letter. Further instructions in this regard will be appreciated.

(R.J. Meek)
Superintendent

Moosehide Day School,

I have received the following letter from Mr. Meek, teacher at Moosehide Indian Day School:

"You will be pleased to hear that I have been offered and have accepted 400 books from the Dawson Public Library. It will be necessary to make another book stand, which I will do with 1 x 12's, and I am sure you won't mind my charging this to the Department and rate it as school material. It should not cost much and I will make the stand myself, however I will wait your O.K. on this, but I will have to pay $5.00 for a gas boat to bring them down, as they will be heavy. Memorandum:

Of interview with Bishop Stringer and the Rev. Mr. O'Meara on October 5, 1908, with reference to matters in the Yukon Territory.

The following matters considered by them to be of special importance:

F.P.

Department of Education, Yukon Territory,
Dawson, Y.T., Jan. 4, 1908.

Sir:

At Selkirk there was also a serious diphtheria epidemic last fall, but the Indians have always attended so irregularly there that Archdeacon Canham has always considered it hopeless or worthless to attempt to make out any printed return.
An examination was held at the day school, all the work is elementary. There were 9 boys and 6 girls present at the time of the examination with Miss K. Martin, the teacher. The subjects in which the pupils were examined are as follows:

READING:- While each of the pupils were rather slow the pronunciation of the English words was clear with only a very little of the Indian accent, the meaning of the words was intelligently given, it may be said, taking the pupils as a whole, that the reading was very good.

WRITING:- This is a subject that seems to appeal to all the Indians and one they seem most interested in consequently they make more progress in this than in most subjects. The pupils examined at Selkirk were very good the letters were well formed in a clear roundhand and very readable, there was marked progress by all pupils in this subject.

ARITHMETIC:- The examination in this branch was in both mental and written examples, all of course rudimentary, answers were readily and in most cases correctly given, their work in this subject was very satisfactory.

SPELLING:- All the pupils were good up to words of four or five letters, the meaning of each word spelt was given, this system is regularly followed by the teacher.

SINGING:- It is characteristic of the Indians that they are all fond of music consequently the singing was very good, the time accurate and the voices well modulated.
They sing one or two patriotic songs very creditably.

Calisthenics: All the movements taken from the Manual sent by the Department were excellently done, they keep good time and drill to music.

It is evident that the teacher, Miss K. Martin, has taken a lot of pains with her pupils, they certainly reflect great credit on her efforts. The general work of the school was very satisfactory.

The school-room was neat and clean and well ventilated, good care is taken of the material and books supplied by the Department.

John Hawksley,
Indian Superintendent.

Sir:

I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt of letter dated December 16th, 1931, file No 166-9-3, in reference to Mrs A. Cowaret teaching Indian day school at Selkirk in the early part of the year.

In reply I beg to say that when Mr W.D. Young left Selkirk I was notified that the school was closed, this was in August 1930. I had no knowledge of Mrs Cowaret commencing to teach or that she had continued to do so until March of last year when a letter was received from her stating that the Bishop of Yukon had been to Selkirk and finding that she had been teaching advised her to send in a report; she sent for the necessary forms which were sent to her. By letter dated July 7th she informed me that she had filled up the forms and hoped to hand them over to me in Whitehorse, she was on her way to Vancouver, but found I had already left for Dawson, she then mailed them to this office.

Enquiries were made from the Bishop of Yukon as to whether he had engaged the services of Mrs Cowaret to teach. He stated that he had not done so nor did he know that she was doing so until he called at Selkirk on his way to Dawson. The work was quite a voluntary act undertaken without the knowledge or consent of the church authorities or the Indian Superintendent. It was felt that in paying for work voluntarily undertaken without the knowledge and consent of those immediately concerned there is the risk of establishing a precedent that might prove to be troublesome in the future.

The school register and school material was locked up in the Mission House and was not available to Mrs Cowaret. No school supplies were sent to Selkirk during the period that she was teaching, nor was any requisitioned by her.

Dear Dr. Scott,

Reference 166-9-1.

Replying to your letter of the 10th instant re Indian School at Fort Selkirk, Yukon. It is a pleasure to bear testimony to unselfish and devoted work performed by Mrs. Cowaret for the Indians at and in the vicinity of Fort Selkirk.

I have observed her there for more than ten years past. Apart altogether from the performance of her formal duties as a school teacher, she has really become an institution among them; adults and children alike look to her for advice and guidance in their affairs. In such a remote and isolated place it is fortunate that there is such a sympathetic, refined and well informed woman willing to minister to the wants of those wretched people.

My understanding of this case is that Mrs. Cowaret did not originally intend seeking remuneration for the period of teaching, but that Bishop Stringer, now Archbishop, visiting Selkirk, becoming personally aware of the circumstances, suggested both to her and to the Indian Agent that she should be paid, and consequently request for payment was made.

As you have been good enough to ask my opinion in the matter, I have no hesitation in recommending that payment be made with the stipulation that it is not a precedent, and so far as Mrs. Cowaret is concerned, I am confident she would never seek to treat it as a precedent.

Further, Mrs. Cowaret's husband is a big game hunter's guide and trapper. Because of the general hard times, hunters did not visit the Yukon in 1931 as formerly. That coupled with the prevailing low price of fur has seriously crippled the Cowarets finan-
cially and payment of the amount involved would be doubly welcome at this time.

Mrs. Cowaret is, in my opinion, really such a valuable asset to your department and a person upon whom you could always rely for support and if needed, could supply intelligent and sympathetic advice in matters pertaining to the welfare of the Indians in that country that if it is necessary, hers should be a special case and payment made without hesitation.

Sir:-

I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt of your letter dated August 3rd, file No 166-9-1, in reference to the Moosehide and Selkirk Indian Day Schools.

In reply I beg to say that there is little prospect of an increased enrollment of pupils at either of these day schools. The Indians, owing to changed conditions, cannot afford to stay around these villages or leave their families while the men go away to hunt and trap; they are compelled to separate into small parties and live in the woods for the purpose of hunting and trapping in order to make a living. Opportunities for obtaining work from the white people are very much reduced. To insist upon the Indian families staying in the village (which has been suggested) would mean that some of them would have to receive help in the way of provisions. It appears to be a much wiser policy to keep them independent, earning their own living, and they are less liable to get into bad habits.

At both places all the children who live in the village of school age are enrolled but do not attend as regularly as they should, possibly a little more effort on the part of the teachers might help towards improvement in the attendance of those enrolled.

The salary paid by the Department, $110.00 per month for the ten teaching months of the school year for each of these schools is rather too high for the number of pupils taught and I would recommend that a reduction be made in view of the urgent need for economy. May I suggest that under existing circumstances, a net salary of $75.00 per month for each of these two schools would be adequate compensation for the work that is being done.

Your obedient servant,

John Hawksley,
Indian Superintendent.

The Department is in receipt of a letter from Arthur R. Parsons, teacher of the Selkirk Indian Day School, in which he stated that he intended giving up duties at the end of May and that he would be succeeded by Mr. Wm. Valentine.

The Department has received no request to approve the appointment of Mr. Valentine. I would appreciate if you would take up the matter with the authorities of the Church of England at the Yukon and advise the Department if it is their wish that Mr. Valentine be in charge of this school from May 31st, last.

You should point out to the church authorities the importance of advising the Department before making any change in the teacher at either the Selkirk or the Moosehide Day School.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Right Rev. Sir:

With reference to Your Lordship's letter of the 5th instant, I beg to say that the Department approves the appointment of Rev. Wm. Valentine as teacher of the Selkirk Indian Day School. It is noted that he has been in charge of this school since the first of May. When issuing salary cheques for the month ended November 30th, payment will be made to Rev. Mr. Valentine for the months of June, September, October and November.

The salary rate at this school is $1,100 a year but, owing to present regulations, when the total compensation exceeds $1,000 but is not in excess of $1,111, the Department is only allowed to pay at the rate of $1,000 a year. Consequently, until further notice, Rev. Mr. Valentine's compensation will be at the rate of $100 a teaching month, as all salaries of teachers of Indian day schools are paid on the basis of ten teaching months in the academic year.

I have the honour to be, Right Reverend Sir,

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,

Dear Sir,

Mr Valentine is still at Moosehide, and will be remaining there I hope for at least the next five years. When he took over at Moosehide at the end of August, Mr Chappell left with his family to return to England. He had only got as far as Whitehorse when war was declared and it was impossible for him to proceed to the mother country. I tried to find work for him in British Columbia but was unsuccessful. The only house that I had in Yukon that was suitable for a married man and that was available was at Selkirk where Mr Ward, a bachelor was stationed. I have therefore been compelled to ask Mr Chappell to go to Selkirk and ask Mr Ward to work among the Indians at [Carmacks]. As far as I can foresee the matter at present I am hoping that Mr Ward will be returning to Selkirk. But in these uncertain times it is hard to tell when that will be. Dear Mr. Gibben,

With reference to our conversation this afternoon regarding the Indian Day Schools in Yukon, I wish to furnish you with the following information.

Regarding the Selkirk Day School; Rev. W. R. Stringer returned to Selkirk on May 30th last and has been stationed there ever since. When he came to Selkirk in 1942 he intended to remain there for five years and I have had as yet no information that he contemplates any change in this plan.

Regarding the Teslin Day School; at the end of September it appeared that there would not be any Indians remaining at the Post throughout the winter, so Mrs. Cowaret moved to Carmacks. If there are children at Carmacks, Mrs. Cowaret will be conducting a Day School and if so I would appreciate it if the Indian Affairs Branch could provide some remuneration for her services in that regard.

With regard to Old Crow, a letter recently received from Rev. J. W. Ellis states that on account of the epidemic prevailing there this summer it was impossible to have the school opened.

I understand that the Indian Affairs Branch has approved the temporary appointment of James Wood as teacher for the Mooseshide Indian Day School.

Dear Sir,

RE: SELKIRK DAY SCHOOL

This is to inform you that Mr. G. C. Robertson is teaching the Selkirk Day School for the month of June. Mr. Robertson is a graduate of San Mateo Junior College in California, and completed 3 years of a four years course at San Jose Teachers College also in California. Mr. Robertson left college at the end of his third year to enlist in the Canadian Army and served for four and one half years with the Seaforth Highlanders from Vancouver. He served in Canada, England, and also in the Mediterranean and Western European theaters of war. On his discharge from the army he entered the Anglican Theological College of Vancouver. He is spending the summer in Yukon. It would be appreciated if Mr. Robertson could be paid either on a monthly or a per diem basis for the month of June.

Mr. Stringer did not teach during the month of May as there were no children in Selkirk during the month. In order to compensate for this Mr. Robertson proposes to teach during July if there are children in Selkirk.

From the term beginning September 1st next I shall be pleased if the Department will appoint Mrs. M. M. Cowaret as teacher of the Selkirk School. Mrs. Cowaret has had years of experience in teaching in Indian Day Schools at Selkirk and elsewhere in Yukon and has the added advantage in that she speaks the language of the Selkirk Indians.

A new building to house the Day School at Selkirk is badly needed. Could the Department erect a new building for the Day School at Selkirk next year or provide any assistance towards its construction.

Yours very truly,

The building intended for school purposes is no longer used as a school. The reason advanced—dilapidation—used for two white children (Donald Cook & Stanley Wilcox) in the post-office which Mrs. Cowanet manages. No satisfactory explanation was forthcoming concerning where the Indian children would sit if they happened to attend.

If it is worthwhile paying a teacher, it should be in order to repair the school. To make it usable, the agent should be instructed to visit this settlement and school frequently and to ensure that the public is getting a reasonable return for the money expended for school purposes.

C.A. Clark Inspector of Schools

Your letter of June 24th, file 166-9-1 (WT), concerning Selkirk Indian Day School. The observations of Major C.A.F. Clark concerning Mrs. K.M. Cowaret have been noted. The official attitude of the Branch was conveyed to Bishop Gibson, Prince Rupert, B.C., and Archbishop W.R. Adams, Vernon, B.C., both of whom visited Whitehorse recently. Archbishop Adam visited the school at Fort Selkirk, and informs me that he has set aside $100.00 for the repair of the school building. I have therefor included the sum of $100.00 in the estimates of 1948-49 for the repair of Fort Selkirk School, (additional to the Diocese).

I have now been informed by Canon L.G. Chappell that several changes are contemplated at Fort Selkirk by the Diocese. There is a possibility that a new and much larger building may be obtained, and a possible change in personnel.

The recommendation in your fourth paragraph is noted, that more frequent trips be made to Fort Selkirk. Not only Selkirk but many other points I believe would benefit by an occasional visit and inspection by the Agent, but it is impossible to do all the work requested, both inside and in the field, without a clerk being appointed. A considerable proportion of my work the last two months has been taken up with Indian Health Services matters and I have only been able to visit a fraction of the places I would like this summer. A Public Health Nurse has now been appointed by Dr. E.L. Stone, who will spend most of her time along the Yukon River, and it is hoped that by her frequent visits to Selkirk, Miss Larkin will keep me informed as to conditions there.

(R.J. Meek)
Indian Agent.

Your letter of March 17th, your file 166-9-1 (E.1), re Fort Selkirk Indian Day School.

The matter of moving Mrs. Cowaret to some other school has been gone into, and it does not appear to be in the best interests of Indian Affairs Branch and the Diocese to have Mrs. Cowaret moved at the present time.

I think the only solution is to close the Fort Selkirk Indian Day School until changed conditions warrant the reopening of a school. Perhaps by that time, the old school building will be torn down if it doesn't fall down first. We will then be able to open an Indian (or joint) Day School starting with a clean slate.

INSTRUCTIONS TO TEACHERS

1. Fill up all the columns in this Return.
2. All the columns of the Return must be added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.
3. Number and date of holidays to be inserted in the column for remarks.
4. By the total number of school days in the quarter is meant the number of days in the quarter exclusive of Saturdays and Sundays. All authorized holidays will be allowed.
5. The standing of each pupil must be signified by inserting opposite his or her name the figure 1 in the column designating the particular grade.
6. No names of other than those of Indian children are to be included in this return.
7. The Quarterly Returns must end on the 31st March, 30th June, 30th September, and 31st December respectively, and be immediately thereafter in each case transmitted to the local Indian Agent.
8. When, owing to the number of pupils, the form of Return is not long enough to contain all the names, use another form, pagging it as No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns. Do not increase the length of the form by pasting another, or portion of one to it.
9. The average daily attendance during the quarter may be ascertained by dividing the total number of days' attendance of all the pupils by the number of days school was open in the quarter.
10. Should the school be closed at any time during the quarter, the reason must be given in the column for remarks for such day or days.
11. The school must be opened and closed punctually at the hours approved of by the Department.
12. This form to be used for Day Schools only.

Sir:

I have been approached by the Rev. H.I. Lee, minister of an interdenominational organization in Whitehorse re starting an Indian day school. Rev. Lee was formerly a member of the R.C.M.P., he was ordained in 1942 in Alberta, and is Canadian-born. He established a Protestant mission in Whitehorse last June, and conducts services for Indians as well as whites.

At present there is no day school for Indians in Whitehorse, though there are two for white children. Consequently Indian children of all ages wander about the streets of the town most hours of the day and part of the night. Rev. Lee has noted these conditions and has offered the use of his mission for a day school. The building would hold approximately 40 children. One teacher only would be necessary and Rev. Lee has two experienced teachers available at any time for classes.

His request is for sanction of Indian Affairs Branch. No salary is asked for teachers' services, but Rev. Lee would require schooldesks, blackboards, standard school books and equipment for grades 1 to 4. No religious teaching would make up the curriculum, simply standard grad-school subjects.

Rev. Lee acknowledges that this school would be in the nature of an experiment and is willing to undertake responsibility of the entire activity. There is at present a Roman Catholic day school here, upon making enquiries I find that it will be used for white children only - classes are expected to start in October. Rev. Lee's offer appears timely and would do much to better conditions among local Indians. What is the policy of Indian Affairs Branch, and what shall I advise Rev. Lee?
