Day School, Whitehorse

Further to my letters of Sept. 5th, and Oct. 14th, 1946, and your reply of Oct. 19th, file 166-8-1 (W.R. 1). The Rev. H.I. Lee opened a day school for the Indian children of Whitehorse on Monday, January 13th, 1947. Both War Assets Corporation and the Canadian Army, at Whitehorse, have given him considerable assistance as to the acquiring of a building, plumbing and electric facilities, heating units and furniture.

At the present time there are 15 pupils and a strong possibility of several more. Several parents are not sending their children back to the Carcross Residential School as a consequence of the opening of a day school at Whitehorse. This has a beneficial effect insofar as accommodating orphans, and children in very remote places are concerned. I have four such requests for admission before me at present.

While the Rev. Lee has proceeded with the organization of the day school on his own initiative, he is receiving the backing and moral support of the local Kiwanis Club and the Men's Council of Whitehorse. The parents are buying scribblers, pencils, pen, ink, etc., for their children.

It is hoped that recognition and support may be extended to Rev. Lee in the near future.

(R.J. Meek)
Acting Indian Agent.
A situation has arisen in Whitehorse which is becoming somewhat embarrassing to myself as Indian Agent. For quite a number of years no school facilities have been available to the Indians of this village, the Carcross Residential School being the only one to which they had access. The Rev. H.J. Lee, minister of an interdenominational church in Whitehorse has now opened a mission school for the Indians.

On Sept. 5th and Oct. 14th I wrote Indian Affairs Branch requesting some form of recognition or assistance. On Oct. 19, (file 166-8-1 (W.T. 1)) B.F. Neary, Supt. of Welfare and Training, wrote me that he had entered communication with Right Rev. W.A. Gedden, C. of E., Bishop of the Yukon. To date no further word has been received on this subject.

The effect of the opening of this school is that several of the parents are not sending their children back to Carcross Residential School after the Christmas holidays. I have discussed education with the parents at every opportunity and I find them enthusiastic to have all their children attend school. The desirability of children attending a day school and living with their parents in preference to the institutional care of a residential school has been brought out many times in the minutes of the Joint Committee examining the Indian Act, at Ottawa.

Will it be in order to submit the names of children not returning to Carcross Residential School, and attending Whitehorse Day School with a view of having them reinstated in Family Allowance pay? Rev. Lee has a fully qualified teacher, and using the curriculum of Alberta, which is required in the Yukon. The removal of a number of Whitehorse pupils from Carcross School should create openings for pupils from remote areas with no possibility of schooling facilities.

Dear Dr. Moore,

During the past week, a new school has started in Whitehorse. It is in charge of the Rev. Lee, a returned evangelist.

A qualified teacher is on her way in to Whitehorse, was delayed by storms. In the meantime Mr. Lee appears to be conducting a quiet, orderly school. He has bought and paid for a great number of books out of his own meagre stipend. Cocoa and sandwiches are served at recess and cod liver oil is given upon entrance each morning.

Having the school here is quite an asset as a place of contact for all families. I seized the opportunity to hold an immunization clinic in the school, the day after the opening. Twenty-six infants and pre-school children were given the first dose of combined diphtheria and pertussin. With the giving of the third dose, I will vaccinate them.

We are trying to combat an epidemic of scabies and impétigo at Burwash Landing. There are cases everywhere. Single handed it is impossible to do it efficiently. Then, too, the natives are on the move all the time, now. We are in dire need of a quantity of scabies lotion or some sulphur ointment.

Might I suggest that all support be given to the new school in Whitehorse, as it will greatly assist the work in town. Hitherto, there has been no place to gather a group like this.

Yours truly,

Schooling appears to have received a minimum attention—particularly during the war years. Only one residential school is situated in this Agency, at Carcross. One Roman Catholic day school functions all winter, at Burwash Landing, while the Church of England have year round day schools at Moosehide and Fort Selkirk. Rev. H. Lee, a non-denominational protestant minister, requested permission to open a day school for Indians in Whitehorse and the matter was referred to Welfare and Training. It is strongly recommended that this school be given recognition.

R.J. MEEK
Indian Agent.
This has been discussed at length with the founder, Rev. H.S. Lee, a big, jovial man in the prime of life who was (and is) connected with the Aberhart Bible Institute in Alberta, Baptist background. He acquired considerable momentum doing welfare work for the armed forces. With his wife and two small children he came here to do missionary work, but when he saw the Indian children wandering the streets because they are deprived from territorial schools, he decided to add education to his repertoire.

For $400 he got the army hutment which is cut up into a decent class-room, a chapel, a kindergarten room, and living quarters for the five Lee's. His brother, a handyman, lives with them. Lee's zeal and magnetism get him a lot of free help in technical and mechanical work. His wife conducts the kindergarten (Army children) probably with considerable competence.

Recently for $2,000 he acquired another large building (Plan herewith) which has five "wings", 20' by 120'. Included are a fancy cold storage plant, wash basins, toilet bowls, showers, single beds, mattresses, and sheets for fifty persons. He hopes to sell the building presently in use and apply the profit to remodeling the larger one.
Eventually the question of financing came out into the open. Mr. Lee wants to know how much help he can expect from the Dominion Government, "help" meaning money. I told him that would depend on many factors, reiterated and amplifying such points as:

1. The Yukon is primarily "American Territory" and the future of Carcross school must be protected.

2. Is Whitehorse a suitable concentration point?

3. Is Lee's obvious affiliation financially sound?

4. If Lee himself were a casualty, who would replace him?

5. How long will the buildings last and how will they be maintained?

6. Saskatchewan pays $60 a day (200 days) for pupils' board.

7. Per capita grants, comprehensive food, clothing, teachers' salaries, and routine maintenance, but always aim to acquire some surplus or additional contribution from the interested church.

8. Lee will have to keep books and records in a manner approved by auditors.

Mr. Lee is a difficult man to discourage. He faces the prospect of paying $250 a year ground rent to the British Yukon Navigation Co. (B.Y.N.) when the Army terminates its lease of the land.

I shall investigate further the possibilities & securing the ban on Indians' attendance at Yukon white schools. Extraordinary, there is no school tax!
Meanwhile, would you please also mail Mr. Lee a copy of your school's brief and such circular letters as indicate our policy regarding maintenance of buildings, responsibilities of principals, etc., and a copy of the Indian Act.

Most people in these parts take a "broad-minded" view concerning church and religion. They are used to non-sectarian schools. Mr. Lee's Christianity affects personal and social living rather than doctrinal matters, although I recall Albert as a "hot Gospel" enthusiast. Here the men support the Rotary Club, Masonry, and the Chamber of Commerce. These do not happen to be personal enthusiasms of my own, but I intend no modification of my oft-expressed wish that all men everywhere could be free.

C.A.T. Clark

I beg to advise that on May 14th Major C.A.F. Clark, B.A., M.A., arrived in Whitehorse by train and was met by myself. An itinerary was drawn up to make the best time at the disposal of Major Clark.

The Indian Day Schools at Whitehorse, Moosehide (Lawson) and Fort Selkirk were inspected by Major Clark. We also visited Indian Residential School at Carcross, the school and buildings were thoroughly examined by Major Clark.

On May 18th, accompanied by Bishop Coudert, and Mr. R. Forsild, contractor, a visit was made to the proposed site of the new Indian Residential School at Teslin. Various sites were examined and agreement was reached by all concerned on a particularly favorable spot close to the shore of Teslin Lake. We returned to Whitehorse on May 19th after a visit to the Indian Reserve at Teslin.

Transportation was furnished by Departmental Carryall. Major Clark was not impressed by this vehicle which is designed for hard riding, and is not particularly comfortable. He suggested that the Carryall be kept for travel on the rougher roads of this Agency, and that the matter of obtaining a standard type sedan for use in Whitehorse and on the Alaska Highway be taken up with Headquarters.

On May 20th we flew to Mayo and went into all aspects of the establishment of a day school on the reserve there. A teacher has already been obtained and the matter is at present well in hand. On May 22nd we flew on to Dawson, and immediately went by boat to Moosehide Lay School. Various matters of Indian Administration were discussed with J.E. Gibben K.C., Controller of the Yukon. We returned to Whitehorse on May 24th, stopping en route at Fort Selkirk which gave Major Clark an opportunity of inspecting the day school there.

An official inspection of Whitehorse Lay School was made on May 26th. On May 29th we visited Carcross Indian Residential School, the pupils
there were given an examination by Major Clark, and a number of other matters of administration were taken up with Archdeacon H.G.M. Grant, principal of the school.

Major Clark left by Pan American plane on the morning of the 30th, flying to Juneau, Alaska, where he caught the south-bound C.F.R. boat to Vancouver.

During the time Major Clark was in this Agency I was in his company the greater part of the time. Consequently the office routine got very much behind. I expect to be away from Whitehorse for quite a number of days this month on a tuberculosis survey with Dr. Roth, and in company with Col. E.L. Stone, M.D., during July. Major Clark suggested that the need for a clerk be again drawn to your attention. Apart from routine work of the Agency, there is the fact that Indians are obliged to walk the 5-mile round trip from downtown Whitehorse to this office, unless they are fortunate enough to own a car. It is disheartening to make the journey to this office only to find the Agent is away and there is no one to help him.

(R.J. Meek)
Indian Agent.

Attention Mr. Warner

Re: Vehicles for Indian Agent, Yukon Territory.

There is ample justification for permitting Mr. Indian Agent Meek to retain the Dodge Carryall when he is supplied with a fast automobile.

From the agent's office near Whitehorse roads radiate two hundred fifty miles to the west, north and east and fifty miles to the south. These distances require a fast car or the agent's absences from his headquarters will be inconveniently protracted.

The carryall would, during its lifetime, operate in the Whitehorse area as a light truck and conveyance for personnel and materials not transportable by passenger car. The agent's office is two and a half miles uphill from the town. A taxi or light truck charges $1.50 for a one-way trip. The aged and indigent frequently have to be fetched and carried from the "reserve" to the agent's office, to the hospital, to the traders', together with parcels of food and clothing. This activity must go on when the agent is far away, and so a secondary vehicle must be available to the clerk in order to keep transportation costs as low as possible.

Moreover, there will in bad weather and always on minor roads be road conditions which compel the agent to use the heavy-tired carryall even at a sacrifice of speed if he is really to cover his vast territory adequately, and sometimes there will be no road and the need for a "cross-country" vehicle will arise.
We shall soon have two residential schools in the territory. As we pay the initial and final transportation costs for pupils we should be able to cut those costs considerably if the agent is in a position to convey some pupils to and from their homes and still have a vehicle to handle local routine chores.

The carryall may give limited service for a year or two and is cheap at the price. Eventually it will have to be replaced by a utility vehicle of the post-war type.

C.A.F. Clark,
Educational Survey Office,

Dear Mr. Clark:

We were all disappointed when you could not come to visit this Agency last month. I particularly wanted you to see the changed conditions at Rev. Lee's school. He now has about 60 pupils, some of them are half-breeds, several are children of Indians on the enfranchised list who don't attend the white school here. I think we should bring this to the attention of the Territorial Government. Lee is caring for in the neighborhood of 40 kids from out of town, and it is costing him a great deal. I have examined the dormitories, kitchens, playrooms, etc., and it certainly shows up in startling contrast to Carcross School.

As you know the Whitehorse School has not been established as a residential school as yet, but Lee figures he can run several more weeks without going broke. Dear Mr. Clark:

I have before me a copy of the letter written to Mr. Meek, by Mr Neary, on behalf of the Deputy Minister, to advise me that no action can be taken this year in regard to our Residential School, to recognize it as such.

The situation that presents itself at the moment is a serious one, and is a matter of great urgency, therefore I am writing to you that somehow this matter may once again be reviewed.

We have spent months in preparation of the building, and a terrific amount of money to get this school equipped for the children to be able stay here. Therefore it seems incredible that they should be compelled to return to the bush, to their filthy tents and unlivable cabins, after we have had gone to the extent of delousing and cleaning them up, healing their sores and what not. During a recent visit to the Whitehorse Indian Day School, Rev. H.I. Lee, director of this school requested some definite commitment from the Indian Affairs Branch regarding maintenance of the school for the ensuing fiscal year, particularly with regard to boarders.

There is at present an enrollment of about 60, with over 40 children being maintained at the school while their parents are on trap-lines and wood-camps. Most of the boarders are from Champagne some 60 miles west of Whitehorse, which does not have a school. It was while conducting a volunteer summer school at the salmon fishing station of the Champagne Indians, that Rev. Lee was approached by several Indian parents and asked if he would take care of their children at his Whitehorse school during the winter.

This modest petition was granted, but far more children than had been anticipated arrived at the school, until the original dozen or so became 40 or 50. The large building owned by Rev. Lee was turned into dormitories, classrooms, kitchen and mess-hall. The feeding of the children constituted a tremendous problem, as very few of the parents seem to realize their own responsibility in the matter. The situation has been somewhat eased by the white citizens of Whitehorse, who, realizing the altruistic efforts of Rev. Lee have held bazaars, sales, etc., and in many charitable ways, endeavored to assist the Indian school.

The two teachers are the only paid personnel at the school. These teachers receive extremely modest salaries for the Yukon, as they are not in receipt of Northern Living Allowance, though I believe the matter is under consideration. Besides the two paid teachers, there are the following unpaid workers: Rev. H.I. Lee, director; Mr. Deforest Lee, mechanical work; Mrs. D. Lee, cook; Mr. Rimling, boys supervisor; Mrs. Rimling, girls supervisor; Mrs. Maggie Chitze (Indian), laundress. The school cannot be considered a religious institution, but is interdenominational.
Rev. Lee understands and appreciates the position the Branch is in when he took in boarders without first making financial arrangements with the Department. Despite this, and the many other difficulties presented, the school is an unqualified success, and compares favorably with any white school in the Yukon.

May the Rev. H.I. Lee be advised of any arrangements between Indian Affairs Branch and himself for the continuance of his boarding school with the assistance of the Department.

Dear Sir:

The main reason that the Department is reluctant to commit itself by recognizing this school as a residential school is of course due to the seeming lack of provision for permanency or continuity in its management.

We have four denominations, viz.: Church of England, Presbyterian, Roman Catholic and United Church, now operating residential schools for Indians. Past experience has proven that great care must be taken before recognizing the smaller denominations and entering into contracts with them for the operation of residential schools.

We are building a residential school at Teslin with a pupilage of 120. It is our intention to purchase from the Church of England their residential school at Carcross. When this has been done it is our intention to improve this school and to increase its pupilage. With these two residential schools and our day schools, we had hoped to provide sufficient educational facilities for the Indian children of the Yukon.

It would be appreciated if we could have your comments concerning these points. We would also like to be advised as to

(a) whether the Territorial Government is paying a per capita grant for the non-Indians,

(b) Whether there is any denomination behind the Reverend Mr. Lee.

Dear Doctor Moore,

Re: Mr. Lee's School

On my recent visit to the Yukon I failed to mention Mr. Lee and his school in my report. This man has, in a very short time, built up an excellent reputation for his school and for his own very excellent relationship with the Native Indians.

The children who are cared for in his school are looked after extremely well and from the health standpoint are also carefully watched. Mr. Lee has been most co-operative with Mr. Neek and Miss Larkin and on many occasions when the local hospital has lacked beds, he has taken in Indian children and looked after them until a hospital bed in Whitehorse was free. I thought I would mention these things about Mr. Lee as I feel he deserves every consideration and help from our Department. I would recommend that a supply of necessary drugs be furnished to him for use in his school, along the same lines as is presently supplied to the Edmonton Residential School.

Whitehorse Indian School

Reference to a/m subject. Yesterday, October 18th, I was asked to sit in on negotiations between Rev. H.I. Lee, director of the Whitehorse Indian School, and Mr. C.J. Rogers, president of the White Pass and Yukon Railroad Co., concerning buildings and land on which the Indian School is situated.

The property concerned measures some 120 feet by 200 feet, and is owned by the White Pass Rwy., and which was leased to the Department of Mines and Resources some five years ago "for the purpose of constructing the Northwest Highway". The U.S. Army built a large office on this site, which has since been acquired by Rev. Lee. Department of Mines and Resources still hold the lease for the ground, but Mr. Rogers expects this will be given up in the future.

When the Department relinquish their lease on this land (apparently on word from the Canadian Army), Mr. Gordon is willing to lease the said land to Rev. Lee at a rental of $250 per annum for a period of five years, with the understanding that at the end of that time if either party wish to withdraw, then the present building must be dismantled and moved away. This is in accord with the policy of the War Assets Corporation.

Mr. Rogers wants to know if the Indian Affairs Branch are concerned with this lease. Is more ground needed? If so, he is willing to make arrangements for this. The land is not included in the taxation area of Whitehorse, but all indications point to it being included in the not too far distant future. Mr. Rogers would like to be guided by the policy of the I.A. Branch with regard to schools - whether day or residential. Would it be possible for Mr. C.A.F. Clark, if he should be in this area, to represent the Branch in discussions on the matter with Mr. Rogers and Rev. Lee.

(R.J. Meek)

Ottawa, October 23, 1947.

Mr. R.J. Meek, Indian Agent, Whitehorse, Yukon.

Residential School Operated at Whitehorse, Yukon by Reverend H.L. Lee.

Reference your letters of August 18th and October 8th, concerning the operation of a Residential School at Whitehorse.

This matter has been discussed with the Director and with the Deputy Minister and I have been directed to inform you that we can take no action towards recognizing this as an Indian Residential School at the present time. It has been decided to postpone any such action for at least a year.

With reference to the request for wood for this school, it is felt that the Department should not be asked to pay more than its share. We are already providing for the salaries of two teachers at this school and for a large quantity of school supplies. We understand that these teachers are teaching half-breeds and whites as well as Indians. We have enough difficulty providing funds for our Indian schools alone without providing for the education of half-breeds and whites. I hope you will appreciate the fact that it is not because we do not want to help Mr. Lee but because we have many pressing demands on the moneys that are provided us each year. We have opened several new schools already this year and several more are under construction. Each new school is another source of drain upon our estimates.
Therefore, it is suggested that you review the wood situation with Mr. Lee with the possibility of having his request for $90.00 per month for wood reduced somewhat. It is also suggested that you let us know the number of Indian children, the number of half-breeds and the number of white children who are now enrolled at this school:

(a) As boarders

(b) As Day School Pupils.

This will enable us to present a more accurate picture of its operation, if required.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Memorandum:

DEPARTMENTAL PURCHASING AGENT

Re: Purchase Order 21231

The above was issued to Smith Davidson and Wright, Vancouver, B.C. The desks have never been delivered and in a letter dated June 3rd which we have just received, Indian Commissioner Arneil writes:

"Smith Davidson & Wright who advise that their Mr. Smith has tried unsuccessfully for months to procure these desks for the school at Whitehorse and so notified the Department.

"If Mr. Smith's letter has not been received this office will if you so desire make further attempts to purchase these desks locally.

"However this type of desk appears to be non-existent in this part of the country and it is thought that the Departmental Purchasing Agent would have more success with the Eastern markets."

We recommend that this purchase order be cancelled and that you replace the order with some firm that are prepared to deliver the desks.

Dear Mr. Simmons:

Personal Greetings!

I am taking this opportunity to write you and place before you a request which I trust you will in turn present to the proper authorities there.

You are more familiar with our School here than perhaps anyone else in the community, you know the efforts that I have put forth to get this work established so that the Indian might have a place to attend school here in the Yukon which they didn't have prior to our opening up of this much needed work. I feel that you are the only one who I can ask to present to Ottawa the urgent need of a proper Boarding School. We have invested everything that we owned to establish this work and we want to see it go ahead and not back. The time has come where we will have to make major repairs to this place if it is to be used much longer for this purpose. Therefore it would seem unwise to invest much more in the present set up due to the serious fire hazard that presents itself in the nature of this particular arrangement.

I believe too that you are acquainted with the fact that we do not own the ground upon which our present School is located, this presents the problem of knowing what to do in regards to any permanent construction or work being done on our present buildings. I am quite prepared to have the school out of town a few miles if we will be able to get a new school under construction very soon. We are anxious about this matter and feel that something should be done as quickly as possible in this regard.

MEMORANDUM TO THE DIRECTOR

WHITEHORSE INDIAN SCHOOL

I have noted the contents of Mr. Lee's letter of February 14, to Mr. J. A. Simmons, M.P.

As you are aware, this is not an Indian residential school but a private school at which Indian pupils are boarded while their parents are on trap line. We pay an amount towards the maintenance of each child and we also operate, in conjunction with this establishment, a day school at which both the boarding and the day pupils are given classroom education.

I feel that great care must be exercised in dealing with Mr. Lee as he seems to have no church body backing his efforts. Another disturbing feature is the possibility that the Anglican school at Carcross may have to be moved. Canon Cook is not in favour of Mr. Simmons' suggestion that it be moved either to Carmacks or to Selkirk. He would prefer to have it established in the vicinity of Whitehorse. If so, we would be faced with requests for the building of two residential schools near Whitehorse,-

(a) Mr. Lee
(b) the Anglican school transferred from Carcross.

We have worked for many years with the four well established churches in the operation of these residential schools and our officials feel that we should not undertake to engage in a contract with a fifth church.

Bernard F. Neary
Superintendent of Education.
The Director,
Indian Health Services,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Str:

At Whitehorse I visited the school operated by Rev. Mr. Lee. He has built up this school over about three years past and now has 75 Indian and some 15 other pupils in residence. I was told that he or his sponsors founded the school at their expense and carried it on for a year or more without the financial co-operation which they now enjoy from the Department.

The buildings are converted army huts and do not look to be in very good repair. The fire hazard is extremely high, but as the buildings are all one story and have plenty of doors the residents would all probably be able to escape.

The premises were as clean and well-kept as could be expected in such buildings. The children were clean, looked well nourished, orderly and cheerful.

Mr. Lee is concerned about the future of the school. The buildings in use will not last long and will become an increasing problem in themselves over the very near future. If for any reason the premises had to be abandoned, 75 Indian children would have no school. There must be about 300 Indians of school age in the Yukon. I know of 5 schools other than this one, and would suppose their total capacity to be about 175. Some few are also in public schools at Dawson and Whitehorse, not many.

It is perhaps not my place to go into detail about education at large, but I appreciate the care, feeding, teaching and health supervision of these 75 children at Mr. Lee's school.

E.L. Stone,
Regional Superintendent,
Indian Health Services.

MEMORANDUM TO THE DIRECTOR

WHITEHORSE INDIAN SCHOOL

March 14, 1950.

As requested by you, I have prepared the following statement which might assist Mr. J.A. Simmons, M.P., in replying to the Reverend H.A. Lee's letter of February 14:

(1) We are now operating Indian Residential Schools in conjunction with four religious denominations. They assume considerable responsibility in the management of these schools and are responsible organizations who assume considerable financial burden in the conduct of these schools. Mr. Lee does not have such financial backing.

(2) The Department does not recognize Mr. Lee's school as an Indian Residential School but only as a private school at which Indian pupils are boarded while their parents are on the trap-line. There are of course a number of non-Indian children at the school towards whose maintenance the Yukon Territorial Council makes a contribution.

(3) The Anglican Residential School will be forced in the near future to move from Carcross. The new school will probably be required within a radius of 100 miles of Whitehorse. If so, we would be faced with requests for the building of two Indian Residential Schools for Protestant children in or near Whitehorse.

(4) We have worked for many years with the four well established Churches in the operation of these residential schools and we do not feel that any benefit would result in the association with another religious group. From the educational point of view it would be most desirable to build...
a larger residential school rather than two smaller units.

We appreciate the good work that has been accomplished at the Whitehorse School under the direction of Mr. Lee. He has carried on under difficult circumstances and much credit is due him for the success of this institution. He, however, is an individual and there is no guarantee that the school would continue to function if he were to depart.

To summarize therefore, we cannot recommend the establishment of two Protestant Residential Schools in or near Whitehorse when educational facilities for Indians are so badly needed elsewhere.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Dear Mr. Simmons:

I am returning herewith the letter you received from Reverend H.I. Lee, Principal of the Whitehorse Indian Mission School.

The subject matter of Mr. Lee's letter has been given careful consideration by the officials of Indian Affairs, including the writer, and I may say at the outset that this Branch could not entertain, at this time, the proposal involving the construction of another residential school in the Yukon-Northern British Columbia section of Canada.

As you know, we are committed to the construction of the first unit of a new residential school to replace the school at Carcross, operated under the auspices of the Church of England. In addition to this, the Branch this year is undertaking the construction of a new residential school at Lower Post, immediately south of the Yukon-British Columbia Boundary, to serve both the Yukon Territory and northern parts of British Columbia. It is our hope that these schools will, when completed, meet to a very large extent the residential school needs of the Indians of those sections. We are, of course, prepared to extend the day school system as and when the need arises.

We greatly appreciate the good work that has been accomplished at the Whitehorse School under the direction of Mr. Lee. He has carried on under difficult circumstances and much credit is due him for the success of the school operated under his direction.
The circumstances are such, however, that we are not in a position to do more to assist in the educational work now being carried on by Mr. Lee than what this Branch is doing at present, unless it is by way of some minor changes in the arrangement now in existence.

I am forwarding for your personal information a copy of a memorandum to me from the Superintendent of Indian Education, Mr. B.F. Neary, on the subject.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Sir:

I am enclosing a letter which I received from Miss H. Larken in regards to a piano which she has for sale.

I am wondering if perhaps your department will consider the purchase of this piano for The Indian Day School here. We are in great need of a piano for our social activities for the children here at school.

This would save the department considerably in the way of transportation charges etc., if this can be arranged.

Yours Very Truly,

Rev. H.I. Lee.
Whitehorse, Y.T.
6th, April 1950

Rev. H. I. Lee,

WHITEHORSE, Y.T.

Dear Sir:

I have for sale a Stanley upright piano which is in excellent condition.

Would you care to purchase this piano for $285.00.

Yours very truly,

H. Larkin,
Box 87,
WHITEHORSE, Y.T.

OTTAWA, Ontario.

I might state that some ten children of the Indian School are now taking piano lessons from a teacher in Whitehorse. The pupils pay their own tuition costs. A piano for practice purposes is supplied by Rev. Lee at the school, but it is an old one, and a replacement or extra piano is needed.

Art Classes - Whitehorse Indian School:

The attached photos show some of the art work done in the classes conducted by Miss Lillias Farley who divides her time between our school and the larger Yukon Territory school in Whitehorse. The children work in paper, cloth (with which Mrs. Meek and Miss Ruth Sconholz are associated), leather, sheet metal, plaster, and wood. Miss Farley is adept in various graphic and plastic arts.

She made a special appointment with Mr. Supt. Meek and me to discuss an increase in salary. She thinks that an proportional increase, based on the rate of increase for academic teachers would be justified. It is to be noted that she does not draw the northern allowance. She is employed nine hours a week in our Department's service. Could she be granted nine-twenty-fifths of the northern allowance. I cannot see how we can increase the number of hours which she gives to the Whitehorse School. She would not be easy to replace.

I should like to see her put on paper the plans for work next year which she discussed with me, and elaborate her objectives and the methods and time which she proposes to use to accomplish agreed objectives.

The classroom which has been established for this work is a superior installation.

C.A.F. Clark
Educational Survey Officer
Memorandum:

CHIEF, EDUCATION DIVISION.

Whitehorse Indian Day School - Rental of Buildings

I notice that the bill from the Reverend H.I. Lee for the rental of classrooms at Whitehorse is supported by a reference to me.

The subject came up for discussion when I was at Whitehorse in June as a result of Departmental letter this file dated May 1 which stated that as the Department does not own these buildings, funds cannot be provided for painting them. On being asked whether the Department would pay rent for the buildings I suggested that an application for payment of rent by the Department would receive consideration.

The bill as submitted appears to be retroactive in the case of the classrooms to the first of September, 1949 and in regard to the two Arts rooms to the first of January, 1950, when they were taken into use after a considerable sum had been spent in making them ready for their specialized purposes.

Mr. Superintendent Meek and the Reverend H.I. Lee seem to have overlooked the fact 16 of the children attending this school are of non-Indian status and are the responsibility of the Yukon Territorial Government. I do not know what the Y.T. Government allows this school other than about $1.25 a day for the maintenance of boarders. Our Department still holds the figure to 95¢ a day.
There is no denying that the buildings require painting and other maintenance and that the sum charged for the rental of the classrooms is quite moderate considering their size and appointments and the location of the school. The Reverend Mr. Lee hopes to have the buildings painted this summer. If they remain unpainted local residents and visitors may ask why and will, of course, be told that the Department has declined to purchase any paint and has not been paying rent for the buildings.

The question arises as to whether some written agreement for the use of the classrooms should be required and stating what the obligations of the landlord are in the case.

C.A.F. Clark

C.A.F. Clark,
Educational Survey Officer.

Reference is to your letter of September 7th.

In view of the fact that Mr. Donald Armour is employed part-time by the Whitehorse Territorial School what possibility is there of making an arrangement with the local school authorities whereby the children of Mr. Lee's school could receive instruction in Manual Training at the Territorial school? In investigating this possibility, you would have to find out:

(a) How many pupils from Mr. Lee's school will receive Manual Training?
(b) How many of these pupils are of non-Indian status?
(c) How many pupils will the Whitehorse Territorial School accommodate at one session?
(d) How much would Mr. Armour charge for one three-hour session per week?
(e) Would there be any charge for the use of facilities at the Territorial school? (You imply that these facilities and the instructor are occupied only part-time.)
(f) If it is not possible for the boys from Mr. Lee's school to attend for Manual Training in one group would they be permitted to mingle with the classes presently being conducted at the Territorial school? If so, would there be any charge for this?

If the arrangements suggested above cannot be made, and it is hoped that they can be, further consideration is required concerning the installation of these facilities at our Indian school.
Firstly, further details are required concerning Mr. Armour's application which he has only partly completed. He states he is married but has he any dependents? Where are his wife and children if any? He claims Grade twelve education but where did he receive it? Where else other than at Whitehorse school and for how long in each case did he teach Manual Training? What remuneration does he receive from the Territorial Government for his services, and how much of his time is already occupied in the teaching of Manual Training? How much time is it suggested that he give to the Whitehorse Indian school? What remuneration therefor is suggested?

Regarding accommodation for Manual Training at the Indian school you state that there is an "ample amount of space" available. What are the dimensions of this room? How many boys can be accommodated at one session? Are there any work benches available? Where would the tools be kept in relation to this room? How is the room heated and lighted?

With regard to reorganization of the school programme required by the addition of this work can you tell us what parallel arrangements will be made for the girls of the grade from which the boys for Manual Training are to be drawn?

Whitehorse Indian School - Manual Training

Your letter of September 14th, file 929-11 (E3) on the above subject. I have interviewed Mr. Armour, manual training teacher, Mr. Todd, principal Territorial School, and the Rev. Lee, director Whitehorse Indian School on the points raised by you. We find the present arrangements at the Territorial School poor for manual training, only 14 pupils can be accommodated in the room, and the principal is looking for a more satisfactory manual training workshop. Mr. Todd would like to make arrangements with this Branch to use suitable space in the Indian School, the manual training room to be used by both schools on a mutually satisfactory schedule.

Replying to your queries in proper order:

(a) At September 30th, 26 pupils from Mr. Lee's school would be eligible and capable of manual training.
(b) Seven of these are of non-Indian status.
(c) As mentioned above: 14.
(d) Mr. Armour charges $5.00 per one-hour period, scaling down with increase in hours, i.e., $30.00 for a week of 8 periods.
(e) Territorial school facilities are not satisfactory.
(f) Not a suitable arrangement.

Regarding Mr. Armour's application: he is married, no dependents. His wife lives in Edmonton. He received all his education in Glasgow. He taught for two years in public schools in Toronto. At the present time Mr. Armour receives $5.00 per hour; he teaches 10 periods a week, this represents about 50% of his occupied time. For the Indian school it was suggested the class be divided in two, with instruction from 3:15 to 5 PM, for four days a week; this plan is tentative and it would have to be given a trial to note its efficacy. I would suggest Mr. Armour be offered $25.00 per week.

Reference your fourth paragraph: the Rev. Lee has a room available measuring 20' x 50', it is well lighted, has a good floor, electricity, toilet facilities adjacent, and can be heated with wood fires. Twenty pupils can be accommodated at one time without crowding. There are 13 work benches available at the Territorial School, with material available for additional benches and projects.
The tools would be kept under lock and key in the manual training room. Tools and equipment provided by each institution would be kept separate though it is very probable that some things would be used in common. Heating is by wood stoves, lighting by ample window space and electric lights.

With the above arrangements, there would be no need for parallel arrangements for the girls. However, if the condition arises, sewing classes have been arranged for the girls.

There are at present about 50 boys at the Territorial School receiving manual training, just about double the number at the Indian School. The heads of both schools are in agreement with the plan suggested above, and the Rev. Lee is willing to make suitable alterations for a manual training workshop.

(R.J. Meek)
Superintendent
Indian Agency.

Whitehorse Indian School—Manual Training:

With Mr. Supt. Meek I viewed the room suggested for manual training. I think the Supervisor of Vocational training would be satisfied with its physical features.

The proposal is that the Territory move in some equipment and that the Indian Affairs Branch supply the additional hand-tools needed. As the Territory hopes to set up its own establishment some day and would likely want some of its property returned, careful inventories will have to be kept.

In a discussion with the high school principal I learned that all local officials concerned were in favour of an arrangement whereby the public school would have the use of the room daily from one to three o'clock in the afternoon, and that the Indian school class would be conducted on Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays from three to five o'clock. I suppose that the Indian boys might be allowed in at other times under supervision (by someone other than the instructor).

It was stated that the instructor, Mr. Donald Armour, could be obtained for $100 a month, but I offered the opinion that, in view of his probable grading by our rules, $75 is a more appropriate figure. He will average about twenty-five hours a month. Besides, the art teacher, Miss Farley, will average thirty-nine hours a month for a salary of $100, and her qualifications in her field appear to be superior to Mr. Armour's in his.

C.A.F. Clark

(a) Manual Training.

We have noted Major Clark's report of November 11 with a recommendation that we establish a manual training shop at Whitehorse. I am not quite clear as to whether this will be a joint enterprise but gather that it is. If so, why are the Indian school boys to be taught from 3 to 5 while the white children attend from 1 to 3. As it is an Indian school (?) why should not the Indian children attend at the best time.

I am aware of the plans to erect a large school at Whitehorse and wonder whether we could not have our Indian children sent to this public school as we are doing elsewhere across the country. I of course am not aware of local feeling but as other school boards are admitting more and more Indian children, I wonder whether the time is ripe for such a suggestion at Whitehorse.

Whitehorse Indian Day School

Reference your letter of 18th instant, file 929-11 (E), and Manual Training. The establishment of a manual training shop at the above school will be a joint enterprise between this Branch and the Yukon Territorial Government insofar as the same teacher will be used under two different arrangements, and the same shop will be used. It is also likely that some tools will be used jointly by the different institutions, but as the Territorial School already has a moderate supply of tools, and as this Branch will obtain tools independently, it is not a joint enterprise in the full sense of the word.

The reason the Indian school boys will be taught between 3 and 5 PM is because the three teachers of the Indian school requested it. The average age of Indian children is considerably above the corresponding grade at the Territorial School, consequently our own teachers do not wish to lose a minute of teaching time. Also as almost all the boys are boarding at the school, there is not a great deal for them to do after school during the winter months when it gets dark so early.

Regarding your second paragraph; the Yukon School Ordinance does not discriminate against Indians, but the several times Indian children were placed in Territorial Schools it ended as a fiasco. A case as recent as 1947 happened at Mayo. Neither the administration nor the teachers would discourage admitting Indians to Territorial Schools, it is always a few parents who raise a violent objection. Regardless of this, I believe the time is at hand when the suggestion of admitting senior grade Indian pupils into Territorial Schools should be made. Most of the Indian children would have to be maintained at some institution, as the parents live away from Whitehorse.

(R.J. Meek)

CANADA
Indian Affairs Branch,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

Manual Training

Mr. Donald Armour, manual training instructor for Whitehorse Indian School, has been to see me this morning concerning the programme laid down by Training Division for the manual training course.

It is Mr. Armour's opinion that the Basic Operations required in Woodwork are too advanced for the average elementary school pupil, Indian or white. Some of the requirements in the list for Third Year seem very advanced indeed and would be a challenge for adult minds.

Mr. Armour has requested permission to use the programme laid down by Territorial school officials until our own requirements are brought more into keeping with the abilities of the pupils.

I am not certain if you require a list of all pupils given instruction who are attending the Whitehorse Indian School. As you are aware, a number of half-breed children, the responsibility and charge of the Yukon Territory, are in attendance at the Whitehorse Indian School, and are taught in our classrooms. Do you wish a record kept by the manual training instructor of these children of non-Indian status?

Your comments regarding Mr. Armour's views on the Manual Training curriculum would be appreciated.

(R.J. Meek)

Memorandum of an inquiry into the cause and circumstances of the death of Donald Miller, Pupil No., of the Whitehorse Indian Residential School at Whitehorse, who died at Whitehorse General Hospital (place) on Feb. 22nd, 1951.

INSTRUCTIONS

When a pupil of an Indian Residential School dies, the Principal is required to inform the Indian Agent at once.

On receipt of the Principal's notice the Indian Agent shall convene a Board of Inquiry, consisting of himself as Chairman, the Principal of the Residential School, and the Medical Officer who attended the deceased pupil. These members of the Board shall, in each other's presence, complete this memorandum, which shall then be forwarded to the Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, in one copy.

The Board of Inquiry shall, if at all practicable assemble within 48 hours of the pupil's death.

The parents or guardians of the deceased pupil shall be given notice of this inquiry and be permitted to attend it or to send a representative. They or their representative shall be asked if they wish to make a statement. In the event of their so wishing, their statement shall be attached to the report. The inquiry, however, shall not be delayed more than 72 hours after the time at which it would otherwise be held, to enable them to attend it.

If the Indian Agent is located at such a distance from the school as to make it impracticable for him to attend the Board, he shall request a responsible local resident to act for him. A suitable person for this duty would be a Justice of the Peace or a member of the Royal Canadian Mounted or Provincial Police. A more or less permanent arrangement of this kind might be necessary in some cases. The Department is prepared to pay a reasonable fee for this duty, on the Agent's recommendation. The report of the Board, in any case, must reach the Department through the Indian Agent's office.

This inquiry is not designed to take the place of, or prevent, any other inquiry, including an inquest, which may be required by law.

If the pupil died as the result of an accident, the Indian Agent is required to take the statements of the witnesses of the accident, and attach them to this memorandum.

6. When was the doctor called? Feb 21st at 12:00 midnight
7. If the pupil was removed to hospital, at what time was this done and by what means of transport? Shortly after 12:00 midnight by Dr. Stewart's car.
8. If the pupil was not removed to hospital, what measures were taken for his or her care at the school?

Mr. R.J. Meek,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
Whitehorse, Y.T.

We have your letter of the 23rd ultimo enclosing memorandum of an inquiry into the cause and circumstances of the death of Donald Miller. We were quite concerned when we noted that the boy died of Tuberculous Meningitis.

This boy was a resident of the hostel section of the Whitehorse Day School, and we have been paying for his maintenance. We presumed that all children were being medically examined before they entered the school, and a serious condition might develop if there are any other pupils in this hostel suffering from Tuberculosis.

It is noted that many of the application forms have been signed by a registered nurse and not by a doctor. Are you certain that every possible precaution is being taken to insure that only medically fit children are being admitted to the hostel? As a result of this boy's death has any effort been made to have the other children medically examined at once to make certain that there are no other children suffering from Tuberculosis?

We have submitted the whole matter to the Indian Health Services and they intend to bring it to the attention of Dr. Falconer, but in any case, we would like to have a reply to this letter.

Philip Phelan,
A/Superintendent of Education

PP/ST
Dr. W. L. Falconer,
Medical Director,
Charles Camell Hospital,
Edmonton, Alberta.

Dear Dr. Falconer:

Res: Donald Miller, Age 10, Whitehorse.

Following is a Clinical History of the above-mentioned boy.

Donald Miller had been a pupil at Whitehorse Indian School for the past 4 years. He seemed a normal child except for the fact that on occasions he had violent night-mares. He also had emesis unless roused at 11.30 p.m. to void. Medical advice about this was sought from Drs. Ziskrout and Pelletier but upon examining the child, they did not prescribe any medication. Reports here indicate the child had a negative chest x-ray in February 1949 and August 1950. He was immunized against Diphtheria and Whooping-Cough in 1949.

Donald had what seemed to be a slight cold for several days and on Monday, Feb. 19th, complained of headache. As 'flu was prevalent in the town the boy was sent to bed in the sick-ward of the school. He was kept on soft diet and fluids were forced. At no time was his temperature, which was taken twice daily, over 100 degrees. The headache persisted. On Wednesday, Feb. 21st, Donald had a poached egg on toast for his supper but complained of nausea and was unable to eat it all. However he was apparently asleep when the boy's supervisor made rounds at 9 P.M. At 11.30 P.M. efforts were made to rouse him to void. He seemed in a coma and Mr. Lee, School Principal, was summoned. He called the Doctor at once.

I am sorry you received the unreliable information that Dr. Stewart did not see this patient before he died. Dr. Stewart was called at 11.45 p.m. and responded immediately to the call. He examined the boy at the school then personally took him to the Hospital. Here a Spinal Puncture was done and Penicillin administered. The boy died several hours later and Dr. Stewart, to verify his diagnosis, had an autopsy done. The specimen was sent to the Provincial Laboratory at Edmonton and a reply has not as yet been received.

Each child is given a medical examination when he is enrolled at the school for the first time. Unless specially indicated, he is not given a medical examination at the start of the succeeding term, especially if he has had a negative x-ray that year. However, each child has a medical examination some time during the school term.

The school has a good infirmary for both boys and girls and one supervisor is specially appointed to care for any patients. It is her custom to notify me when any child has the slightest ailment and Dr. Stewart is always called if there is the slightest indication of anything serious. In this instance I was at Mayo and was not available.

There was absolutely no evidence of neglect on the part of anyone. Special commendation is due Mr. Lee's Staff for the very excellent care given to the children at the school.

Respectfully submitted,

Copy: Dr. Wm. C. Stewart.
Dr. E.L. Stone, Regional Director,
Indian Health Services.
Mr. R.J. Meek,
Sup't Yukon Agency.

"Mary V. Wilson"

I am in receipt of your letter of lst instant, file 929-23 (El) re death of Donald Miller, a pupil of the Whitehorse Indian Day School. All pupils are examined by Dr. W.C. Stewart or Miss A. Wilson, R.N., Indian Health Services, shortly after they arrive at the school for admittance.

Regarding the medical examination of children by Nurse Wilson, my Quarterly Report October - December 1950, page 6 stated that Dr. Stewart was the only civilian doctor in Whitehorse and he was not always available to examine school pupils. He is aware of Nurse Wilson's outstanding qualifications and her examinations have his consent. In addition, throughout the year Miss Wilson has clinics two or three times a week at the Whitehorse Indian Day School, and a complete record is kept of the medical history of each child.

A copy of a letter to Miss Wilson and Dr. Stewart from Dr. W.L. Falconer, Charles Camell Hospital, Edmonton, has been received asking for a Clinical History and other information on Donald Miller. I am attaching copy of Miss Wilson's report to Dr. Falconer.

An effort was made immediately on the death of Donald Miller to have every child at the school X-rayed; as the Whitehorse General Hospital could not handle mass X-rays permission was given by Dr. E.L. Stone, C.M.G., Regional Supt., I.H.S., to have the children X-rayed at the Army Hospital, and I understand this is being done today under the direction of Dr. Stewart and one of the R.C.A.M.C. doctors.

Donald Miller has been a pupil of the Whitehorse Indian Day School since it opened over four years ago. He has been X-rayed each year and examined a number of occasions by different I.H.S. nurses; when he was taken to the hospital Dr. Stewart stayed with him from before midnight to 2 A.M. administering professional treatment. Donald died at 3 A.M. I am satisfied that every effort is made to admit only medically fit pupils to the school, and that everything possible was done to care for Donald Miller.

c.c. Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Particulars regarding Yukon Indians.
(Received June, 1907. A.F. O'H.)

1. Name of Band? Teslin Lake.
2. Tribe or Nation? Klinkit or Hlingit.
3. Language? Klinkit or Hlingit.
4. Principal Village or other headquarters? Nisutlin Bay, Teslin Lake.
5. Territory over which Band hunts, traps or fishes?
   Surrounding Teslin Lake and eastward to Wolf Lake.
6. Occupations of band other than hunting, trapping or fishing?
   No others of any account.
7. Period or periods of year spent in headquarters?
   They are absent during winter from one to four months.
   A few have cabins in Atlin and spend there part of summer and fall.
   Others occasionally visit Atlin.
8. Total number of Band? 95.

Additional Memo. re Teslin Lake Indians.

1. In intellectual capacity and industry these Indians seem to be amongst the best in the Yukon. It will be noticed that many of the young men are anxious to learn. The children also seem promising. One boy, fifteen years of age went out trapping by himself during the past winter and sold his furs for $96.00.

2. The conditions in relation to marriage are not wholly satisfactory. Christian marriage is generally recognized, a religious service based upon that of the Presbyterian Church being used. There are, however, cases of bigamy, discarding the first wife, etc.

3. In addition to those of which particulars are given, a number of the Teslin Lake Indians at present reside at Atlin, but it is thought that many of these would return if a school were established at the Lake; It seems manifest that such result would be in the best interests of the Indians and their children.

4. Father Allard has been since June devoting himself to work among the Indians residing at Atlin and has purchased a building to be used as a school.

5. At Teslin Lake the Indians conduct each Sunday two services in the native language, using prayers, hymns and chants taught them by the Russian Church at Juneau. Much superstition is mingled with these services, but all the people join in them and seem earnest and reverent.

6. These Indians request that the Government and the Church of England should send them a teacher who will conduct
conduct a school for the children and young people and also teach Christianity to all. They offer to undertake a share of the support of such teacher by providing such articles as meat, fish and wood. Messrs. Taylor and Drury, proprietors of the Trading Post, also express a strong desire that this be done and offer to help.

7. One of the Indians, Edgar Sidney, was educated at a Presbyterian school in Sitka and was baptized in the Russian Church, of which he became a communicant. He speaks English well and has an English Bible with which by orally translating he teaches the people. He desires further training with a view to being an ordained minister. It is possible that with some assistance he might translate portions of the Scriptures into the Klinkit language. Any such translation would be useful for some thousands of Indians along the Coast of Alaska speaking the same language.

8. The Government has so far done nothing for the Teslin Lake Indians.

Dear Mr. Scott:

Upon the occasion of our recent interview the work connected with the Day School which has recently been established by the Church of England at Nisutlin Bay, Teslin Lake, was fully explained, and it was understood that I should lay before the Department a formal application for an additional grant to be made from the current year's appropriation towards the support of that work.

I have since had opportunity of conferring with Bishop Stringer regarding the amount which it would be reasonable to ask the Department to contribute for that purpose, and now beg to make application for a total grant of $1150.00 made up as follows:

- Salary of J.R. Bythell for 9 months at $50.00........... $450.00
- Mr. Bythell's travelling expenses within the Territory. (Estimated)......................... 100.00
- Buildings now in course of construction............. 500.00
- Furnishing and equipment.......................... 100.00

Total...................... $1150.00

Let me add a few words of explanation. The salary which is being paid to Mr. Bythell is at the rate of $600.00 per annum. Of the travelling expenses we have not full particulars.
As you are aware however such expenses are very heavy in the Yukon, and the Church has paid in addition the expenses incurred in travelling to the Yukon. With regard to the amount asked for buildings it is well to have in mind that the Government probably could not in the ordinary course of business erect the same buildings for twice the money. You will remember that Mr. Bythell expected to secure voluntary help from prospectors in the construction.

A cheque for the amount decided upon may be made out in my favor and sent to Wycliffe College, Toronto.

Yours very truly,

Financial Secretary,
Diocese of Yukon.
Ottawa, April 26th., 1909.

Right Reverend Sir,-

I have to inform you that an application made by the Rev. A. E. O'Meara on behalf of the Day School which it is proposed to establish at Teslin Lake has received consideration. The Department will be disposed to allow a salary of $500.00 per annum for the teacher, and $300.00 for the rental of the building in which the School is to be conducted. The continuance of the grant will be contingent upon the results obtained from year to year at the School. Payments will be made in the usual way, and the grant may take effect from the 1st. of January last, if the School was then in operation and if the usual returns are forthcoming.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLEAN

The attendance, however, varies very much because the Indians go off on hunting expeditions and return again for a time to the vicinity of the school. Mr. Bythell reported twenty as enrolled but there will be considerable variation in the attendance. Particulars regarding Indians of Teslin Lake.

The Indians at Teslin Lake are known as the Klinkits. The tribe numbers about 80 including men, women and children. Their chief occupation is hunting and trapping. They leave Teslin Lake, their headquarters about first week in September to engage in their work of hunting and trapping furs until June or July when they return with their winter's catch and spend the summer there.

When I arrived at Teslin Lake August 13th 1908, I only found about one third of the tribe there, the others having left for their hunting grounds only two days before. With the assistance of two young Indians, I erected a temporary school and started to give instruction the same day (Aug 13th 08). Of the 26 Indians who were there, 20 came to school. Those who could not come to day school owing to work generally attended my special class which I held every evening.
When these Indians were leaving I gave to each a book containing writing exercises and instructions how to write them and also sent books to many who had gone out before I got there.

During the winter I visited as many of my scholars as it was possible for me to reach. At each camp I would stop long enough to review their work and assign more writing exercises, and also give medicine to those who needed it. Of course I held religious services on all my visits.

Those whom I could not reach generally sent their exercise books with other Indians who came in for supplies at Xmas time.

In the spring with the assistance of two other white men, I erected a building which we used as a Church and day school. This building was not quite ready when the Indians came in, in June. I called on them for help and they willingly set to work and finished it so that we were able to start school July 5th.
They showed their great appreciation of their new school by regular attendance. Thirty-eight were enrolled on my register, and many others not able to attend day school owing to building boats etc., came to the special classes which I held the evenings of the week.

The attendance at school continued very good, unfortunately I did not get the supply of books and pencils I had ordered. We used rough building paper and small pieces of pencil tied to pieces of sticks but even these crude materials could not last, so we were forced to close school about three weeks earlier than if our supplies had come.

I was very sorry to see them going away without their exercise books, which they begged for and had had the previous fall.

I might say that besides teaching school, I held regular religious services and Sunday school, also administered...
medicine and did all I could to relieve suffering. I had twenty-four cases of sickness and attended to cuts and wounds of various descriptions. No death occurred.

The Klinkitis are an unusually healthy tribe. They are also very clean and industrious, and rather intelligent. They are very anxious to learn to read and write.

They are also Patriotic and regularly celebrate Canada's Birthday, July 1st, by sports and decorations. As to their moral character, they are far above the average Indian, a quiet peaceful well-behaved people.

The Klinkiti Indians will likely be coming into their headquarters about June the 1st. I left Tulin Lake Oct 1st 1907.

J.M. Bythell.

In one respect the conditions would appear to be different from what we understood. Information secured in 1907 from sources thought quite reliable showed that during eight months of the year the Indians spent most of their time at their headquarters. Dear Sir,

I must apologize for the delay in answering your communication of May 30th regarding the Indian Day Schools in Yukon territory. I was in a remote part of the territory at Lambert House when your letter reached Dawson and it awaited my return. Since then I have been travelling almost continuously and could not get at my correspondence. I have only just received yours of August 12th.

In reply to your proposals to allow a grant of $200 for a teacher's salary and $200 rent for a building to a limited number of Day Schools, I wish to say that I feel the conditions laid down by you are in many cases prohibitive.

It is impossible in some cases to procure a minimum average of 10, and yet I think, in certain cases, the result justify us in having schools open with a much less average than ten and for a smaller number of School Days in the year than 75. I think you should
Consider carefully the circumstances and conditions in Yukon Territory. We are endeavoring to do our best to hold day schools for the Indians, and we have no desire to waste the time or our money in unpromising fields, if there are more suitable openings in other parts. The opening of a school for Indians is rather an experiment and we have to stand the cost of such experiments no matter what the result may be and I therefore think your Department could afford to deal liberally with any efforts to educate the Indians under such unfavorable conditions as obtain in the Yukon.

If the education of the children in our centre is considered to be worthy of a certain support, then the education of a smaller number should be worthy a proportionate amount especially in view of the fact that we, not the Department, have to stand all the initial expenses.

In the case of Champagne and Selin I have arranged that the teacher shall spend the winter at the former and the summer at the latter place, at our place.

With reference to Bishop Stringer's letter of the 7th of October supplemented by a personal interview with me later in the month I would submit that under the conditions prevailing in the Yukon our terms with reference to day schools were too exacting. The late Minister gave direction that "unless the attendance is up to a fixed minimum and for a fixed minimum of days the grant will not be continued". The phrase that you used was "where there is a prospect of obtaining a reasonably fair attendance". The Bishop recommends the minimum attendance to be 3 and the minimum number of school days in the year 40. If we were to make it any higher than this I think the schools would receive no revenue whatever from the Department and I am, therefore, favourable to accepting the limit set by the Bishop.

Sir,

When visiting Teslin Post, it was my pleasure to meet Mr Ball who is conducting the Mission at that point. In going into the matter of the education of the Indian children, it was found that much help could be given to Mr Ball with resultant benefit to the children attending that school.

I beg to respectfully submit a list of material that would come under that head, and would also beg that this be supplied the Teacher as soon as possible, for next year's school work.

It was noticed that the Black Board was not at all what it should be, and a better one, or even two is really wanted.

During a Sunday evening there, whilst torrents of rain fell a service was being conducted, and in passing I happened to glance into the building, and the sight that met my gaze was rather astounding. The roof was leaking, and water came in by streams, yet in spite of that the Indians were at service, and stayed there till the service was finished.

It is understood that $300-00 was collected last year for the purpose of doing some repairs, and more has been collected since, surely some assistance should be given right away to such a good crowd of Indians as there are in Teslin.

I wish to state that Mr Ball is doing very fine work, and should be helped in every way possible, and if my Office can in any way be of assistance, please command it.

I am,

Sir,

Your obedient servant.

Harper Reed.
Indian Agent.

Sir,

During this summer's visit to Teslin Post, Y.T., amongst other matters claiming my attention was that of "schooling" for the Indian children.

The Mission School at this point, was, this year, in charge of Mr. Semple - Bishop Stringer's man, and I found him a most capable, and energetic person with the Indians well-fare at heart.

The old Church, which also does duty as a day-school was inspected, and it is regretted that no improvements have been done since last year's visit. The youngsters when at school can look through the sides of the building, much to their huge enjoyment. Some roofing has, it is thought, been ordered, but was not seen. The building as it stands is not a decent place to be used as a Church or for a Day-School.

There is an average of 25 scholars in attendance, and this could be increased were attention given the school.

There are 4 classes going at the same time, and the more advanced are doing fractions; a sample of a girl's handwriting is herewith enclosed. Of School equipment there is practically nothing; cut-down baking powder cans being used for ink-pots, and many more make shifts were noticed. Slates for the children's use were not in evidence, in fact to summarize the matter, a complete set of school equipment is needed most urgently.

I beg to submit a letter with attached papers thereto, that was directed to Mr. Commissioner Hawksley of Dawson, last summer with regard to this school, and it was hoped by so doing that the supplies would be ready for use, this year.

Mr. Semple has done wonders this summer, amongst other things, a play ground has been cleared, swings, etc. have been set up. A presentation set of Base-Ball equipment would be most acceptable to the community, and would be well repaid by free labour given in return.

Respectfully submitted also, are some views taken during the visit, which go to show that these Indians are above the ordinary standard. As Teslin Post is cut off from all roads, it is to their credit that a 6 mile road has been hacked out-beaver-wise, along the edge of the lake, with quite a few bridges over creeks, and over this runs their car.

Also, these people will not accept "Rations" unless the cause is illness, and then the Old Chief has to be first interviewed, which would again go to show that they do deserve all the help that can be afforded, with the education of their children.

All of which, Sir, is most respectfully submitted with the hope that some assistance may be granted.

I am, Sir.

Your obedient servant,

Harper Reed,
Indian Agent.

Sir,

Inspector G. S. Pragnell, for the Indian Agencies of British Columbia, with your agency visited the Teslin Lake Yukon Terr. English Church Indian Day School, at that point on June 16th 1935, as reported. This Mission was then in charge of Rev Mr Parsons, who is resident, it is understood in Atlin, B.C. and goes over there for the Summer' work.

This School has been reported upon several times during the past years, and although in the Yukon Terr., serves the many B.C. Indian children who spend their summers at this point, and trap during the winters down the Lake 30 miles, which is in B.C.

The School deserves every assistance that can be given it, and upon this visit, again it was found short of real necessary supplies. Several times the Department has been good enough to allow this agency to send up School Supplies, but with over 30 odd children, and more coming along, the supplies it receives are quite insufficient.

Therefore may the necessary action be taken to have this excellent school put into such shape that the bright youngsters who attend same may reap a benefit. The worthy Minister is no doubt working at a private loss to his own pocket, for living here is most expensive, and is therefore entitled to some consideration in regard to equipment to carry on his good work- i.e. necessary school supplies.

May it be humbly suggested that the same sort and amount of supplies that have been granted to the Thaltan mission at this point, be allowed Teslin Lake. The Little Minister at Teslin has only requested the following small odds and ends which are considered not sufficient, or effective.

Sir:

I beg to submit hereunder a report covering the month of April 1938.

Next morning we got away early and had to run down to Simpson Lake to get over the difficult Liard Divide, but eventually made it and arrived at Teslin Post, on that Lake. It was found that some of the Jennings River band had arrived and the Chief was expected the next day. The R.C.M.P. Detachment was visited, and also the stores. All matters were taken up and dealt with. Fur here was just up to that of last year's catch, and as usual the B.C. Jennings River Indians were better fixed than those of the Yukon. Right Reverend Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 6th instant recommending the establishment of seasonal schools at Lower Post, B.C., in the Stikine Agency, and at Ware, B.C., in the Stuart Lake Agency.

Our estimates for the fiscal year 1939-40 were prepared in the fall of 1938. No provision was made in them for the expenses that would be necessary if schools were conducted at both these places during the summer of 1939. Under these circumstances favourable consideration cannot be given to your request at the present time.

Sir:

I beg to submit hereunder a report covering the month of February 1939.

During the fore part of this month the R.C. Mission's general affairs came up for reporting upon and same with their school requirements for next summer were duly submitted. Since then letters have been received from His Lordship Bishop Couder, O.M.I. to say that he is flying around to all the Mission points in the month of March, and expects to meet your agent in Atlin about the end of March. It is quite possible that we shall return to Telegraph Creek on the same plane when all matters will be closely taken up with him. They are pushing out their Missions in such a manner that there is a rush way requests will be coming along for further aid with their schools and their various teachers, and it is considered that some idea should be given to the Department as to what they intend to do - or it is done. As instance in point is that of Teslin Lake in the Yukon at which point the better set of Indians come in from the B.C. side of the Provincial Line. Here Bishop Geddis of the English Church has maintained a very fine Day school, to which all the Indian children attended, and to which the Department has allowed much help. To-day the R.C. Missions have taken up some vacant ground around the Trading Post of Messrs Taylor & Drury, and last summer moved Father Drein up from Liard Post and started to build their own Mission. Now the Indians of Teslin Lake have quite a revenue to spend, and being Indians are ever ready to shift their attention to something new, especially if they are made a lot of in so doing. There is no such little "lamp" as I have expected at that point in the new future, but of course nothing much can be done about the matter. Most of these Indians did at one time belong to the Russian Faith, and that with the stated fact, that the English Church has had in its keeping, for some years now, quite a sum of money belonging to the Indians that was collected for a new school, or Church, and that same has never been built. The matter is just mentioned for future reference, as going by experience gained on the Yukon River, many years ago; such affairs blow up sometimes into serious matters causing much trouble and expense. However after an interview with Bishop Couder, more information will be gained, which will be submitted in due course.
