Remarks by Constable. Ages given by the older indians are just approximate as most do not know their ages.

RELIGION. The indians of the Teslin District are at present greatly confused by the two Religious Denominations at Teslin. The Church of England has had a summer Mission at Teslin Lake for many years. In the summer of 1938 the Roman Catholics established at Teslin. This has greatly confused the indians and they are not very sure whether or not they are C of E or R.C.'s. When asking the indians on Census Taking as to their Church, such answers as this were received - That they went to both Churches. That they went to the Church that gave them the most work. The older people who had originated in Juneau Alaska, stated that they were of the Russian Catholics.

Future Census taken of this Band will show that religious Denomination as declared at present, will be much altered.

Stikine Indian Agency NOTES.

The Family of Telegraph JACK and son being Atlin Indians and numbered on that Band were told to move away or else their Trapground holdings might be questioned. Davey Johnson another Atlin Indian was found at Teslin - destitute. As he was and is a trouble indian - he was told to return to his affairs in Atlin. Harper Reed Indian Agent.
Also as Fathers Drean and Father Poulett were both in Teslin - having come up from Liard Post, B.C., they were spoken to over the wireless Phone (agent's Diary April 3, 1939). Father Poulett stated he was returning to Liard Post, but Father Drean stated he was remaining at Teslin Lake. At this time the R.C.M.P. Constable was instructed to "keep out" of any entanglements that might come about, and be most careful as to "taking sides" as to which Church Indians claimed they belonged to.

This Summer (1939) the long delayed Vaccination of the Teslin Lake Indians was undertaken, which same has been reported upon to the Indian Commissioner in Vancouver B.C. Whilst the vaccination was in progress all other matters were looked into, and school Affairs came in for their attention.

It was found that a Mr Frank M. Gilbert was in charge of the Day School. Upon looking over his equipment it was found woefully short of everything needed, even down to plain writing paper. Blackboard were missing, in fact it is a wonder how the fellow carried on. He stated that the R.C. Missions were actively engaged in trying to start a school of their own, and talk was going around the camp, which it was hard to control, or even discount. The Indians had been told that their Fathers in times gone by had been of The Russian Faith, and as the R.C. Missions were the same at that, they should return to their own Church.

Submitted herewith are some views; three small ones showing Bishop Geddes with some of his Indians, and some of which are now claimed back by the R.C. Mission. A view of the New R.C. Building which is part Church and general meeting room. A view of the present school Registrar, which of course contains the names of all the children of the area. As Bishop Geddes was on his way up the Yukon River to this point he was "wired" to meet your Agent in Atlin, which latter he kindly did.

Then the Indians were seen and their views obtained, especially the B.C. Band who have consistently backed up the present School. They were found divided, some stated that the Mission that paid the highest "wages" for any work done, would get their attendance. In fact the matter was looked on as a "joke" in which the Indians would come off best. One family stated that it depends who rings the "Bell" first; for they stated, that as soon as we hear that, we drop everything - and "go" for when God calls we go no matter where. These people meant what they said also.

Constable Robson (R.C.M.P.) was asked about the situation, and he stated that he had just taken the Census, and had put down what the Indians said they were, but he knew that it was not correct. A list of so-called Indians was obtained signed by Father Drean O.M.I. and is as follows:

James Fox Baptized 1903 Monica Fox Baptized 1903
Frank J. Morris - 1906 Louise James Morris -- 1908
Geo Jack Morris - 1916 Charlie Jack Morris -- 1916
Minnie Morris - 1916. Also "The Sidneys Only" were thought to be baptized some time ago.

Father Drean O.M.I. was called upon, and having had some words with him over Liard Post Matters, in which he was rather too high-handed (The Agness Shorty Case thrown back to LeJack without authority) some time ago, we quite understood each other, and he made no pretence over the matter, and it was understood he was there "to build up their Church Mission". He suggested an Industrial School, and was at once informed that, it was a matter entirely in the hands of the Department and that Teslin Lake was a very remote place at present for such an undertaking. He then suggested the Stikine River, between Telegraph Creek and the Coast, and was given the same reply, but that such a situation would be a far better location etc.

Submitted is a copy of the Census taken by the R.C.M.P. Constab and it is considered that most of those marked R.C., have been induced to say that when asked about the matter.
STIKINE AGENCY. TESLIN LAKE ANGLICAN DAY-SCHOOL Contiu 3.

Before leaving Teslin Lake an informal meeting was held with the B.C. Indians proper. They were told once more to go slow in this matter. That in such affairs the Indian Department has found that such fights only brings along much trouble for the Indians with their families. That today in their camp, several families were half for one Church and half for another, and that always a man and wife should be both the same. They agreed that it was a bad thing, and that they would go slow and talk the matter over good or the final decision to which church they would attend. The constable was once more requested to keep out of this affair as much as possible and that it would be far better for His Indian Agent from Dawson, or the Stikine Indian Agent, to finally hear and settle such a question.

And so the matter stood upon leaving Teslin Lake on the 18th of July 1939, as really nothing more could be done. However on the 22nd Bishop Geddes arrived in Atlin on his way to Teslin and a couple of hours was spent in his company. He stated that he had just visited Ottawa, and that some school supplies were promised him, but he would much appreciate the favour if the Department would grant him the list made up by the Teacher. This has been submitted under separate cover.

He then admitted that a Church-schoolhouse should have been constructed here this, but that he was going over there to start same up. He was told that the Indians generally were at his back, but they wanted a new building, and it was their due. We considered that a list of members should be obtained by him whilst over there, to somewhat settle this affair, and he promised to do this. He was told that Chief Billy Johnson with others had been informed that if they "Threw away the present school, after all they had received from that point for their children, perhaps they would never be allowed to come back again". Some paper school supplies that it had been possible to obtain by a passing plane from Telegraph Creek, was given to the Bishop to take over to his school, but their equipment is very low indeed.

It is regretted that it is nearly impossible to state how many Catholic children; and how many non-Catholic children, are attending this school, for as stated all the children of the community have been in attendance, and as also stated the families are split on the matter. Perhaps it would be as well to allow the matter to brew itself out for a time, and then have a meeting to finally decide who is who.

This Report has been submitted in all detail, so that a general idea can be arrived at, it is hoped, and which might prevent some further correspondence on the matter, as time and distance to this point is some consideration.

All of which Sir is most respectfully submitted, and it is hoped will meet with the approval of the Department.

I am,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

Re:- TESLIN LAKE. Y.T. Anglican Day-school.

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter dated July 31, in regard to the affairs of the above Day-school; which was received upon my return to this point, after visiting Teslin Lake.

So that there shall be no misunderstanding as to why the Stikine Indian Agent pays a visit to this point in the Yukon, it is mentioned that the Yukon - B.C. "Line" crosses Teslin Lake, west to east, at about 10 mile south of Teslin Lake R.C.M.P. Post. Therefore over 60 persons come up the Lake from the B.C. side of the "line," to trade and reside at the lake, our Reserve at this point. Moreover this crowd of B.C. Indians are the best that live around Teslin Post - so much so that the "Chief" Billy Johnson is a B.C. Indian, if such a difference can be used between various parts of this one lake; and the reason why he was so elected by all the Indians at this Post, was for the reason he was thought most capable.

During the time that Mr. Hawksley was Indian Agent for the Yukon little attention was given from that point to Teslin Lk., and an understanding came about that the Stikine Agent - having to visit Atlin - should also give attention to Teslin Lake. This was given and even the Day school visited and supplies allowed. Lately, however the R.C.M.P. Authorities have given more attention to Indian Affairs here, and the Stikine Agent's visitations have been more or less confined to his B.C. Indians and their trapping affairs.

Up to this present date, the only school that has been operating at Teslin Lake, has been the Anglican, or Church of England Day School, to which each summer a Teacher is sent up from "below." Enclosed is a photograph of the School Register showing such facts taken on my recent visit, as it was seen some trouble was brewing.

This is a pure Trapping Area, and all and every Family get out of this Post during the winters and have to do so for a living, therefore it was not common sense to keep a Teacher at this point over the winter months. During summer there is nothing for the youngsters to do but go to school, and this with a supply of school material given to the youngsters to take out into the bush in the Fall - amply meets with the requirements of school education. The youngsters must learn to trap, and this they do whilst out in their camps.

The following data is submitted in connection with the movement into Teslin Post of the R.C. Mission:

Agent's Diary April 5th 1938 reports he found land staked at Teslin Post on his winter inspection of that area.

Special Agent's Report on R.C. Affairs dated July 27th 1938 did not mention Teslin Post, as it is considered "outside" real Stikine Agency Affairs.

Agent did not visit Teslin Post summer of 1938, -no time.

Winter of 1936-7 Teslin was not visited, but Constb Robson of that Detachment (R.C.M.P.) did come over to Atlin, was seen (Agent's Diary March 8th 1938) and stated that the R.C.'s were going ahead.
Sir,

Re:- TESLIN LAKE, Y.T. Church of England, School.

I beg to submit a rather non-consequential Report on the known affairs of the above Summer Day School, in connection with the Indian children that attend same, from the Stikine Agency.

This Yukon Trading Post, to which the Indians of Teslin Lake, trade, was not visited last summer owing to lack of time to do so. The Boundary Line between the Yukon and British Columbia crosses East & West about 15 miles south of this Post, directly across the Lake, and so therefore there is a great mingling of all Indians during the summer months and at the above school all such Indian children attend. Hence again is seen the over-lapping of the Stikine Agency Affairs with that of the Yukon, regarding Indians and their family affairs. It happens that here the better class of Indians are from the B.C. side of the line, and no helper is ever requested from these families.

As this School is of the English Church Missions, and operating in the Yukon it is really out-side the care or attention of this Agency; but never-the-less when visiting that point, the school is always inspected and such help as can be afforded, offered.

The last Report on this school from this Agency is dated August 16th 1939, and was of a rather long description as to how matters stood at that point in regard to the starting up of the R.C.M.P. Mission at this Post. Since that time the R.C.M.P. Constable has been changed, and recently no reports have been received from that Detachment. It is expected that everything is going along correctly, otherwise some letters would have been received ere now.

During the expected Inspection of this Agency, next Summer by Mr Inspector Coleman of Vancouver B.C., it is hoped to pay this School a visit, and look into the welfare of our Indians at that location.

I am,

Sir,

Dear Sir:

Thank you for your letter of February 22nd, received today. I am sorry that my letter did not reach you sooner but I was unaware of your temporary residence in Atlin.

The school supplies for the Teslin Lake School were possibly dispatched in 1939 for Mr. Frank Gilbert made out the requisition form. I opened the shipment and used them last year.

While in Teslin I received no correspondence nor saw any on file suggesting that a signed list should be made out by those who wished their children to attend the school. I would have most certainly complied with such a request for all the parents were eager that their children receive schooling during the short summer months.

Last year Teslin was not the pleasant gathering place of friends which it used to be back in 1934. Suspicion and ill-feeling have been engendered among the natives so that families have been separated in a subtle way. I had hoped to have seen you in Teslin last summer for only by actual visitation could you sense the change in the communal atmosphere. I do hope that there will be a representative of the Church of England in Canada at Teslin when you and Inspector Coleman make your visit in the spring.

Enclosed is a list of the school children I taught last summer. There were thirty-four pupils on the register with an average attendance of 25.4 which is very good considering that the whole group was not in Teslin all the time. Some of the older boys also occasionally attended classes but were not put down in the book.

Thanking you for your appreciated kindness in the past

I remain,

Yours truly,

Re:- TESLIN LAKE, Y.T. - Church of England School.

Once again it is found necessary to bring the above matter to the notice of the Department for their further consideration and advice. In this regard it is respectfully requested that a letter on this subject, dated August 16, 1939, be used as a reference. In this letter is mentioned Father Dreen, once an Liard Post, and his connection with the return of an Indian girl at that point, from the Lejock school. Agness Sherry - who caused all the trouble we have since experienced from the Bronson TOM case recently. It is mentioned as Father Dreen is over progressive, and more mixed affairs may be expected from this quarter.

Submitted herewith is a letter received from Rev. Robt C.W. Ward, Missionary and Teacher at Teslin Lake for the above School. Also is attached a Requisition for some small school supplies, which same is thoroughly endorsed as necessary by this Office, on behalf of our B.C. Indian Children attending that school.

It will be seen that matters have not improved at all - which is exactly as expected, but which it seems cannot be avoided. However it is high time now to hold an investigation and somewhat settle the affair. Inspector Coleman on his visitation to this point could look into the matter and no doubt arrive at some arrangement. This would work in together with the proposed separation of the B.C. Indians from those of the Yukon proper.

The crux of the matter is, that the R.C. Missions are intending to establish their Mission at Teslin, and are practically using conjurement to establish their aims. They have in fact already accomplished much; Father Dreen is very clever.

It is considered that the above school, after all the years it has operated, under every friendly condition with all the Indian families of that location - should receive every consideration possible.

In the consideration of this subject, it might be borne in mind that to further advance the affairs of the R.C. Mission, those Authorities have requested a Boarding School on Tagish Lake, and not least a proposed WINTER (Bush) school at Johnston Town at the south end of Teslin Lake, which would take in all the B.C. Indians that live there; and who are at present the strongest supporters of the above Church of England School (summer).

Dear Sir,

Re. Teslin Lake School.

With reference to your letter of Nov. 6th 1941 concerning the above School, I should like to point out that our Church has operated this school as a seasonal Day School for a considerable number of years. Early in 1940 you informed me that no grant would be available for that School during the current year. We operated the School however without expecting a grant, and forwarded the return in the usual course. The return was sent back to us with the statement that no grant was available.

I find it difficult to understand the question in the last paragraph of your letter regarding the advisability of operating this School at the present time, in view of the fact that, if my information is correct, your Department has this year agreed to recognize a Roman Catholic Day School at Teslin Lake at least to the extent of agreeing to furnish them with School Supplies. I should also like to point out that as late as 1934 the Census returns of your Department list all the Indians at Teslin Lake as members of the Anglican Church. It does seem strange that you should question the advisability of the Anglican Church continuing a Day School that has been established for many years, and at a post that until very recently listed all the Indians as Anglicans, and at the same time agree to recognize, as soon as it is established, at that same post the school of the Roman Catholic Church.

Inasmuch as this School has operated continuously for many years past as a seasonal day school, no question of its re-opening arises at the present time.

Yours truly,

Stikine Indian Agency - July, 1942.

Teslin Lake.

Here there are two privately operated schools, one Anglican and the other Roman Catholic. The attendance appears to be fairly good at both and good work is being done, particularly in the Anglican school which has operated for several years now. The attendance at both schools is made up from Indians of both this Agency and the Yukon Territory. The teachers in both schools are clerics, neither of whom is paid by the Department for their services which incidentally is a departure from the procedure in small seasonal schools operated by the Agency. The quality of the tuition does not appear to be inferior to that in schools of this Agency either. Teslin Post, where the schools are operated is in the Yukon Territory and it is understood that a few supplies are obtained through the Indian Agent at Dawson, Y.T. More details concerning these schools will be given in a separate report covering the school situation at Teslin Post, to be submitted shortly. No regular day school reports are being submitted for these schools as they are private and in the Yukon Territory.

Dear Mr. Meek:

On my return from Victoria I received a letter from Mr. Gibben, authorizing the opening of a school at Teslin, with the proviso that there would be an assured regular attendance of seven white pupils, and that a satisfactory building be provided for a school. I assume that the latter is being furnished by your Department.

I may be censured for going ahead with the establishment of the school, but in any case I have offered the appointment as teacher at Teslin to Miss Joah Adams, whom you have met, no doubt, in Whitehorse. I have also ordered blackboards and all necessary supplies for the school, except desks. These supplies are being shipped to the teacher, c/o you, on the Princess Norah, leaving Vancouver August 28.

It seemed to me that something had to be done at once, although I was in doubt whether the requisite number of white pupils would be on hand. Forgive me if I place that responsibility on you. I know there are a number of half-breed children who would attend Teslin school if it were opened; besides, the Indian children there would give us an enrollment similar to that in other schools on the Highway.

Two months ago we ordered 75 desks for use in new schools or at Whitehorse. Mr. Warwick can inform you whether these are available. I am afraid that he cannot supply desks, as he had no reserve on hand when I was there in July. If desks are not on hand, possibly some could be borrowed from church schools.

I believe you will approve the action I have taken, and I know that you will do what you can to help.

Sincerely yours,

(signed) R. Huland,
Superintendent of schools.

P.S. I expect to visit Teslin between Sept. 9 and 12. I asked Miss Adams to open school on or after Sept. 7.

R.H.
Indian Affairs Branch,
OTTAWA,
Ontario.

Reference Teslin joint Day School, and my telegram of 31st ultimo and your reply today's date. This subject was first reported on in my letter of November 17, 1948, on which date I also sent you a telegram suggesting a day school for Teslin. There are not enough Indian children to warrant a day school, and neither are there quite enough white children at the present time to justify a full time teacher of the Yukon Territorial Government.

At the annual meeting of the Yukon Territorial Council at Dawson recently, an appropriation of $2,700.00 for a teacher's salary, and $100.00 for classroom supplies, was passed for Teslin. There are several day schools along the Alaska Highway, mainly for the benefit of road maintenance crews, and in at least one of these schools, Indians are being taught. These schools are paid for by the Yukon Government, with the Canadian Army furnishing schoolroom and teacherage. Mr. Huland no doubt thought that a similar arrangement could be effected with Indian Affairs Branch.

I plan to proceed with Mr. Huland and Miss Adams to Teslin on Thursday, Sept. 9th, when the school will be officially opened. The Anglican and Church of England seasonal schools have both very kindly offered to assist by lending any equipment needed until the Territorial School system can furnish same. This Branch has been asked to obtain and maintain school building and teacherage.

I shall take up your suggestion of purchase of house-store for school and teacherage with Mr. Huland. The teacherage is in excellent condition, store is suitable for school but needs lining on the inside. Rental of $25.00 for these two buildings considered extremely reasonable for the Yukon. It is very difficult to estimate number of white and Indian children likely to remain during the winter; but a further report will be submitted when more facts are known.

(R.J. Meek)

Colonel Neary:

Teslin Day School:
This now requires a new file as it has become a predominantly territorial non-denominational school.

Miss Adams is in the service of the Yukon Territorial Council — for how long I cannot say but if it depends on the regular attendance of seven non-Indians then we would be well advised not to purchase or lease that store. A monthly arrangement is likely to suffice, and will prevent our tenancy of an empty building.

Even timing the school should be deferred until its prospects of functioning are clearer than they are now.

The equipment which we can lend from nearby season schools may not be needed long in this combined school.

I would suppose Mr. Holland is confident that he can maintain the attendance. These pupils are going to cost at least $300 each per annum before we (and I feel it is I.R.) start buying wood.

If Mr. Controller Gibbon cuts off financial assistance we could scarcely retain Miss Adams there unless we are prepared to subsidize parents who would otherwise be miles away.

The denominational school pattern is not favored in the Yukon and Mr. Musk has not had to give much attention to denominational activities. This are, however, becoming more obvious and they could blight this combined project before it gets well started.

The money might have been better used if they sent the few children concerned to Lee's school.

C.A.T. Clark

Dear Sir:

With regard to the joint opening of a school at Teslin by the Department of Indian Affairs and the Yukon Territorial Government, I would like to inform you of the agreement the Territorial Government has with the Canadian Army respecting the operation of schools along the Alaska Highway.

The Army agrees to furnish the school building, fuel, and light, as well as accommodation for the teacher, with light and fuel provided. Whenever possible, the teacher's residence should be in a building separate from the school building.

The Territorial Government agrees to pay the teacher's salary, to furnish desks and classroom supplies, including blackboards.

The system has worked very well during the past three years, when we first opened the Highway schools.

Mr. Gibben, Controller, Yukon Territory, has intimated that the Department of Indian Affairs agrees to work on the same basis as the Canadian Army in the operation of the school at Teslin.

We feel fortunate in securing the services of Miss Joan Adams, a very superior type of teacher, at Teslin School. We can assure you that she will have the full support of the Territorial Government at all times. We feel sure that the Department of Indian Affairs will co-operate in like manner.

Yours faithfully,

R. Hulland,
Superintendent of Schools.

OTTAWA, Ontario.

October 16, 1948.

Reference the opening of a joint Territorial Government-Indian Affairs day school at Teslin, Y.T. On September 10th I proceeded to Teslin with R. Holland, Yukon School Inspector, and Miss Joan Adams, school teacher. Arrangements were made to make alterations to rented house for use as a school room. It is suitable for the purpose. Permission was obtained from Indian Health Services for Miss Adams to live temporarily at the nursing station at Teslin. There is no Public Health Nurse now working along the Alaska Highway.

Supplies have now come forward to Miss Adams. My latest information is that nine children are attending. Proportion of whites and Indians not known. It is possible that more Indians would attend if there was any place for them to stay at Teslin. The entire community is nomadic, living in well-built log cabins during the summer and, with the exception of three or four elderly people, moving out to their trap-lines in the winter.

Fuel for school has been ordered, accounts will be submitted later. The school is equipped with electric lights supplied by the R.C.I.F. Report of Mr. Holland, dated 4th instant, is attached hereto.

P.J. Meek

My dear Bishop Sovereign:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of July 12 concerning the proposed erection of an Indian Residential School at Teslin, Y.T.

While tenders have been called for the erection of this building, no decision has as yet been reached with respect to the awarding of a contract. You can rest assured that the Department does not propose to spend seven hundred thousand dollars or anything approaching such an amount for the erection of this school.

We are quite aware of the work that has been done by your Church in the Southern Yukon. The 1944 census of the Indians in Canada shows that there are some 307 Indians of the Roman Catholic faith in the Yukon. These are mainly situated at Burwash Landing, Kelly Lake, Frances Lake, Watson Lake and Teslin. In addition to the children of these Indians, we had of course planned to provide for the children of the northeast corner of British Columbia. There are some 450 Catholic Indians in this region, including 96 in the Atlin-Teslin area, 75 at Nelson Creek, 42 in the Liard-Frances Lake area, 60 in the Nelson River district and 184 at Tahltan. There are also Indian children in the Peace River district down the Alaska highway as far as Prophet River, who require institutional care.
Before a decision was reached to erect this school, two separate educational surveys were carried out. Both were in agreement that such an institution was necessary.

With regard to the Teslin Bay School, our records show that for many years we have paid an amount towards the salary of your seasonal school teacher, usually a theological student. We have also sent in school supplies. Only in 1933 were we unable to make such payments. For many years these teachers were nominated by the late Bishop Geddes. A joint school is now being operated at Teslin in co-operation with the Yukon Territorial Council. The teacher, Miss Joan Adams, is an Anglican.

We are aware of the condition of the buildings at the Whitefish Lake Church of England Residential School and in a recent letter to Archbishop Kingston I mentioned that we had assured your officials that we were prepared to erect a day school for the Anglican children at this point. I presume from your letter that your recommendation is for the erection of another residential school there.

Training

I am pleased to say the Joint School at Teslin is an outstanding success and the Yukon Territorial Government is anxious to continue operations. Superintendent of Schools, R. Holland, included a splendid tribute to the teacher, Miss J. Adams, in his annual report. He concludes with the following:

"The school at Teslin is unique in that it is the only school in Yukon Territory where both white and Indian children are in attendance. I am convinced that the Department of Indian Affairs will realize the necessity of improving facilities for pupils and the teacher."

This suggestion has been acted upon and correspondence is under way concerning a new school building and teaching staff.

A sports meeting was held at Carcross under the direction of Clerk H.J. MacDonald, on June 10th, when all pupils of Whitehorse and Carcross Indian Schools and Teslin Joint School attended. Each contest was enthusiastically fought for and Carcross emerged the winner, being donated the Taylor and Drury Cup by Mr. W.L. Drury. This cup is for annual competition.

Some excellent films were shown to the Indian schools of Southern Yukon by R.C.M.P. during the quarter. While it may be unfair to single out a particular person, I would like to draw attention to the outstanding interest and sympathetic manner in which Const. B.E. Harrison, Reg. No. 13800, Whitehorse Sub-Division, R.C.M.P., has co-operated with this office in handling, amongst other things, athletic meets and film showings.

As shown in my report for Quarter ending September 30th, 1943, Fort Selkirk School, though officially closed, continued under Church of England auspices, teaching for 63 days during the present quarter with an average daily attendance of 5.36.

A teacher has not yet been nominated for Old Crow and I am afraid the season is getting very late. Due to tough conditions there, the post demands a teacher (preferably a married couple) of outstanding qualities. It is one place I am anxious to see with a school.

I spent a day or two at Vancouver in company with Mr. R.F. Devey, Inspector of Indian Schools for B.C. Mr. Devey was most considerate and helpful regarding some of our problems. If and when he next visits Stikine Agency he has kindly agreed to make a courtesy inspection of some of our more accessible schools. I have wondered if a working arrangement could be made with Mr. Holland, Yukon Territory School Superintendent to give a complete annual inspection to Indian Affairs schools in the Yukon while on Territorial inspections.
Proposed new buildings for Teslin (Joint) Day School:

Mr. Supt. Meek has not been able to fix a firm figure for this project which he is suggesting be included in the 1950-51 estimates. Consideration has been given to the structures and costs at Bighorn and Alexis. Possibly the best approximation will be arrived at by studying Mr. Supt. Knapp's estimate for the building project at Upper Hay River, which is a modification of Alexis. Requisitions from Mr. Knapp are being processed now. His letter of November 7 deals with such matters as trucking and storage which also will arise at Teslin.

No doubt the interest of Yukon Territory at this point will increase with the growing non-Indian population of religious denominations other than Roman Catholic, but the disposal of Indian pupils at this point remains to be seen after projected construction of accommodation to be conducted under denominational auspices is in operation.

Father Plourde of the Oblate Commission has objected to your letter of December 27, sent to Father Drean at Tealin, concerning the Jule children.

You are of course aware of those sections of the Indian School Act with regard to the sending of a Catholic child only to a Catholic school and a Protestant child only to a Protestant school.

However, a ruling from the Department of Justice in 1922 permits the father to decide whether he wishes his children to a school of another denomination. If Mr. Jule wishes to have his children continue to attend the Tealin Joint School, you should secure from him an affidavit certifying that he wishes his children continue to attend this school.

Rev Sir:

I have received your letter of the 21st regarding suspension of Family Allowances to Effie and Kitty Jule. This was done pursuant to the Family Allowances Act which states that if a child is absent for more than five days without reasonable excuse, Family Allowances must be suspended. Miss Clancy tells me she warned the children who were absent concerning this. We had no alternative but to suspend Allowances. I might add that we were instructed on this policy by C.A.F. Clark who visited here some two months ago.

The Teslin School is known as a Joint School, and is not conducted under religious auspices, but directly under the supervision of the Territorial Government. Indian Affairs provide the school and teacherage and certain classroom material. It is designed to accommodate Indians and whites who are resident in Teslin.

My understanding of Summer or Seasonal Schools is that they are for children who cannot attend day school by reason of being with their parents on the trap-line. They are, as you point out, entirely under religious supervision. A much greater latitude is given to these schools for obvious reasons. The Indian Act does not state that they are obliged to attend Summer School when they have already attended Lay School. However, as you have written to Col. Neary I feel he will issue a ruling on this matter for future guidance.

Yours truly,

(R.J. Meek)
Superintendent
Teslin Joint School

As you are aware, the above school is for Indian and white children of Teslin. In addition there is a Roman Catholic Seasonal School for those children unable to attend the Joint School through absence on trap-lines.

The Monthly Attendance Report for November showed the attendance of Effie and Kitty Jule, and Peter Sydney as being unsatisfactory and without reasonable excuse. I visited Teslin on December 9th and explained the requirements of the Family Allowances Act to the parents of the children. Results did not improve and this office recommended to Director of Family Allowances, suspension of payments to the two families concerned.

I received a letter from Fr. Dream O.M.I. on Dec. 27th, stating that, as the Jule girls were Roman Catholic, they must attend the Roman Catholic summer school. I replied to him the same date as per copy attached.

Miss Clancy, teacher at Teslin, now advises that the Jule family still remain away from school. She states: "The Jules have not returned to school since Christmas. I have heard that they consider Father Dream's summer school to be sufficient for their educational needs, so they are quitting this school. Is there any way you could stop Father Dream from holding this school? The Jules are quite clever youngsters but it is difficult to teach them when they come so irregularly."

Will you please advise regarding the matter of attending seasonal school and day school, and if my interpretation of the Family Allowance Act is correct.

(R.J. Meek)

SUPERINTENDENT OF EDUCATION

Teslin Lake Joint School

Reference is to your query regarding the salary of the teacher.

It appears that no action is necessary by this Department concerning the salary paid to this teacher (presently Miss Clancy) as she is a full-time employee of the Yukon Territorial school system.

You have seen the photographs of this school and my comments thereon, and you have approved the suggestion to defer construction at this point until the possible developments at Teslin appear more clearly.

This development may include the provision of facilities for children of the R.C.A.F. personnel. In that event the Yukon Government and the Department of National Defence might be influenced to set up a larger establishment suited to the needs of an enlarged White population. Provision for married quarters is already being made at the Watson Lake air station and Teslin is, I understand, next on the list for this enlargement.

In his letter of October 4, the Superintendent of Yukon schools outlines the agreement under which these joint schools are operated. Our Department is somewhat in...
arrears in providing the school building. An associated Department is, however, providing accommodation for the teacher. Perhaps we should ask Mr. Superintendent Meek whether we are providing fuel for the school and the residence. Light for the school is supplied by the airport electricity plant.

The children present said that they had seen Peter Symes in the area on the previous day. His boy and the two Peters children are expected by Rev. H. Kirnne to attend the seasonal school when the territorial term closes next winter. The father of the Peters children says the Peters children will be sent to a residential school at Lower Post.

The white pupils attending are not, in any case, children of service personnel at the airport. The provision of married quarters at the airport or a re-location of Highway Headquarters camp, together with the opening of a Roman Catholic residential school, would reduce the Indian enrollment at this school to a very minor fraction of the whole. I have accordingly requested Mr. Sipt. Muck, to postpone further action.
To erect the proposed new small log school as it might become inadequate or unsuitable to local needs in a very short time. Something better will likely be required.

The children told me that Teslin Lake is already warm enough for them to go "swimming" but that they don't know much about swimming. I told them that we would try to supply literature on the subject. Teslin Lake is about ninety miles long and there is still ice at the northern end. On the preceding Sunday I saw plains land and lake off, people catching fish, children bathing, and Indians drawing water for drinking and washing. It has a high scenic value, too, and mosquitoes and flies are less troublesome than elsewhere.

Right Reverend Sir:

I have to inform Your Lordship that, owing to recent orders for a reduction in our Appropriation, it has been found necessary to discontinue the grant which is provided towards teachers' salaries at a number of our Indian day schools during the current year. I have therefore to inform you that the Department will be unable to provide any grant towards the salary of the teachers at the following schools conducted under your auspices in the Yukon territory, viz.:

Teslin Lake,
Whitehorse,
Rampart House,
Champagne Landing.

The only day schools in the Yukon territory for which the Department can provide a grant for teachers' salaries are Moosehide and Selkirk. Mr. Superintendent Hawksley is being informed accordingly.

I have the honour to be,

Right Reverend Sir,

For your information, Mr. Holland, Superintendent of Schools, for the Yukon Territory, in his annual report to the Commissioner of the Territory, includes the following:

"Miss Adams has done very good work in organizing the school for Indian and white pupils at Teslin. The school building is inadequate, lighting is poor, and sanitation unsatisfactory. If the school is to be continued a new school should be erected and an apartment for the teacher provided. At present the teacher is living in the Public Health Nurse's residence.

"The school at Teslin is unique, in that it is the only school in Yukon Territory where both white and Indian children are in attendance. I am convinced that the Department of Indian Affairs will realize the necessity of improving facilities for pupils and the teacher."

Due to the difficulties in building at Teslin, would it be possible to erect a log school building? This
would not only give employment to the Indians but would also be much cheaper to erect. Mr. Indian Superintendent Robertson is now erecting such a school on the Alexis Reserve and Major Clark has commented very favourably upon the design. Indian Affairs Branch,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

Your letter of 6th instant, file 930-5 (E), concerning the Teslin Joint School. The building of a Joint Day School, with teacherage, is recommended. Your suggestion of using native logs is feasible, in fact, I would prefer it to using Outside materials. It would have the added advantage, as you point out, of being cheaper to construct, and would be a source of employment to local Indians.

I would recommend the use of oil heat in the school to avoid extremes in temperature during winter time. There are one or two local carpenters well skilled in the building of log houses and structures.

The O.C. R.C.A.F. informs me there are four married quarters at Teslin, and a total personnel of about nine. Department of Transport employ five men permanently. There are also a number of civilian personnel on the airbase. Miss Adams, teacher, suggests a schoolroom designed for 30 pupils. While this figure may not be reached for a few years, it is quite within the limit of possibility. A teacherage is necessary, present arrangements are temporary, as Miss Adams has been living in the Nursing Station, Indian Health Services.

I have conferred with Crown Lands Agent W.M. Emery, who suggest that two lots be requested for the use of a school. I shall take up this matter further and in due course application for land will be made through the usual channels.

Dear Mr. Hawksley,

With reference to Rampart House, the difficulties are somewhat similar. The Church of England has now a native clergyman, the Rev Amos Njootli in charge of the Mission. He does all he can in teaching the Indians to read and write in their own tongue, and with considerable success. He travels with the Indians to their hunting grounds, and holds school regularly. He does not, however, teach the English language, and I know it would be a great advantage if we could have a regular teacher in English for the Indian children. Here again financial difficulties have been in the way. The Indians at Rampart House spend most of their time in hunting and trapping and are scattered all over the country. For a short time some of them gather together at one place, and during this period school could be held, but when the parents go off to hunt again, their children must accompany them, unless someone is prepared to keep them, and this would require a boarding school of some kind. The government grant for day schools is now given according to the number of days school is held. I am afraid under the circumstances at Rampart House, the grant would go only a very small way towards the expense of keeping a teacher. Because of the remoteness of the place it would be impossible for a man to come and go very frequently, and he would have to settle down for the year. The cost of salary and travelling expense would be considerable, and thus again financial difficulties are hard to overcome. However, I hope we may be able to do something in the course of time to pro-

REPORT OF ROSS RIVER BAND OF INDIANS.

Near the headwaters of the Pelly River are two trading posts, one belonging to Taylor Drury & Co and the other to Mr J. Cote. Around these posts are gathered some 200 Indians, all emigrants from the Mackenzie River and principally from Fort Norman. They belong to the Slavi tribe and speak a distinct language to the Indians of the Yukon. Having spent six years among the Slavis I am acquainted with their language.

The traders report them as being a fairly industrious people and comparatively healthy. During the past year one of the traders paid them over $3,000.00 for the furs they brought to him and no doubt the other firm paid them quite as much if not more, they are a larger firm and carry a bigger stock.

Game is plentiful in the district, there is no market for their meat very few white people are in this vicinity. Both white fish and salmon are caught in the lakes and rivers but the salmon are not plentiful.

There is no day school but one of the members of the band, a man trained by myself years ago, holds school in the native tongue, most of the younger members of the band can read and write in their own tongue. He also conducts religious services. He is not permanently stationed at Ross River but travels about with the band and conducts school when not on hunting expeditions.

They are not settled in log cabins but live in tents and tepees.

A supply of simple medicines was given to Mr Cote for the benefit of the Indians. In cases of sickness and destitution relief is given in the way of provisions by Cote from the fund provided by the Department to meet such cases.

No attempt at farming has been made by any of the band as they are constantly on the move.

Have made arrangements with the trader to send in reports of births and deaths. He will have no difficulty in getting accurate statistics.
REPORT OF ROSS RIVER BAND OF INDIANS (Cont)

I was unable to arrange a visit to this band the small steamer that I was to have gone by sailed some days earlier than at first planned so that when I reached Selkirk she was already gone. On my second trip up the Yukon I found the boat at the foot of the rapids unable to get through, she was held up there for two weeks. I hope to visit them next spring when navigation re-opens.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Supt of Indians.

Sir:

The Bishop of Yukon has notified me that the following students have been sent to the undermentioned places and will conduct Indian day schools while in residence.

Mr. O.W.R. Hughes, Selkirk,
Mr. M.C. Humphrey, Carmacks
Mr. — Semple, Tealin Lake.
Mr. W.I.B. Stringer, Champagne.

The first three are students from the Anglican College, Vancouver B.C., the other is a son of the Bishop, he is from Toronto University and has completed his fourth year in medical work.

The Bishop also suggests that a supply of school material be sent to Mary Martin, daughter of Rev. John Martin (native clergyman stationed at Ross River). Mary is an ex-pupil of the Hay River Indian Residential School. I do not know anything of her qualifications as a teacher and am in doubt as to whether school material should be supplied until she is accepted as a teacher by the Department. Kindly advise.

Your obedient servant,

John Hawksley,
Indian Superintendent.

Ottawa, June 26th, 1931.

Sir,

In reply to your letter of the 2nd instant, I beg to say that it is noted that seasonal schools will be conducted this summer in the Yukon, as follows:

Selkirk - Mr. O.W.R. Hughes.
Carmacks - Mr. M.C. Humphrey.
Teslin Lake - Mr. Semple.
Champagne Landing - Mr. W.I.B. Stringer.
Ross River - Miss Mary Martin.

From the information given in your letter, it appears that all of the above are competent of taking charge of the schools mentioned, with the possible exception of Miss Martin. No doubt, you can make some further inquiries regarding her and, if the information you receive is satisfactory, you may forward a small supply of school material consisting of articles that are absolutely necessary.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie.
Secretary.

John Hawksley, Esq.,
Indian Superintendent,
Dawson, Y. T.
Sir:

I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt of your letter dated June 26th, file No. 166-14-1, in reference to the seasonal Indian day schools in the Yukon Agency.

In reply I beg to say that in the case of the school at Selkirk it will be kept in operation during the whole of the coming school year. Mr. O.W.R. Hughes having completed his course at the Anglican Theological College, Vancouver, B.C., taking the prize for reading, was ordained on July 4th, and appointed to the charge of Selkirk and instructed by the Bishop to teach and keep the school open regularly in accordance with the requirements of the Department.

Carmacks, Teslin Lake and Champagne Landing will be seasonal schools.

A small supply of school material has been sent to Mary Martin at Ross River. Until further proof of her ability to teach is forthcoming I do not see my way clear to recommend a grant for this school. No record of the number of pupils attending has been received at this office.

Your obedient servant,

John Hawksley
Indian Superintendent.

A.F. Mackenzie, Esq.
Secretary.
Department of Indian Affairs.

Sir:

The enclosed day school returns of attendance at the Ross River Indian day school were sent in by the Bishop of Yukon, Dr A.H. Sovereign, who expresses a hope that the Department will be disposed to give the matter favorable consideration and allow a grant.

It will be noted that the Bishop has, on the return form, made a note regarding the teacher, Mary Martin. The girl is a full native she has been taught by her father, Rev John Martin. She has not attended any Residential School, she is bright and energetic but her English is rather crude, I called the Bishop's attention to this also to the requirement of the Department that teachers must be competent to teach English correctly.

The Bishop says that he does not expect that the Department would be willing to make a grant equivalent to what would be paid to a white teacher but hopes that some small grant will be made for the work that has been done.

Your obedient servant,

John Hawksley,
Indian Superintendent.

Sir,

I beg to submit the following report in regard to the Indians of the Yukon Agency and conditions as found by me on my recent inspection tour of the Agency. During this inspection trip all points of the Agency were visited with the exception of the Francis Lake district, and conditions were found to be improved over last year.

x x x x

At Ross River practically all the Indians were in the Village. A fair fur catch is reported here, but as the Indians of this district dispose of their fur at several widely scattered trading posts it is practically impossible to get any idea as to the amount of fur caught during the season, however I received no complaints and I could see an improvement in these Indians from my visit last year. It is unfortunate that the day school is closed at this point as there are several children of school age who are getting no education.

x x x x

Your obedient servant,

G. Binning

General Report of the Ross River School

During the month of March 1931 school was opened 2½ hours daily for 24 days.

During the months of April opened for 13 days no school was held in the month of May when there is no children. During the months of June and July I had school open both in the morning and in the afternoon when the attendance was much larger.

Dear Mr. Hawksley,

In conversation with you the other day you stated that the Educational Secretary of the Indian Department had intimated that the holding of Lay Schools at Ross River and Carmacks was of a spasmodic character and it was doubtful if the results obtained warranted the expenditure, and you suggest that I should give an expression of opinion on this matter.

I wish to explain to the Department the local conditions with reference to these and other Indian Lay Schools in Yukon. The Indians make a living wholly by hunting, trapping and fishing—while a few are employed in cutting wood along the river or as helpers on steamboats in Summer. In some cases they have to travel from place to place in order to make a living. Besides it is generally considered unwise to encourage the Indians to stay around the trading posts or missions for any length of time unless they have some useful occupation in the neighborhood. As a rule the Indians come in to the various centres at certain times of the year chiefly during the Spring and early Summer. At such periods the children are available for school and we have tried to take advantage of the presence of the children to hold day schools. For the greater part of the year there are no children, or at least very few at these centres. The Indians are scattered generally, and as a rule only a family or two are found in one place.

A few years ago we had a permanent missionary at Carmacks and Little Salmon and he was able to hold school for a few weeks at a time. He found it was impossible to hold school during certain periods of the year because there were no children to attend. Mr. Wilkinson was stationed for a time at Little Salmon last Summer and had a very good attendance of twenty to twenty-five children for a week and they were making good progress when suddenly the Indians all moved away into the hills. They were right out of food and had to go out to hunt or they would starve. In a short time the whole camp was deserted.

For the last few years College students have been employed as teachers and they have endeavored to take full advantage of that period in the Spring when most of the Indians gather at the various centres. It is hoped that a permanent man may be secured.
before long who will visit several centres, but even then it will be difficult to hold school much more regularly than under the present arrangements.

The grant from the Indian Department is given only for the actual number of days during which school is held. Now some one must be responsible for the salaries of the men during the long periods when it is impossible to hold school and therefore impossible for him to earn any grant from the Indian Department. If an annual grant were given towards the teachers salary, the Indian Department would in this way assume a proportion of the risk. The number of the Indians in some of the localities is rather small and it seems too much to expect that a man should spend all his time for one small band.

I do not know in what way the work could be better done taking everything into consideration. Even if the children got only a months teaching at a time, it is better than nothing, and we simply have to do the best we can for these Indians.

I shall be glad to co-operate with the Indian Department in every way possible and shall be glad of any suggestions by which the schools could be made more efficient.

I remain,

Yours sincerely,

Isaac O. Yukon.

Sir,— referring to your letter dated Dec 15th, 1924.

In reference to the grant for the Carmacks and Ross River day schools, I beg to say that as requested I have taken the matter up with the Bishop of Yukon who has sent me the enclosed report.

For several years past the Bishop has been bringing in students from Toronto and Saskatoon to work for two or three of the summer months in the vacant missions and to teach Indian day schools whenever possible. This is rather a costly procedure and it is somewhat doubtful whether the experiment justifies the expense entailed on the Bishop's funds. The Bishop looks to the Department's grant given for the number of days that the schools are in operation to help to defray the salaries and travelling expenses of these students.

One point of view is that if these students did not teach the Indian children when the opportunity arises they would get nothing in the way of education.

Another point is that such spasmodic and intermittent teaching is not likely to be very effective. Two weeks teaching in a year with no effort on the part of the pupil to keep up what he has been taught has a tendency to become lost so that when the pupil returns to the school again in the summer the work has to be done all over again. It may be said that it is doubtful whether any real progress is made. There may be and are isolated cases where a pupil learns to read and write but these are not numerous. However, it is the best that can be done under the circumstances.
In this large territory where the Indians are so widely scattered in small bands.

If it were possible for the Bishop to obtain the services of a permanent missionary with headquarters at Carmacks, one who is both willing and able to travel from place to place when the Indians are gathered there and do what teaching he could as long as the Indians stayed around, it is quite possible that the results would be greater.

I would like to add that I am satisfied that the Bishop is very anxious to do all he possibly can for the Indians though it has a heavy drain on his available resources. I would therefore recommend that the grant usually given for the number of days that these occasional Indian schools are in operation be continued if at all possible.

Your obedient servant,

John Hawksley,
Indian Superintendent.

Dear Mr. Hawksley,

Following up my letter to you of Jan. 31st last inasmuch as the question has been raised by your Department as to whether they were justified in making grants to certain Day Schools in Yukon which are open only for a short time each year.

I wish to draw your attention again to some of the difficulties with which we have to contend in carrying on these schools. Take for example Teslin School— for the last two Summer Mr. Wilkinson a University graduate has gone to Teslin chiefly for the purpose of teaching Indian Day School. On both occasions he went as early as possible and remained till the Indians were moving away to their hunting grounds. In 1923 he was able to hold school thirty-eight days and in 1924 school was held for thirty days. During that period school was held both afternoons and evenings. The children attended pretty regularly and were anxious to learn and consequently made good progress. Mr. Wilkinson did not spare himself and devoted his whole time to the Indians. After school hours, he engaged in healthy outdoor games with the Indian children such as would develop the Indian boys and girls both physically and socially. In his report for 1924 he states that he noticed the children retained a good deal of the teaching given them in 1923.

The short Summer period is the only time that the Indians are assembled together, and unless we take advantage of this season to hold school it is difficult to do much otherwise in the way of education. This whole tribe is above the average in intelligence, and the children are brighter and keener than most Indian children in Yukon. Moreover some of the children continue their studies to some extent out in the woods. I know also that the schooling given to the children encourage some of them even after they grow older to continue on in their studies. The result is shown by the fact that generally as a result of the start they receive at schools quite a number of Indians in different parts of the Territory are able to write letters and read a little, and also work out arithmetical problems such as are necessary in trading etc.

These small schools seem to be well worth while, and I think the expenditure is warranted even though the cost may seem fairly high.
In Mr. Wilkinson's case I know a part of his time was spent in missionary work and a portion of his expenses should be charged to other than school work. The travelling expenses alone were considerable. For example it cost $95.00 to get from Whitehorse to Teslin and return besides the other travelling expenses. After a careful calculation I have charged $350.00 as the proportion of cost to be assigned to Mr. Wilkinson's school work at Teslin. Your Department has made a grant of $90.00- the per diem grant being even smaller than usual. I think the Indian Department might easily increase this and other grants to Indian Day Schools.

If you Department had to carry on these schools, you would have a good deal of worry and trouble in engaging workers besides the much heavier cost entailed. At present I take all the risk regarding the number of days in which school can be held, but the expense is practically the same whether we are able to hold school for a shorter or longer period, while the Department gives remuneration only for the actual number of days during which school is held irrespective of what it really costs.

Probably the plan of making a per diem grant is as good as any but a larger grant would be more equitable considering the cost of operating such schools, and I wish to ask the Department to increase the grants of different schools which can be kept open only for a short period each year.

I remain,

Yours sincerely,

Right Reverend Sir,

The Department is in receipt of a return prepared by Miss Mary Martin, in connection with a school she conducted for the Indians at Mayo Village between August 12th, 1935, and March 31st, 1936. The return shows that there were only a few children present on any one day.

As far as we can find, no authority was given by the Department to conduct a school at this point and I think you will agree that an allowance should only be made for seasonal schools when such schools have been recommended by yourself.

It is impossible for the Department to provide funds if we admit the principle of allowing a teacher to open a school wherever and whenever she pleases. No payment is, therefore, being made to Miss Martin.

I have the honour to be,

Right Reverend Sir,

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,

Sir:—

I have the honor to enclose herewith returns of attendance at the Rampart House and Old Grow River Indian Day School for the quarters ending March 31st, 1925 and March 31st, 1926. Teacher Miss Maggie Fredson, an ex-pupil of the Carcross Indian Residential School.

These returns have been sent in by the Bishop of Yukon who recently visited the above place. Having no regular forms with him, he made the records from the school register and obtained the teacher's signature.

Regarding the returns for the March quarter 1925 the Bishop states that owing to the absence of the Rev G.H. Moody the teacher did not send them in. I find, on reference to my files, that the last returns for this school were mailed to the Department in August 1925; they covered the quarters ending September 30th, and December 31st, 1924.

This school is now being taught by the Rev A McCullum who took charge last July. Owing to there being no regular mail service to Rampart House the returns can only be sent in as opportunity offers.

The Bishop hopes that the Department will give the usual grant for the two quarters during which Miss Fredson taught the school.

Sir:-

I have the honor to enclose herewith the returns of an Indian Day School that has been held at Old Crow River. This is the first intimation I have had of the existence of this school. I am also enclosing a copy of a letter sent to me by the Bishop of Yukon which speaks for itself.

A small band of Indians have, for some years past, made Old Crow River their central place and have built some cabins there, a trading post has also been opened at the village.

Regarding Murdo Baalam I cannot say much as to his qualifications but the Rev J. Davies met him some time ago when on a visit to Rampart House, he speaks very highly of him. I am unable to give the number of the band located there.

Judging from the Bishop of Yukon's letter it would appear that the school would only be open periodically.

If the Department take any action in this matter may I ask that notification be sent at the earliest convenience as the season is so short for getting anything up there.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Superintendent.
Old Crow River,
June 19th, 1917

My dear Mr Hawksley:

Murdo Baalam, a graduate of the Hay River School, has been teaching school for the last three months at Old Crow River village. He is making out the returns for this quarter and will enclose them in this to you. He has done well and has a very creditable school even without any facilities. It might be considered an outstation of Rampart House School and as such I shall be glad if you will send this return in and see if something can be done in allowing a grant for this school, when Murdo is at Rampart House he helps Jacob Njootli with the school. Jacob will send in his returns separately.

I shall be glad if you can supply Murdo with say 2 dozen slates and a dozen or so of part one phonic primer and some slate pencils and some sort of a map. I gave him one of the roller lesson series and that will help. Any other books would be acceptable such as an arithmetic, Geography, Copy Books or perhaps Scribblers and pencils.

Old Crow is sixty miles above Rampart House.

Yours sincerely,

(Signed) Isaac O. Yukon.

WAG:GRH
OLD CROW

There are about 200 Indians in this district, most of whom were in the village at the time of my visit. The Old Crow flats are famous for the large number of muskrats trapped there, but the last two years the catch has been very poor, however it is hoped that the next season will be a better one. There is very little other fur found in the district so that it makes it very hard on the Indians when the muskrat trapping is poor. Caribou has been very scarce in this district during the past year and the Indians have had to go far afield for meat. This is the heaviest village in the Yukon in regard to relief, there being 16 people drawing rations monthly. There is no day school in Old Crow although there are about 75 children in the district. 40 of whom are of school age. The health of the Old Crow Indians is poor, and there is no medical attention nearer than Fort Yukon, Alaska, except the aid which is rendered by the R.C.M.P. Police detachment at Old Crow. The children all look sickly, in fact the children here are the poorest class I have seen, all appear to be infected from Tuberculosis, and no steps are being taken to improve their health. I would suggest for the consideration of the Department that a trained nurse who could teach school should be sent in to Old Crow during the summer, so that something could be done for the children. If this could be done she could perhaps instill some idea of cleanliness into the heads of the women, who in turn would then be able to look after their children in a better manner. As already stated the children of this place are the poorest I have seen and something should be done to try and improve their general condition of health. The village was found in fair condition, and the Chief and councillors were seen and no complaints received.
August 20th, 1935.

Memorandum:

Mr. SUTHERLAND:

In the Mounted Police report on the Yukon you will see a recommendation that the Department establish a summer school at Old Crow to be carried on by a nurse teacher. It seems to me that if anything of this kind is contemplated the worker should be in the district the whole year. The Church of England used to have a missionary in this area. I do not know whether they now have or how strong their interest is. The maintenance of a worker in this area would be fairly expensive, and if you think well of this suggestion I wonder if we could get together on some such basis as the salary of the worker being found from the Medical Appropriation and her maintenance from the Vote for Education. This is a suggestion on which your comment might be useful in submitting the matter to the Deputy Superintendent General.

Director of Medical Services.
October 25th, 1936.

Memorandum:

DOCTOR MCGILL

When Inspector Binning, R.C.M.P., Acting Superintendent of our Department in the Yukon, visited Old Crow last summer, he made a rather disturbing report of health conditions there. Knowing that the Church of England had some missionary activities in the district, we consulted the Bishop of the Yukon as to what suggestion he might have. He has replied that his Church has a native missionary and that he hopes the Department may station a health worker and school teacher at this very remote point.

From this place the only outlet is Fort Yukon in Alaska and we have had a good many patients in the hospital at that place, some at least of whom have appeared to us as suitable for home treatment if there was anybody at Old Crow to look after them. There does not appear to be any school there and there should be about forty children of school age. Mr. Sutherland and I have agreed to recommend the stationing of a nurse, who has also been a school teacher, at Old Crow. We do not want to fix the position as permanent and our suggestion is to ask the Bishop of the Yukon to nominate a suitable person for this post, to put not only the person but the work on probation for one year and judge thereafter whether it is profitable to continue. In such a remote place the minimum salary of a nurse should be $1200. per annum and she should have her maintenance in addition. I would make it a condition with the Bishop that the nurse should receive the whole of the salary without any such deductions as are sometimes made. The cost would be $1800. per annum, of which Mr. Sutherland agrees to contribute $600. from the schools fund. As this will have to be provided for in the Estimates we should appreciate your direction.

The cost will be somewhat offset by a lesser number of patients going to hospital at Fort Yukon, which is not in Canadian territory.

Dear Sir:

I have received your letter of Nov. 25 regarding a nurse-school teacher for Old Crow in the Yukon Territory, and I am pleased to see that provision is being made in your draft estimates to provide the sum of $1000.00 to cover the salary and maintenance of such a worker, and I sincerely hope that when the final estimates are passed that this particular amount will not have been deleted. I feel quite confident that if the right person can be secured for this position, a great deal that will be a benefit to the Indians of that area can be accomplished.

As you are no doubt aware, Old Crow is a rather remote spot and transportation to and from it is not at all easy. However, in view of the fact that the worker is to combine the two duties, that of school teacher and nurse, I think it should be possible to find one who would be able to undertake the task at the sum mentioned.

I presume that you will be expecting us to provide the living quarters and I have no doubt that this can be arranged. I shall write to you again regarding this matter as you suggest, about the beginning of March next. In the meantime I shall endeavour to find out if a suitable worker can be secured. I have in mind at the moment a fully qualified nurse who has had northern experience and who might be willing to undertake this position, but I fully understand that no definite arrangements can be made until the final estimates have passed parliament.

In the meantime I should like to bring to your attention another matter concerning Old Crow. In June last there was returned from our school at Carcross an Indian boy who had reached the age limit for Indian education. This young man, Philip Joseph by name, is greatly handicapped in that he has only one leg, and it will be almost impossible for him to earn a living for himself in that country by hunting and trapping. In
order to help him out in a financial way as well as to find him some occupation, I have arranged for him to teach school during this winter whenever opportunity affords. In this work he will be under the direct supervision of Mrs. Kirk, the wife of the Corporal of the Mounted Police stationed at Old Crow. Mrs. Kirk is a full qualified school teacher who came to Old Crow as a bride this year and she has been most willing to help Philip Joseph in this work. If your department can see its way clear to make a small per diem grant for the days that Philip Joseph will be able to teach school, I feel quite sure that it will be a great help, not only in providing him with the means of livelihood, but to enable him to do something in a country where work is not easy to be had.

Dear Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of January fifth. There appears to be some misunderstanding regarding the rate of salary to be paid to the teacher at Old Crow in the Yukon.

On November 25th 1935, the Deputy Superintendent General of Indian Affairs wrote to me that an amount of $1800.00 was being placed in the estimates to provide for a nurse-teacher at Old Crow and asked me to secure someone for the position. On February 15, 1936 in accepting my nomination of Miss McCabe, R.N., for this position the Deputy Superintendent General wrote that an amount of $1200.00 would be paid as for the services of the Nurse, and an amount of $600.00 would be paid as a salary for the teacher, and that this sum, on the basis of $60.00 per month for ten teaching months, would be paid direct to Miss McCabe. In the absence of any information to the contrary from Miss McCabe, I assumed that this amount was paid to her during the four years she was at Old Crow. In the light of your letter mentioned above I shall be glad to hear from you just what salary was paid to Miss McCabe from your branch of the service.

While at Old Crow Miss McCabe's health broke down and she had to leave there in July 1940. For more than two years she had to remain at home to regain her health and it was only last October that she was able to resume work again. Her breakdown was caused largely by the isolation at a place such as Old Crow, but was in part due to the fact that at Old Crow at certain times of the year all the able-bodied natives leave the settlement and at such times Miss McCabe could secure no one to do the chores, such as bringing the water from the river etc. When she left Old Crow, Miss McCabe very strongly urged me not to send another single woman to such a remote post. She urged, and others whom I consulted agreed, that it would be much better to have at Old Crow a young married couple, the wife being a qualified nurse. In the autumn of 1940 I consulted the Director of Indian Affairs regarding this and he assured me that if a fully qualified person could be found the Department would have no
objection to her being married.

In the spring of 1941 I contacted a young couple in Vancouver who had just been married. The wife had graduated at the head of her class from the Vancouver General Hospital in 1937 and had practiced her profession of Nursing till April 1941. They agreed to go to Old Crow and came to the Yukon in June of that year. Transportation difficulties arose and for a time it looked as if they might not get to Old Crow that year. Eventually however they were able to proceed and reached Old Crow in the early part of September 1941. Mrs Ellis was appointed nurse as from Oct. 1st 1941 and the salary of $100.00 per month has been paid from that date. As Mr Ellis had had previous experience teaching Indians, Mrs Ellis suggested that it would be much better if Mr Ellis did the teaching, and again with the consent of the Director of Indian Affairs I nominated Mr Ellis for the position of Teacher and received your letter making the appointment.

About one month ago I received a letter from Mr Phelan, Chief of the Training Division, stating that no salary had been paid because no school returns had been received. I immediately communicated with Mr Ellis and received a reply that Returns had been sent and in due course as your letter states they reached your office. Now you state that instead of paying the teacher on a monthly basis as was agreed when this work was undertaken you are allowing only a per diem grant for the days the School was open. I shall be glad to hear from you regarding this work, and if a change in the agreed remuneration has been made, when and why was it done.

As regards to the value of the work that was done at Old Crow by Miss McCabe, and the work that is being done at the present time by Mr. and Mrs Ellis, I think there can be no question. I understand that when the Indian Agent visited Old Crow in the summer of 1939 he was so impressed with the work being done there that he advocated the institution of similar workers at other points in the Yukon.

Yours truly,

[Signature]
