Dear Sir:

We, the undersigned Indian residents of the Old Crow district wish to bring to your attention the following points. This is for your consideration in connection with the establishment of an Indian Residential School at Old Crow. This matter having been the subject of some previous discussion between yourself and Joseph NETRO, Old Crow trader, who is one of us.

1st. We are all in favour of a Residential School at Old Crow and would like to see one established here.

2nd. We do not like sending our children to the Residential School at Carcross Y.T. for the following reasons.

(a) We are unable to ever see our children when they are at Carcross School because of the distance involved, and in the past Old Crow children have remained at that school from admission until discharge, in some cases being 13 years of age by that time. During this spread of years they lose touch with their relatives and parents.

(b) At that school children lose touch with our way of life, which is the way they must make their living. When they return they are considered "no good" for they have to re-learn our language, learn how to trap and hunt and make their way in the woods, and learn our whole way of life. All of these things they should have learned during childhood years.

(c) There is a great difference in climatic conditions here and at Carcross. We have found that our children upon returning here must become re-acclimatized.

(d) It has been noticed in the past that our children so lose touch with us during a long absence at that school, that they look down upon their parents and our (and their) natural way of life.

These are some of the reasons why we have not been sending our children to school far from home for the past ten or more years.

3rd. Were a school established at Old Crow, the above disadvantages would be eliminated, and we would be able to see our children occasionally in accordance with school rules, and have their company during holiday periods. We have heard from friends at Aklavik N.W.T. how well it works out when the Residential School is in the district that is native to the child. It appears they are not losing touch with their natural way of life, and their natural climate, and it seems that holiday periods are arranged so that the children are free during the season when the bulk of our yearly income is secured, such as in the muskrat season, the larger children are free, and able to help, as well as becoming proficient in our ways of trapping. We feel that a school at Old Crow would keep the children in touch with us. They would not forget our language, would not disdain the livelihood of their parents which is what they must follow. They would not have forgotten the way in which to hunt, trap and fish and look after themselves in the woods.

4th. We are in favour of a Residential school instead of a day school. A day school requires that the parents of school children remain in the village during the whole of the school term in order to provide a home for the children near the school. This is impossible for us as we must scatter through the district to follow our trapping and hunting. With a Residential School we are able to go our ways and make our living, knowing that our children are receiving the care and training that they need. A Residential School would get away from a situation such as exists at present when there is not day school available due to the lack of a teacher.
Many of us have discussed the desirability of a move to Akilavik, N.W.T., in order to secure educational facilities. This would allow us to be reasonably close to our children in school. But we do not want to move from Old Crow. Sooner or later we would return here, and in the interim would have lost our own traplines, for we could not expect to hold a trapline during several years of absence. We would have to find some means of livelihood there, or secure a trapline in that area. We would also have to adapt ourselves from a meat diet to a fish diet. We all agree it would be much better for us all were a school established here.

Thanking you for your consideration of our needs, and for your request that we write you on this subject

Yours very truly

Sir:

1. On Nov. 12th a wire was received from Mr. R.J. Meek, Indian Agent, Whitehorse, Y.T., as follows:
   HAVE TEACHER FOR INDIAN DAY SCHOOL WHAT IS YOUR ADVICE POSSIBILTY CONTINUING SCHOOL FROM JANUARY ON STOP

   MY OC

The following therefore is in response to the above, and may same be expedited please to the agent. It is thought well to be quite lengthy and touch the many angles, so that the Agent will have full details on hand, to assist in his decision.

2. It might be well to remark in beginning; that nine Old Crow children are absent at Carcross School, one at Akleivik School, three (mixed blood) at Dawson Hostel, and two families containing eight children of school age have moved from this district because of the absence of any school facilities here.

3. It would also be well to point out that it is an impossibility for the families to remain in the settlement at some seasons of the year, as they must go far afielde in order to make their living and the whole family moving out with the breadwinner. There are, for instance, only about six children of school age in the settlement at the present moment. Also during the period from mid-April to about June 20th, in each year, there would not be more than one or two children in town unless illness caused any family to remain in any given year, this being the usual spring hunting time for muskrat, the districts' greatest source of income. I have drawn up the following list of the school age children at present in the district, giving the ages, during 1948, of each, his status (Indian otherwise) and the probable time that each will be available for school during 1948. There is also the possibility that some children who are spending the present winter far afielde may be moved into the settlement for next autumn if a school is in existence, the parents planning accordingly. These are noted as possibilities. The list follows:

As intimated earlier, the above is an estimation of the availability for school of the children, who total eighteen, during 1943. There is no doubt that the parents are keen to have their children receive schooling. There is no doubt in my mind, that apart from the "Three Rs" the discipline will be of great value, for there is practically no parental discipline maintained in the average home.

5. As to a school building, there is a small log building originally built for a school, belonging to the Anglican Mission. However it is small and is cold. It is usable during the spring, summer and autumn, but would be very difficult to heat in the winter. Rev. J.M. Ellis, when he was here, would not use this building in winter for the latter reason; he used a mission building presently occupied by Rev. and Mrs. Kendall as their living quarters, for a school in winter time. Same is of course now not available; however, if a teacher was being sent in during the present winter, the building mentioned in the first sentence of this para. would have to be plastered and fixed to do in a make shift way for this winter, no other being available.

6. With regard to living quarters for a teacher, the only quarters available, is a Mission residence previously occupied by Rev. and Mrs. Ellis, which is at present vacant. This house would be suitable for either a single teacher, or a married couple, and has the advantage that it is completely furnished less blankets, linens, etc. It is supposed that the Dept. could acquire this building from the Anglican Mission. There is no other suitable place for a teacher to live. He, or she, would of course have to "hatch". There are only the two married couples (white) in the district, neither of whom would have the room for a boarder, available, and in the case of the writer, we would not have sufficient supplies on hand to permit a boarder.

7. It may hardly be within the scope of the advice required from me, but it is felt that I should mention that living costs at a place like Old Crow are very high, provisions costing approximately double the price of Dawson. And with a school being started in midwinter, depriving the teacher of the ability to purchase outside before next summer, he will be dependent on the Old Crow stores for provisions. Might I suggest therefore that it is most unlikely that the salary paid a teacher would cover the cost of his living here, where living costs are so high by reason of isolation? It would appear fairer for the Dept. to pay the teacher a small salary, and supply him with a given quantity of supplies, his quarters, heat and light in addition thereto. Somewhat similar to our Police system in remote areas.

8. With regard to the transportation into this district during the winter months, of course air is the only method available, and it has occurred to me that possibly if all other difficulties have been overcome, and it is dependent on transportation costs as to whether or not the school is opened, that the whole matter might fold up by reason of the high cost of a plane from Whitehorse to Old Crow. I would point out that the most economical route to Old Crow would be to take any regular method to Fairbanks chartering a plane to Old Crow from that point. It is possible in Fairbanks to charter a small one-passenger plane (carrying very little baggage) to Old Crow for one hundred and twenty five dollars, or larger sized aircraft in proportion up to a Norseman carrying nearly a ton for approximately four hundred and fifty dollars.
9. The natives are all out of town for the present time, and I am unable to sound any of them out re the school opening, from the point of view of fuel for the school and residence. Fuel is a problem here, especially dry wood. However it is thought that they can be secured to cut wood, and probably the N.C. Co. "east" could be secured to haul same. Same would probably be very expensive by reason of the long haul by cat, which would be necessary in the winter.

10. With regard to school supplies, there seems to be quite a sufficient quantity of such supplies as scribblers, drawing books, readers, simple arithmetics, chalk, geographies, etc., to go on with. However, I see no pencils, crayons, or blackboard erasers. It would probably be well to have some of these latter come in with the teacher. There are of course, no proper desks, benches having been used for seats.

11. Some of the points previously brought out will probably indicate that the set up for a school at Old Crow is not too good at present. It will be also apparent that mid-winter is the most difficult time in which to get a school started. None of the difficulties are insurmountable however. As to whether starting the school at this season of added expense would be justified, this will depend on departmental policy, and the type of teachers secured. Should it be intended to secure permanent teachers, and build up a proper day school, and have a permanent day school at Old Crow, by all means get started, for the expense would be warranted. If however, the department should be faced with the possibility of securing teachers, who would come here for a few months experience in the North, or the glamour of it, thus giving Old Crow only a spasmodic school, and under makeshift conditions and buildings, I would opine that the expense thereof would not be warranted by the results secured, and that the whole thing might better be forgotten.

12. With regard to this matter of day schools in the North, might I suggest that consideration be given to the system that the Alaskan native service schools have built up, and it should be mentioned that while numbers of the Alaskan schools are being closed down, it is understood that the Indians are full citizens in Alaska, and that the Federal Govt. wish the Territorial Govt. to assume what is rightly their responsibility, therefore the natives school services were the first curtailment in a huge budget cut during the past year.

13. I have become personally acquainted with several of the Native service teachers in Alaska. It seems that this service usually secures the services of a married couple for a school. Of these married couples, sometimes both hold teachers certificates, but generally the wife is a certificated teacher. She is hired as the teacher, and the husband is hired as maintenance man, often the latter, who is usually a practical type, will furnish annual training. A suitable permanent teachingage is supplied, furnished with heavy furniture. A suitable school is usually adjacent to or if one room, attached to, the residence, as the size of the community warrants. Insofar as I am aware, these schools come under the supervision of the Dept. direct, and are not attached to or operated by any of the various Missions. This system seems to have worked very well, and while I am more closely acquainted with circumstances at Fort Yukon, our closest Alaskan town, the service seems to have always been able to secure teachers, even for such remote spots as Fairbanks, Alaska, on the Arctic Coast, a hundred miles or so from Ft. Barrow. This I would say is more isolated than Old Crow which is the most isolated Yukon village.

14. I would make the points that Old Crow is not a place for a single teacher. With a single male teacher, there is the ever present possibility of entanglement with native girls. It is definitely not a place for a single female teacher, either young or middle aged. Unmarried teachers will never stay for a long period in such isolated places. A suitable married couple will overcome these disadvantages. And for instance, I have personally known three married couples in the Fort Yukon area of Alaska who have spent their lives in the native teaching service. The results obtained at Ft. Yukon itself, by the past two teachers in the past ten years, have been outstanding.
15. Should the Department be interested in the possibilities outlined in the past three paragraphs, I should be glad to outline what I would consider a suitable school set up for a day school at Old Crow. It is pointed out that should a permanent day school be in operation in Old Crow, that most probably the parents would want their children to return from Carcross etc., thus relieving the overcrowdedness which is understood to exist there. I would consider that if all the Old Crow children were at home, that there would be an average of thirty, probably more, children of school age in the district at all times.

16. To return to the main topic of this report however, the facts as outlined in the foregoing hereof are submitted in the hope they may be of assistance to the Agent in his decision as to whether or not, to start a day school here during January. Re: Indian Day School - Old Crow Y.T.
Enquiries by Indian Agent.

Sir:

1. On Nov. 12th a wire was received from Mr. R.J. Meek, Indian Agent, Whitehorse, Y.T., as follows:
   HAVE TEACHER FOR INDIAN DAY SCHOOL WHAT IS YOUR ADVICE POSSIBILITIES CONDUCTING SCHOOL FROM JANUARY ON STOP HOW MANY CHILDREN WHITE AND INDIAN WHAT SCHOOL FACILITIES AND WHAT LIVING QUARTERS FOR TEACHER
to which I replied as follows, dated today-
RE SCHOOL MATTER TOO LENGTHY FOR FULL DETAILS BY WIRE AM EXPECTING AIRCRAFT WITHIN WEEK WILL AIRMAIL REPORT VIA MY OC

The following therefore is in response to the above, and may same be expedited please to the Agent. It is thought well to be quite lengthy and touch the many angles, so that the Agent will have full details on hand, to assist in his decision.

2. It might be well to remark in beginning that nine Old Crow children are absent at Carcross School, one at Aklavitk School, three (mixed blood) at Dawson Hostel, and two families containing eight children of school age have moved from this district because of the absence of any school facilities here.

3. It would also be well to point out that it is an impossibility for the families to remain in the settlement at some seasons of the year, as they must go far afield in order to make their living and the whole family moving out with the breadwinner. There are, for instance, only about six children of school age in the settlement at the present moment. Also during the period from mid-April to about June 20th, in each year, there would not be more than one or two children in town, unless sickness caused any family to remain in any given year, this being the usual spring hunting time for muskrat, the districts' greatest source of income.

I have drawn up the following list of the school age children at present in the district, giving the ages, during 1948, of each his status (Indian or otherwise) and the probable time that each will be available for school during 1948. There is also the possibility that some children who are spending the present winter far afield may be moved into the settlement for next autumn if a school is in existence, the parents planning accordingly. These are noted as possibilities. The list follows:

As anticipated earlier, the above is an estimation of the availability for school of the children, who total eighteen, during 1948. There is no doubt that the parents are keen to have their children receive schooling. There is no doubt in my mind, that apart from the "Three Rs" the discipline will be of great value, for there is practically no parental discipline maintained in the average home.

5. As to a school building, there is a small log building originally built for a school, belonging to the Anglican Mission. However it is small and is cold. Is usable during the spring, summer and autumn but would be very difficult to heat in the winter. Rev. J.W. Ellis, when he was here, would not use this building in winter for the latter reason; he used a mission building presently occupied by Rev. and Mrs. Kendig as their living quarters, for a school in winter time. Same is of course now not available; however, if a teacher was being sent in during the present winter, the building mentioned in the first sentence of this para. would have to be plastered and fixed to do in a make shift way for this winter, no other being available.

6. With regard to living quarters for a teacher, the only quarters available, is a mission residence previously occupied by Rev. and Mrs. Ellis, which is at present vacant. This house would be suitable for either a single teacher, or a married couple, and has the advantage that it is completely furnished less blankets, linens, etc. It is supposed that the Dept. could acquire this building from the Anglican Mission. There is no other suitable place for a teacher to live. He, or she, would of course have to "batch". There are only the two married couples (white) in the district, neither of whom would have the room for a boarder, available, and in the case of the writer, we would not have sufficient supplies on hand to permit a boarder.

7. It may hardly be within the scope of the advice required from me, but it is felt that I should mention that living costs at a place like Old Crow are very high, provisions costing approximately double the price of Dawson. And with a school being started in midwinter, depriving the teacher of the ability to purchase outside before next summer, he will be dependent on the Old Crow stores for provisions. Might I suggest therefore, that it is most unlikely that the salary paid a teacher would cover the cost of his living here, where living costs are so high by reason of isolation? It would appear fairer for the Dept. to pay the teacher a small salary, and supply him with a given quantity of supplies, his quarters, heat and light in addition thereto. Somewhat similar to our Police system in remote areas.

8. With regard to the transportation into this district during the winter months, of course air is the only method available, and it has occurred to me that possibly if all other difficulties have been overcome, and it is dependent on transportation costs as to whether or not the school is opened, that the whole matter might fold up by reason of the high cost of a plane from Whitehorse to Old Crow. I would point out that the most economical route to Old Crow would be to take any regular method to Fairbanks chartering a plane to Old Crow from that point. It is possible in Fairbanks to charter a small one-passenger plane (carrying very little baggage) to Old Crow for one hundred and twenty five dollars, or larger sized aircraft in proportion up to a Norseman carrying nearly a ton for approximately four hundred and fifty dollars.
9. The natives are all out of town for the present time, and I am unable to sound any of them out re the school opening, from the point of view of fuel for the school and residence. Fuel is a problem here, especially dry wood. However it is thought that they can be secured to cut wood, and probably the N.C. Co. "cat" could be secured to haul same. Same would probably be very expensive by reason of the long haul by cat, which would be necessary in the winter.

10. With regard to school supplies, there seems to be quite a sufficient quantity of such supplies as scribblers, drawing books, readers, simple arithmetics, chalk, geographies, etc., to go on with. However, I see no pencils, crayons, or blackboard erasers. It would probably be well to have some of these latter come with the teacher. There are of course, no proper desks, benches having been used for seats.

11. Some of the points previously brought out will probably indicate that the set up for a school at Old Crow is not too good at present. It will be also apparent that mid-winter is the most difficult time in which to get a school started. None of the difficulties are insurmountable however. As to whether starting the school at this season of added expense would be justified, this will depend on departmental policy, and the type of teachers secured. Should it be intended to secure permanent teachers, and build up a proper day school, and have a permanent school at Old Crow, by all means get started, as the expense would be warranted. If however, the department should be faced with the possibility of securing teachers, who would come here for a few months experience in the North, or the glamour of it, thus giving Old Crow only a spasmodic school, and under makeshift conditions and buildings, I would opine that the expense thereof would not be warranted by the results secured, and that the whole thing might better be forgotten.

12. With regard to this matter of day schools in the North, might I suggest that consideration be given to the system that the Alaskan native service schools have built up, and it should be mentioned that while numbers of the Alaskan schools are being closed down, it is understood that the Indians are full citizens in Alaska, and that the Federal Govt. wish the Territorial Govt. to assume what is rightly their responsibility, therefore the natives school services were the first curtailment in a huge budget cut during the past year.

13. I have become personally acquainted with several of the Native service teachers in Alaska. It seems that this service usually secures the services of a married couple for a school. Of these married couples, sometimes both hold teachers certificates, but generally the wife is a certificated teacher. She is hired as the teacher, and the husband is hired as maintenance man; often the latter, who is usually a practical type, will teach manual training. A suitable permanent teacherage is supplied, furnished with heavy furniture. A suitable school is usually adjacent to or if one room, attached to, the residence, as the size of the community warrants. Insofar as I am aware, these schools come under the supervision of the Dept. direct, and are not necessarily supervised by any of the various Missions. This system seems to have worked very well, and while I am more closely acquainted with circumstances at Fort Yukon, our closest Alaskan town, the service seems to have always been able to secure teachers even for such remote spots as Wainwright, Alaska, on the Arctic Coast, a hundred miles or so from Pt. Barrow. This I would say is more isolated than Old Crow which is the most isolated Yukon Village.

14. I would make the points that Old Crow is not a place for a single teacher. With a single male teacher, there is the ever present possibility of entanglement with native girls. It is definitely not a place for a single female teacher, either young or middle aged. Unmarried teachers will never stay for a long period in such isolation. A suitable married couple will overcome these disadvantages. And for instance, I have personally known three married couples in the Fort Yukon area of Alaska who have spent their lives in the native teaching service. The results obtained at Ft. Yukon itself, by the past two teachers in the past ten years, have been outstanding.
15. Should the Department be interested in the possibilities outlined in the past three paragraphs, I should be glad to outline what I would consider a suitable school set up for a day school at Old Crow. It is pointed out that should a permanent day school be in operation in Old Crow, that most probably the parents would want their children to return from Carcross etc., thus relieving the overcrowdedness which is understood to exist there. I would consider that if all the Old Crow children were at home, that there would be an average of thirty, probably more, children of school age in the district at all times.

16. To return to the main topic of this report however, the facts as outlined in the forepart hereof are submitted in the hope they may be of assistance to the Agent in his decision as to whether or not, to start a day school here during January. Should it be decided to start a school, it would be appreciated if the Agent could notify me to this effect as soon as possible. I can then get word to the various families, and can possibly have the natives make some preparation at least.

(signed) Corp. R.A. Kirk 10035
i/c Old Crow Detachment.
Indian Affairs Branch,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

Re: Old Crow Day School

Further to correspondence and various telegrams re the above matter, I attach hereto two copies of a very complete report submitted by Corp. E.A. Kirk, R.C.M.P., i/c Old Crow Detachment.

It would appear that winter time is a poor season to open a school at Old Crow. Navigation downstream from Whitehorse can be depended upon for the first week in June, and the Porcupine River, upon which Old Crow is situated a week or two later.

As the former school at Old Crow was conducted under Church of England auspices, I am informing Archbishop Adams (now Bishop of the Yukon) of developments to date, and am sending him a copy of Corp. Kirk's report.

I am informing Corp. Kirk that there is little possibility of immediate action being taken with regard to opening the day school. Your further instructions in this regard are awaited.

(R.J. Meek)

Dear Bishop Geddes:

I have your letter of the 5th instant, regarding the engagement of a nurse-school teacher at Old Crow, Yukon Territory. Funds will be available for salary as from April first, next. I would suggest that, in due time, you nominate the services of a qualified nurse-school teacher for this point and inform the Department fully concerning the name, age, qualifications and experience.

I note you have arranged to have Philip Joseph, an ex-pupil of the Carcross Indian Residential School, conduct classes at Old Crow during the present winter months and that he will carry on the work under the direct supervision of the wife of the Corporal of the Mounted Police stationed at that point, who is a fully qualified teacher. Regarding your request that a grant be provided towards his salary during the period he teaches this school, I would say that the Department will allow the sum of $2.50 per teaching day. This will be paid upon receipt of a return, showing the attendance and the actual number of days taught by him up to the end of March, next. As our funds during the present fiscal year are limited, this is the full grant we can provide in payment for Philip Joseph's services. I would request that you have him prepare the return, stating definitely the number of days he taught, and forward same to the Department.

Yours very truly,

Deputy Superintendent General.

Ottawa, July 5, 1938.

Dear Sir:

In connection with the salary paid to Miss Mildred E. McCabe, I would point out that $600.00 of the amount is paid from the Vote for Indian Education. In order to do this, she is classified as a teacher, and, as our usual system is to pay on the basis of ten months of the academic year, she will be allowed salary as teacher at the rate of $60.00 a month for ten months.

On receipt of the return for the quarter ended September 30, 1937, it was found that the school had been open for the months of June, August and September and, consequently, $180.00 was sent to her. A similar amount was paid at the end of December, and we are issuing another cheque for the March quarter for the same sum. This will mean that since July first, 1937, she has been paid $540. Therefore, when her June quarter return is received, it will only be possible to allow her $60.00, which is the balance of the amount provided for her services as teacher.

Teslin Post, Oct. 25th, 1941.

Mr. G.A. Jeckell,
Indian agent,
Dawson, Y.T.

Dear Mr. Jeckell:

In compliance with Chapter 98, Part 1, No. 10 of the revised Statutes of Canada requiring that "No Protestant child shall be assigned to a Roman Catholic School or a school conducted under Roman Catholic auspices; and no Roman Catholic child shall be assigned to a Protestant school or a school conducted under Protestant auspices"; and at the request of their Excellencies our Bishops Dunoz and Coudeur, I opened a day school at Teslin last summer for our Catholic children.

School opened June the 13th, immediately after the Indians came to the Town and closed September the 25th. Attendance at school was very good. 16 Catholic children between the ages of six and sixteen came to school regularly and 4 above sixteen years of age came to school quite often. We had to buy all our school supplies for this first summer school.

As I am in residence at Teslin, I expect to have a summer school every year for our Catholic children and we would appreciate very much the help of the Indian Department in our school work.

Would you kindly let me know if the Indian Department would grant our school supplies for the summer 1942. You will find here enclosed a list of all the items needed for our school.

A new census has been taken last summer and you can see that a good half of the Indian population living at Teslin is Catholic. Others are under Instruction - so I am confident that the Indian Department will help us in our school work.

Thanking you for your kindness to us in the past, I remain,

Yours truly,

(Sgd.) Father A. Drea, O.M.I.
Teslin Lake.
DAWSON, Y.T. January 21, 1942.

Sir:

I enclose copy of a letter received from Reverend Father A. Dream, C.M.I., of Teslin Lake, Yukon Territory, which contains a request that the Indian Affairs Branch recognize the summer Day School which is being conducted by Father Dream for Roman Catholic Indian Children at Teslin Post, Yukon Territory.

Father Dream states that a day school was opened at Teslin last summer for Catholic children. The school was opened on June 13th and closed September 25th. Eighteen Catholic children between the ages of six and sixteen attended regularly. Father Dream states that he is in residence at Teslin and is prepared to conduct a summer school every year for Catholic children.

I would ask for favourable consideration for this application for assistance. The customary grant should be made and school supplies should be furnished. A Day School has been conducted at Teslin by the Anglican Church, and the same favourable consideration should be given for a Roman Catholic Day School.

Owing to the fact that mail communications with Teslin Post are irregular, particularly in the winter time, I would ask that you communicate the decision of the Department direct to Right Reverend Bishop Coudert, Whitehorse, Yukon Territory.

Yours truly,

G.A. Jeckell

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 21st instant enclosing copy of letter received from Rev. A. Dream, O.M.I., regarding the Indian seasonal school which he intends to conduct at Teslin Lake during the summer of 1942.

The whole question of administering seasonal schools in the Stikine Agency and surrounding territory is now under review by Indian Commissioner MacKay, Vancouver. This was requested by a recent report received from Mr. Coleman, Inspector of Indian Agencies for British Columbia, who visited the seasonal schools in the Stikine Agency during the past summer. Until a definite decision is reached regarding the policy which we should follow in regard to seasonal schools in the north country, the Department is not prepared to recognize any new seasonal schools to the extent of allowing any salary to the teacher. However, we are willing to assist by supplying some school supplies and an order is being placed with the Government Stationery Office. It is not our intention to allow all the articles requested by Father Dream, nor in the quantities that he apparently desires, as it is considered that his requests are excessive in some particulars.

Yours truly,

Dear Bishop Coudert:

I am in receipt of a letter today from Father Drean in which he states that you have advised him that the Teslin Lake R.C. Day School has been recognized by the Department.

You will recall that when you visited our office I advised you that it would be necessary to secure an Order-in-Council before the school could be officially recognized. James Coleman, Esq., Inspector of Indian Agencies for B.C.

Your 1941 Inspection Report instructed that the question of another seasonal school under Roman Catholic auspices being established at Teslin Lake be investigated and reported on. Owing to the disturbed condition of affairs at Teslin Lake since the advent of the Alaska Highway and Teslin Airport it was considered advisable to wait until things became more settled before attempting to report the situation. On my last visit to Teslin in January the Indians appear to be resuming their former occupations gradually but a complete return to normal is not yet evident. This naturally affects any proposal of creating new seasonal schools.

Conditions have been watched during the past two years and it now appears that the R.C. Mission at Teslin has given up the idea of opening a school at Johnstown and have been carrying on a day school at Teslin Post, Yukon, at which both Yukon and B.C. Indian children attend. The Department is apparently paying $3.00 per teaching day for an indefinite length term to the Rev. Father Dream, C.M.I., for conducting the school. I understand that the Anglican mission also receives a similar allowance for the operation of their day school. The attendance is about equally divided between the schools.

As the majority of the Teslin Indians are Yukon membership arrangements concerning these schools are evidently all handled through the Indian Agent at Dawson for no official word has come to this office. Bishop Coucort of Whitehorse recently informed that Ottawa had authorized the construction of an R.C. day school, probably seasonal, at Teslin Post but this office has no official knowledge of it.

A further report will be submitted next July on my return from Teslin Lake when I will have had a further opportunity to obtain the most recent details of the situation at first hand.

R.H.S. Sampson,
Indian Agent.

Memorandum:

SUPERINTENDENT OF EDUCATION

Attendance of Indian Children at Teslin Joint School

I have reviewed the file and noted that the Reverend Father Drean was involved in disputes at Teslin years before Mr. Superintendent Meek entered our service.

I attach a copy of a report on the Whitehorse Indian Day School in which there are allusions to Family Allowance stoppages and to the necessity of determining the denominational affiliation of Indian children. Mr. Superintendent Meek has a copy of this report and he may be alluding to it in his letter of December 27 to Reverend Father Drean. The Teslin question, however, had not arisen at the time of my discussions with Mr. Superintendent Meek.

I do not recall having advised Mr. Meek that some clergymen would have the children of their denomination stay away from school entirely rather than attend a school that is not conducted under denominational auspices. Reverend Father Drean appears to be a clergyman of this type.

Mr. Superintendent Meek's action in attempting to enforce attendance may have its origin in your letter of June 25, 1949, in which you agree that "it would not be practical to operate the Teslin Seasonal School in view of the fact that we are now cooperating with the Yukon Territory in the operation of a joint school". I can not think that it would occur to Mr. Superintendent Meek or to Mr. School Inspector Hulland or, indeed, to any Yukon official that in the circumstances...
we would operate a seasonal school for any denomination. The development of the Roman Catholic White school at Whitehorse may serve to acquaint these gentlemen with the philosophy of denominational education.

I note that the present teacher at Teslin is a Miss Clancy and that no information is given concerning her religious affiliation which, of course, ought not to be a consideration, interest or influence in a non-sectarian school. She seems to regard the local children primarily as candidates for instruction in the school curriculum and probably considers that the non-attendance of the Jule children is a disturbing factor on the other pupils. We are not informed where these Jule children spend most of their time. Reverend Father Drean suggests that they ought to be on the trapping grounds but very likely they are hanging around the post most of the time. Reverend Father Drean says "Other parents are sending their children to the Territorial school and making the real sacrifice of staying here instead of being on their trapping grounds where they could live much better, until better provisions can be made for their children. I am afraid (sic) new adjustments will have to be made then and without prejudice." From this statement it is a fair deduction that Reverend Father Drean will follow a course designed to eliminate all Indian pupils from this school as it is obvious that he hopes to persuade "other parents" to his way of thinking.

According to a religious census prepared in 1939, Charlie Jule was regarded as Roman Catholic. At that time Effie Jule was three years old and Katie four months. Unless the father has changed his affiliation in the meantime, an affidavit would be required only if he wished his children to attend the Teslin Joint School. If he is still a Roman Catholic no affidavit is required if he wants to keep his children away.

On the other hand Peter Sydney is the child of Anglican parents and the Reverend Father Drean is out of court in
claiming that he should not attend Teslin School. In this case if exemption from attendance is desired an affidavit is necessary. The danger is that the "other parents" may also seek to exempt their children. In that case the existence of the joint school must be brief.

I suggest that Mr. Superintendent Meek be requested to supply the following information:

(1) To what religious denomination does Charlie Jule now adhere?

(2) The same question for the parents of Peter Sydney.

(3) Do the three children live at the Teslin settlement most of the time?

It also seems necessary to decide whether a Roman Catholic Seasonal School should be operated at Teslin.

C.A.F. Clark,
Educational Survey Officer.

Rev. Sir:

The action on your part of taking away the Jule children from the Territorial school created certain problems which necessitated a considerable amount of writing to and from Ottawa. Col. Neary has replied, and I attach hereto a copy of a ruling given by Duncan Scott in 1922. I particularly draw your attention to the last paragraph. Col. Neary ends his letter with this statement:

"You can appreciate, therefore, the need for a short affidavit, taken in your presence, and relating to the wishes of the father with regard to attendance at both day and residential schools."

We have run into the same difficulty at both Whitehorse and Carcross Residential Schools. In a case similar to that of Pete Sidney which you mention, Col. Neary, in a letter written August 24th 1949, states:

"The transfer of young Indian children from one educational institution to another entails various adjustments which are not easy for such children to make, and failure to make them is likely to produce undesirable results. The change suggested for these children will, therefore, not be authorized at this time. It is considered, moreover, that as long as there are said to be children in your Agency who are not regularly attending any school, existing schools should draw their enrolment from such children rather than seek to enrol children for whom adequate arrangements have already been made."

I gather from the foregoing instructions to me, that Pete Sidney will remain at Teslin School. As to the Jules, an affidavit is required by the father.

Yours truly,

(R.J. Meek) Superintendent.

Dear Sir:

Thank you for your letter of February the 21st received yesterday and the attached copy of a ruling given by Duncan Scott in 1922.

I absolutely reject your accusation of taking the Juk Children from the Territorial school at Teshin, and if such accusation was made by you to anyone, I would kindly ask you to withdraw it. I did not take the Juk Children from the Territorial school and I never told Charlie Juk, nor any other person for that matter, to withdraw their children from the said school. I did not believe I had authority to do so.

On the other hand, I know for a fact that strong pressure was used, last year, and even threats made, to get Charlie Juk's children and other children in the Territorial school. I heard of these threats and still never said a word pro or con.
It was only when I came to the knowledge, by one of your letters to Sandy Fox, that the family allowance of Effie and Killa Jule had been suspended and when Charlie Jule himself, had decided, in protest, to withdraw his children from the Territorial school, that I entered the picture, for their protection, because I did not believe the sanction fair. These children attended the summer school provided for them before they went to Grouard, and since they came back from Grouard, and they were being forced in the Territorial school board, against their wishes and against the wishes of their Parents.

Other parents are sending their children to the Territorial school and making the real sacrifice of staying here instead of being on their trapping grounds where they could live much better, until better provisions can be made for their children. I am afraid new adjustments will have to be made then and without prejudice. At least it is the desire of the parents and I am sure the Department of Indian Affairs will do them justice.

About the Jule children, Col. Shary has replied that an affidavit is required by the Fathers.
In other words: Charlie Jule and his wife are Roman Catholics, their children are Roman Catholics, therefore these children must go to a Roman Catholic school, unless Charlie Jule signs an affidavit to the contrary, which affidavit must not be forced upon them by threats.... Duncan Scott says: "... And the person who takes such affidavit must certify that the statements set forth in the affidavit were read over or interpreted and explained to the deponent who thoroughly understood the same."

The affidavit has been signed by Charlie Jule.... and still sanctions are taken against the children. Do you believe this fair and just?

Orders were given to Gordon Ireland, storekeeper for Taylor and Dury at Teslin, in a letter dated Feb 15th, to reduce Mr. Charlie Jule's family allowance from $35.00 dollars to $21.00 dollars, starting the 1st of March.

I took a copy of that letter and sent it to Ottawa.

I am sorry this dispute had to happen. When Indian Department authorities and Religious Authorities should cooperate and work together for the settlement and the welfare of the Indians.
But I had no choice in the matter.
Hoping this will lead us to a better understanding of the situation and of each other's opinions.

I am
Yours Very Truly,

Whitehorse Indian School:

From Fort St. John I made an unannounced visit to Whitehorse and viewed the activities at this school (art classes excepted) on the morning of Thursday, Nov. 3 and on Friday, Nov. 4. As the art teacher is at this school only the first three days of each week, I had to have an evening discussion with her. I think we may be confident that the children will benefit from her teaching. I gave her one copy of "Good Health for Canada's Indians" and suggested that she might combine her technical ability and increasing familiarity with Indians to produce similar useful illustrated booklets.

May fifty copies (or more, if available) of the named booklet be sent to the Whitehorse School, please, and may the issue to all our schools in the Yukon be confirmed.

The school should be requested to submit age-sex-grade tables for Indian and non-Indian pupils as at Dec. 31, 1949. This is, perhaps, the most significant date. So many of our schools this year seem to be hoping for "filled accommodation by Christmas."

Of the absentees among the day pupils, the attendance of two (Joan Charlie and Betty Shakoos) seems particularly unsatisfactory.

All pupils were seated at large tables on backless forms usually four to a form. As they use only one side of a table so as to face the front of the room, the tables in two rooms are quite close together, and the inner children on each form have difficulty extricating themselves to go to the blackboard or elsewhere. The height of the tables suits only some of the pupils. The desks now on order have more appropriate sizes but there will be only eighty of them. I have asked Mr. Supt. Meek to request your instructions concerning a shipment of desks which are not all needed at Mayo.

As these classrooms still retain the army pattern of fenestration, the teachers must be alert to ensure good ventilation. Heating is by stoves in each room. The lighting fixtures are adequate, in some cases fluorescent having been installed.

You have received completed forms showing the teachers' training and experience. All classes and rooms show that a trained person is in charge. Mrs. Weigand has given her former pupils a good start; Miss Patterson contributes the most missionary zeal, and Mr. Lee brings interest and vigour to the handling of physical education. In this he is aided by our agency clerk, Mr. McDonald, and now by the army authorities.
who grant the use of a hall once a week. A rink is being made ready near the school.

As Mrs. Weigand has 48 pupils registered some adjustment of the teaching loads might be made if Miss Wallinger, when available, is added to the staff without displacing one of the present teachers.

There are in the Yukon more pupils who should be in school, and pressure will continue to be exerted by parents upon the Superintendent to have children admitted to the Rev. Mr. Lee's hostel when according to the Indian Act they belong in schools conducted under other denominational auspices. In an area where the public schools are by statute or custom non-sectarian some people are likely to be unaware or forgetful of the special provisions regarding Indian education, but ecclesiastical influences will be quick to challenge any admissions of children who have any history of affiliation with other branches of the Church. I emphasize the need of close attention to this matter because another building has recently been acquired by the Rev. Mr. Lee - additional to the one in which the hostel was started last year.

The latest addition includes a former army mess-hall and kitchen which compares very favourably with similar installations in our residential schools. There were eighty-eight pupils present at meal-time, and there could be room made for another thirty. The well-equipped kitchen (oil-burning stove) is in charge of Miss Ruth Sponholz who does a good job, including bread-making. She has previous experience in institutions. The walk-in refrigerator, well-stocked with moose meat which only Indian Hospitals and Indian schools in the Yukon may buy from Indians, is an impressive feature.

House-keeping chores receive attention from the pupils outside of regular school hours. As most of the staff come from Alberta, they have some acquaintance with procedures in dormitories conducted in connection with consolidated schools.

The sleeping accommodation is plain but acceptable; the sanitary facilities likewise. Local inspection authorities appear to keep a good watch on the place. Health services in Whitehorse have been reinforced.

There is a small laundry with some machinery, most of the work apparently done by women on the staff.

The future of this experiment is not altogether clear. There cannot be much profit over operating costs, looking to inevitable heavy maintenance and repair. It might be wiped out by fire, or the owners of the land might cease for possession thereof. The town looks forward to replacing its own schools, but admission thereto of Indians seems unlikely. The Roman Catholic school which Bishop Couët graciously invited me to visit (it now has three rooms excellently adapted in a former army building) restricts attendance to white children.

I have your letter of the 22nd ultimo, with reference to the desire of Reverend E. Morisset to open a school at Burwash Landing, Yukon Territory.

It is noted that Father Morisset only requests some school supplies. Re: Indian Day School at Burwash

Dear Mr. Phelan:

I wish to thank you for your encouraging answer regarding the approval of our Indian Day School at Burwash.

The reason why Father E. Morisset did not reply at once to Mr. J.E. Gibben, Indian Agent, was not due to neglect, but on the contrary to the desire of knowing exactly the situation before making a formal application to the Department; it was a new experiment in a part of the country where previously no winter school had ever been conducted; the experiments made in connection with summer schools at that point had been complete failure; we were urgently requested both by the white and indian population to come into that new field; It must be well understood by the Officials of the Department that our work is still in the experimental stage, and this is the reason why I instructed Father E. Morisset to apply for text books only and school supplies but not yet for salary.

My letter of March let was not intended, therefore, as yet to claim a salary to which, I perfectly well know, our teacher is not entitled to; it was intended to prepare the ground for a formal recognition of the school for the school year 1946-1946; by next summer, Father E. Morisset should be in a good position to report accurately on his experiments and on the kind of school he may safely conduct. After the kind of day schools we have seen conducted in such places as Carmacks and Fort Selkirk (which are apparently tolerated by the Branch) we feel absolutely certain that the kind of school we hope to be able to conduct at Burwash will meet the full approval of the Branch.

Here are, for your information, some data concerning the Burwash School, pending the more accurate information Father Morisset intends to send you at a later date.

The School is located in the Burwash Settlement, between the Store and the Indian Village; the Indians of Burwash have good houses, cleaner and better kept, as an average, than the houses of most Indian Camps of the Yukon; they are of the proper Indian stock and are related to the White River Indians; they are all good trappers and hustlers; they seem to reside permanently at Burwash during January, February and a part of March, and again during the whole summer season; some of them even leave their families at Burwash permanently as they are quite close to their trapping grounds. All are anxious to give an education to their children and would be willing to let them board with us, when they are out on their trapping work, if we had accommodation for the children. We have four substantial log buildings with a cement cellar under the buildings; all the buildings are connected together; two are already completed inside with plywood and are quite comfortable; they are the best buildings in the Burwash Settlement.

I will instruct Father E. Morisset to provide you with the additional information you may need before making your final decision.

Yours sincerely in Christ,

J.L. Couderc O.M.I.

To Mr. Gibben,
Indian Agent,
Dawson City, Y.T.

Dear Mr. Gibben,

I am surprised to hear that you did not receive the letter I wrote to you in the beginning of February in answer to yours of August the 14th, 1944, concerning the school of Burwash Landing.

I delayed until February to answer your letter in order to give more accurate information after experience. But it seems that you did not receive the said letter. I answer again therefore to the questions you send me.

1/ Yes, the Indians reside at Burwash Landing itself, about 500 yards from the Trading Post.

2/ They are permanently located there and have decent homes, the most decent Indian homes in Yukon, according to some visitors. They spend most of the year at Burwash or near by. Their trap-lines are situated right across the lake (Kluane Lake). In March they go away to the White River (75 miles from Burwash) to hunt musk-rats, and they come back in May.

3/ I am conducting school in a log building. The school-room itself is 30 by 20 ft., and 10 ft. high. Five windows; three big and two medium size, give light to the room. The building belongs to the Mission.

4/ At the present time, eleven children of school age can attend and in fact attend school. Besides these, three over school age children, who never had any schooling before, attend also regularly.

5/ I think I will be able to teach school five days a week and about five months a year: three months in winter and two in summer.

I remain yours truly,

Fr. Joseph Morisset O.M.I.
Burwash Landing, Y.T.

Re: Roman Catholic Day School,
Burwash Landing, Y. T.

When at Burwash Landing over the week-end of July 27, 28, and 29, I had an interview with Father Morisset, and inspected the premises which have been constructed for a combination of Church and Day School purposes.

Father Morisset, with some assistance from the Indians and others, has erected quite adequate buildings. The one which is in use as a Day School is well constructed, and can be easily heated. Father Morisset has done a good job with the material at his disposal, and has even gone so far as to make desks for his pupils.

The Father informs me that he has twelve or thirteen pupils, five of whom are boys, and one of whom is a half-breed, living the life of an Indian. The pupils are of varying ages, one girl being eighteen, and another twenty-two, years of age. None of them have ever had any schooling before.

The School was opened in January, but was closed during March, April and May, when the pupils were following native pursuits. It has remained open during June and July, but will be closed during August and September, as Father Morisset expects to be in another part of the country.

While, in many respects, it may not conform to strict Indian Day School requirements, in my opinion, the project should receive every encouragement. Father Morisset has furnished me with a list of supplies which are needed, and I enclose a requisition for these. I may say that I am also requisitioning for certain medical supplies which are to be dispensed to the children.

Indian Agent.
Ottawa, 6th September, 1945.

Mr. J.E. Gibben, Indian Agent, Dawson, Y.T.

I have your letter of the 4th ultimo with reference to the Burwash Landing Seasonal School.

It is noted that you found the new building adequate and that reasonable progress is being made in the classroom.

Father Morisset should forward returns for each period during which the school has been open. The first for the period beginning in January, the second for the period June and July and the third at the end of the period when he next teaches. I enclose a supply of forms for this purpose.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

AIRMAL

Ottawa, January 16, 1946.

Dear Bishop Coudert:

Reverend Father Plourde has brought to my attention a letter he recently received from you, with reference to payment of teachers' salaries for seasonal schools.

As we have not received the usual returns, showing the names of the children, days taught, etc., from the respective teachers, the only information that we have available regarding the periods during which the schools were open is taken from the attached copies of letters which you forwarded to Father Plourde.

The cheques that we have issued, as shown on the attached statement, were sent direct to the teachers concerned, previous to the time we received your request that all these salary cheques should be forwarded to your office. We will follow the latter procedure in future, as we have done in a few cases in the past.

I wish you would review the attached statement carefully and advise me the exact period during which each of these schools was in operation in the calendar year 1945. As soon as we receive this information, any additional salary will be paid and we will also allow rent for each of the buildings at a rate of $25.00 a month for each month during which the school was in operation. I will arrange to have payments made for the amounts requested for fuel and janitor services, but any balances
